import Mathlib

/- Vasinivev N. 5.

Can natural numbers be arranged in a $4 \times 4$ table such that the following conditions are simultaneously satisfied:

1) the products of the numbers in each row are the same for all rows;
2) the products of the numbers in each column are the same for all columns;
3) there are no equal numbers among them;
4) all numbers are no greater than 100? -/
theorem number_theory_200312 :
    ‚àÉ a : Fin 4 ‚Üí Fin 4 ‚Üí ‚Ñï,
      (‚àÄ i j, a i j > 0) ‚àß
      (‚àÄ i j, a i j ‚â§ 100) ‚àß
      (‚àÉ p, ‚àÄ i, ‚àè j : Fin 4, a i j = p) ‚àß
      (‚àÉ p, ‚àÄ j, ‚àè i : Fin 4, a i j = p) ‚àß
      (‚àÄ i j, ‚àÄ k l, a i j = a k l ‚Üí i = k ‚àß j = l) := by

soln_description:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\text { 86. } \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leqslant \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}-\sqrt{a b} \Leftrightarrow \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leqslant \frac{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}-a b}{\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}+\sqrt{a b}}= \\
\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}+\sqrt{a b}\right)} \Leftrightarrow a+b \geqslant \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}+\sqrt{a b} \Leftrightarrow(a+b)^{2} \geqslant\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}+\right. \\
\sqrt{a b})^{2}=\frac{(a+b)^{2}}{2}+2 \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}} \quad \sqrt{a b} \Leftrightarrow \frac{(a+b)^{2}}{2} \geqslant 2 \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}} \sqrt{a b} \Leftrightarrow \\
(a+b)^{2} \geqslant \sqrt{2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right) a b} \Leftrightarrow(a+b)^{4} \geqslant 8\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right) a b \Leftrightarrow(a-b)^{4} \geqslant 0 .
\end{array}$$

The left inequality is proved. Now, let's prove the right inequality.
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}} \quad \sqrt{a b} \leqslant \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{4 \sqrt{a b}} \Leftrightarrow \\
\frac{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}-a b}{\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}+\sqrt{a b}} \leqslant \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{4 \sqrt{a b}} \Leftrightarrow \\
\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}+\sqrt{a b}\right)} \leqslant \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{4 \sqrt{a b}} \Leftrightarrow \\
\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}+\sqrt{a b} \geqslant 2 \sqrt{a b} \Leftrightarrow \\
\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}} \geqslant \sqrt{a b} \Leftrightarrow \\
(a-b)^{2} \geqslant 0
\end{array}$$

The right inequality is proved.
informal_statement: 86. Given that $a, b$ are positive numbers, prove: $\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leqslant \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}-\sqrt{a b} \leqslant \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{4 \sqrt{a b}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 86. Given that $a, b$ are positive numbers, prove: $\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leqslant \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}-\sqrt{a b} \leqslant \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{4 \sqrt{a b}}$. -/
theorem inequalities_599585 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    (a - b)^2 / (2 * (a + b)) ‚â§ Real.sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b) ‚àß
    Real.sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b) ‚â§ ((a - b)^2) / (4 * Real.sqrt (a * b)) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_599585 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    (a - b)^2 / (2 * (a + b)) ‚â§ Real.sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b) ‚àß
    Real.sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b) ‚â§ ((a - b)^2) / (4 * Real.sqrt (a * b)) := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- First inequality: $\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leqslant \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}-\sqrt{a b}$
    have h1 : 0 < a * b := by
      nlinarith
    have h2 : Real.sqrt (a * b) > 0 := by
      positivity
    have h3 : Real.sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) ‚â• 0 := by
      positivity
    have h4 : Real.sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b) ‚â• 0 := by
      have h5 : Real.sqrt (a * b) ‚â§ Real.sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) := by
        apply Real.sqrt_le_sqrt
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b)]
      linarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2), Real.sqrt_nonneg (a * b), h5]
    have pos1 : 2 * (a + b) > 0 := by
      nlinarith
    have h10 : (a - b) ^ 2 / (2 * (a + b)) ‚â§ Real.sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b) := by
      have h7 : (a - b) ^ 2 ‚â§ (2 * (a + b)) * (Real.sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b)) := by
        nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2), Real.sqrt_nonneg (a * b), 
          Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (a^2 + b^2) / 2 by positivity), 
          Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ a * b by positivity), 
          sq_nonneg (Real.sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b)), 
          sq_nonneg (a - b), 
          Real.sqrt_le_sqrt (show 0 ‚â§ a * b by positivity), 
          Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (a * b) by positivity)]
      have pos2 : 2 * (a + b) > 0 := by
        nlinarith
      apply (div_le_iff‚ÇÄ pos2).mpr
      nlinarith [h7]
      all_goals linarith
    linarith [h10]
  ¬∑ -- Second inequality: $\sqrt{\frac{a^2 + b^2}{2}} - \sqrt{a b} \leq \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{4 \sqrt{a b}}$
    have h1 : 0 < a * b := by
      nlinarith
    have h2 : Real.sqrt (a * b) > 0 := by
      positivity
    have pos1 : 4 * Real.sqrt (a * b) > 0 := by
      nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.2 (show 0 < a * b by nlinarith)]
    have h3 : Real.sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b) ‚â§ (a - b) ^ 2 / (4 * Real.sqrt (a * b)) := by
      apply (le_div_iff‚ÇÄ pos1).mpr
      nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2), Real.sqrt_nonneg (a * b), 
          Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (a^2 + b^2) / 2 by positivity), 
          Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ a * b by positivity), 
          sq_nonneg (Real.sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - Real.sqrt (a * b)), 
          sq_nonneg (a - b), 
          Real.sqrt_le_sqrt (show 0 ‚â§ (a * b : ‚Ñù) by positivity), 
          Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (a * b) by positivity)]
    linarith [h3]

soln_description:
Given $a>0, b>0, c>0$, it also holds that $a+b>0, b+c>0, c+a>0$ and

$$
a+b\frac{1}{a+b+c} ; \quad \frac{1}{b+c}>\frac{1}{a+b+c} ; \quad \frac{1}{a+c}>\frac{1}{a+b+c}
$$

Multiplying the last three inequalities by $c$, by $a$ respectively by $b$ and adding these, one obtains

$$
\frac{c}{a+b}+\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{a+c}>\frac{c+a+b}{a+b+c}=1
$$

## Solution by Wolfgang Burmeister:

According to a well-known theorem, the arithmetic mean of $n$ positive numbers is not less than their harmonic mean. Therefore, for the positive numbers $x ; y ; z$:

$$
\frac{x+y+z}{3} \geq \frac{3}{\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}}
$$

Applying this to the case

$$
x=\frac{a+b+c}{a+b} \quad ; \quad y=\frac{a+b+c}{a+c} \quad ; \quad z=\frac{a+b+c}{c+b}
$$

one obtains

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{c}{a+b} & +\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{a}{b+c}=3 \cdot \frac{\frac{a+b+c}{a+b}+\frac{a+b+c}{a+c}+\frac{a+b+c}{c+b}}{3}-3 \\
& \geq 3 \cdot \frac{3}{\frac{a+b}{a+b+c}+\frac{a+c}{a+b+c}+\frac{c+b}{a+b+c}}-3=3 \cdot \frac{3}{2}-3=\frac{3}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the sharper inequality holds:

$$
\frac{c}{a+b}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{a}{b+c} \geq \frac{3}{2}
$$

where equality holds only for $x=y=z$, which is only possible for $a=b=c$.

## Solution by J√∂rg Seel√§nder:

I estimate the inequality

$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b} \geq 1
$$

from below by reducing each fraction on the left side (which is possible according to the assumption $a ; b ; c>0$):

$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b}>\frac{a}{a+b+c}+\frac{b}{b+c+a}+\frac{c}{c+a+b}=1
$$

which completes the proof.

## Solution by Karl B√∂llmann:

The following inequality is certainly correct:

$$
(a+b)(a-b)^{2}+(a+c)(a-c)^{2}+(b+c)(b-c)^{2} \geq 0
$$

where equality holds only for the case $a=b=c$.

Adding the product $3(a+b)(a+c)(b+c)$ to both sides, one obtains after appropriate calculation

$$
2[a(a+b)(a+c)+b(a+b)(b+c)+c(a+c)(b+c)] \geq 3(a+b)(a+c)(b+c)
$$

Dividing both sides of the inequality by $2(a+b)(a+c)(b+c)$ and simplifying the resulting fractions, one gets

$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{a+c}+\frac{c}{a+b} \geq \frac{3}{2}
$$

Thus, an even sharper inequality holds.

## Solution by Manfred Kie√üling:

To show is

$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{a+c}+\frac{c}{a+b}>1
$$

for real $a, b, c>0$. Since the expression is cyclic, we may assume w.l.o.g. $a\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{b+c}+\frac{c}{c+b}=\frac{a+b+c}{b+c}=1+\frac{a}{b+c}>1
$$

## Solution by Eckehard Krau√ü:

If $s=\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}$, then due to $a_{i}>0$:

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{a_{i}}{s-a_{i}}>\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{a_{i}}{s}=\frac{1}{s} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}=\frac{1}{s} \cdot s=1
$$

In our case, $n=3, a_{1}=a, a_{2}=b, a_{3}=c$.
informal_statement:
## Task 27/67

Prove that the inequality

$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{a+c}+\frac{c}{a+b}>1
$$

holds for any positive real $a ; b ; c$!
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 27/67

Prove that the inequality

$$
\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{a+c}+\frac{c}{a+b}>1
$$

holds for any positive real $a ; b ; c$! -/
theorem inequalities_149555 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    a / (b + c) + b / (a + c) + c / (a + b) > 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_149555 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    a / (b + c) + b / (a + c) + c / (a + b) > 1 := by 
  have h1 : 0 < b + c := by linarith
  have h2 : 0 < a + c := by linarith
  have h3 : 0 < a + b := by linarith
  have h4 : a / (b + c) + b / (a + c) + c / (a + b) - 1 > 0 := by
    have denomin_pos : 0 < (b + c) * (a + c) * (a + b) := by positivity
    have numer_pos : a * (a + c) * (a + b) + b * (b + c) * (a + b) + c * (b + c) * (a + c) - (b + c) * (a + c) * (a + b) > 0 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (c - a), 
        sq_nonneg (a + b + c - b - c), sq_nonneg (a + b + c - a - b), sq_nonneg (a + b + c - a - c),
        mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos ha hc, mul_pos hb hc, 
        mul_pos ha (show 0 < a * b by nlinarith), mul_pos ha (show 0 < a * c by nlinarith), 
        mul_pos hb (show 0 < b * c by nlinarith)]
    have h5 : a / (b + c) + b / (a + c) + c / (a + b) - 1 =
        (a * (a + c) * (a + b) + b * (b + c) * (a + b) + c * (b + c) * (a + c) - (b + c) * (a + c) * (a + b)) / ((b + c) * (a + c) * (a + b)) := by
      field_simp [h1, h2, h3]
      ring
    rw [h5]
    apply div_pos
    ¬∑ linarith
    ¬∑ positivity
  linarith [h4]

informal_statement: Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers for which $ab + ac + bc \ge  a + b + c$. Prove that $a + b + c \ge  3$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers for which $ab + ac + bc \ge  a + b + c$. Prove that $a + b + c \ge  3$. -/
theorem inequalities_72531 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b + a * c + b * c ‚â• a + b + c) : 3 ‚â§ a + b + c := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_72531 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b + a * c + b * c ‚â• a + b + c) : 3 ‚â§ a + b + c := by
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (c - a),
    mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos hb hc, mul_pos ha hc]

soln_description:
(4) (1) If there exists $a_{l}=0\left(l \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$, then from $a_{n-1}=2 a_{n-1} a_{n}+3 a_{n}$ we know, $a_{l-1}=$ 0. Proceeding in this manner, $a_{l-2}=0, a_{l-3}=0, \cdots, a_{1}=0$, which contradicts $a_{1}=\frac{1}{2}$. Therefore, $a_{n} \neq 0\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$.
Thus, from $a_{n}=2 a_{n} a_{n+1}+3 a_{n+1}$, we get $\frac{1}{a_{n+1}}-\frac{3}{a_{n}}=2$, i.e.,
$$
\frac{1}{a_{n+1}}+1=3\left(\frac{1}{a_{n}}+1\right) \text {. }
$$

Therefore, $\left\{\frac{1}{a_{n}}+1\right\}$ is a geometric sequence with the first term 3 and common ratio 3.
Thus, $\frac{1}{a_{n}}+1=3^{n}$, i.e., $a_{n}=\frac{1}{3^{n}-1}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$.
(2) From (1), we have $b_{n}=1+\frac{1}{a_{n}}=3^{n}$. Therefore, $\log _{3} b_{k}=k(k=1,2, \cdots)$.

Thus, the inequality $\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{n+\log _{3} b_{k}}>\frac{m}{24}$ is equivalent to
$$
\frac{1}{n+1}+\frac{1}{n+2}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n+n}>\frac{m}{24} \text {. }
$$

Let $f(n)=\frac{1}{n+1}+\frac{1}{n+2}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n+n}$, then
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(n+1)-f(n) & =\frac{1}{2 n+1}+\frac{1}{2 n+2}-\frac{1}{n+1} \\
& =\frac{1}{2 n+1}-\frac{1}{2 n+2}>0,
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $f(n)$ is monotonically increasing.
Thus, $f(n)_{\min }=f(2)=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{7}{12}$.
Hence, $\frac{7}{12}>\frac{m}{24}$, i.e., $m<14$.
Therefore, the maximum value of the integer $m$ is 13.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- (4) (30 points) Given the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies $a_{1}=\frac{1}{2}, a_{n}=$ $2 a_{n} a_{n+1}+3 a_{n+1}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$.
(1) Find the general term formula of the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$;
(2) If the sequence $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfies $b_{n}=1+\frac{1}{a_{n}}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$, and for any positive integer $n(n \geqslant 2)$, the inequality $\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{n+\log _{3} b_{k}}>\frac{m}{24}$ always holds, find the maximum value of the integer $m$. -/
theorem algebra_100447 {a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (ha1 : a 1 = 1 / 2)
    (han : ‚àÄ n, a (n + 1) = 2 * a n * a (n + 2) + 3 * a (n + 1) * a (n + 2)) :
    (‚àÄ n, a n = 1 / (n + 1)) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ b : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù, (‚àÄ n, b n = 1 + 1 / a n) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ n ‚â• 2, ‚àë k in Finset.Icc 1 n, 1 / (n + logb 3 (b k)) > m / 24) ‚Üî m ‚â§ 13) := by

soln_description:
```
Divide the denominator into two groups to get
\[
\begin{array}{l}
(3+\sqrt{15})-(\sqrt{6}+\sqrt{10}) \\
=(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{5})(\sqrt{3}-\sqrt{2}) \text {. Answer: } \sqrt{3}+\sqrt{2} .
\end{array}
\]
```
informal_statement: 5. Simplify: $\frac{\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{5}}{3-\sqrt{6}-\sqrt{10}+\sqrt{15}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Simplify: $\frac{\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{5}}{3-\sqrt{6}-\sqrt{10}+\sqrt{15}}$. -/
theorem algebra_321250 : (Real.sqrt 3 + Real.sqrt 5) / (3 - Real.sqrt 6 - Real.sqrt 10 + Real.sqrt 15) = Real.sqrt 3 + Real.sqrt 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_321250 : (Real.sqrt 3 + Real.sqrt 5) / (3 - Real.sqrt 6 - Real.sqrt 10 + Real.sqrt 15) = Real.sqrt 3 + Real.sqrt 2 := by 
  have h1 : Real.sqrt 6 = Real.sqrt 2 * Real.sqrt 3 := by 
    rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
    <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num [Real.mul_self_sqrt, mul_assoc]
  
  have h2 : Real.sqrt 10 = Real.sqrt 2 * Real.sqrt 5 := by 
    rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
    <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num [Real.mul_self_sqrt, mul_assoc]

  have h3 : Real.sqrt 15 = Real.sqrt 3 * Real.sqrt 5 := by 
    rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
    <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num [Real.mul_self_sqrt, mul_assoc]

  have h4 : (3 - Real.sqrt 6 - Real.sqrt 10 + Real.sqrt 15) = (Real.sqrt 3 - Real.sqrt 2) * (Real.sqrt 3 + Real.sqrt 5) := by 
    rw [h1, h2, h3]
    nlinarith [Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (2 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (3 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sqrt_nonneg 2, Real.sqrt_nonneg 3, Real.sqrt_nonneg 5, mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg 2) (Real.sqrt_nonneg 3), mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg 2) (Real.sqrt_nonneg 5), mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg 3) (Real.sqrt_nonneg 5)]
  
  have h5 : Real.sqrt 3 + Real.sqrt 5 ‚â† 0 := by 
    positivity
  
  have h6 : Real.sqrt 3 - Real.sqrt 2 ‚â† 0 := by 
    -- Show sqrt(3) - sqrt(2) ‚â† 0
    by_contra h
    have h7 : Real.sqrt 3 = Real.sqrt 2 := by linarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg 3, Real.sqrt_nonneg 2]
    have h8 : (Real.sqrt 3) ^ 2 = (Real.sqrt 2) ^ 2 := by 
      rw [h7]
    -- norm_num at h8
    -- leads to 3 = 2
    nlinarith [Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (3 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (2 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sqrt_nonneg 3, Real.sqrt_nonneg 2]

  rw [h4]
  field_simp [show Real.sqrt 3 - Real.sqrt 2 ‚â† 0 by exact h6, show Real.sqrt 3 + Real.sqrt 5 ‚â† 0 by exact h5]
  <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num
  <;> ring
  <;> norm_num
  all_goals nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg 3, Real.sqrt_nonneg 2, Real.sqrt_nonneg 5, Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (3 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (2 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num)]

soln_description:
[Proof] By induction. When $n=2$, take $S=-a_{1}+a_{2}$. Since $0 \leqslant a_{1} \leqslant a_{2}$ $\leqslant 2 a_{1}$, then $0 \leqslant S \leqslant a_{1}$.
Assume the proposition holds for $n=k$, consider the case for $n=k+1$.
Take any $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{k}, a_{k+1}$ satisfying the given conditions. For $a_{2}, \cdots, a_{k}, a_{k+1}$, use the induction hypothesis to get $S^{\prime}=\varepsilon_{2} a_{2}+\varepsilon_{3} a_{3}+\cdots+\varepsilon_{k+1} a_{k+1}$, where $\varepsilon_{m} \in\{-1,1\}, m=$ $2,3, \cdots, k+1$, satisfying $0 \leqslant S^{\prime} \leqslant a_{2}$. Let
$$
S=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}-S^{\prime}, S^{\prime} \leqslant a_{1} ; \\
-a_{1}+S^{\prime}, S^{\prime}>a_{1} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

From $0 \leqslant a_{1} \leqslant a_{2} \leqslant 2 a_{1}$, we have
$$
0 \leqslant S \leqslant a_{1} .
$$

Thus, the proposition holds for $n=k+1$ as well.
informal_statement:
9„Éª199 Let real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ satisfy $n \geqslant 2$ and
$$
0 \leqslant a_{1} \leqslant a_{2} \leqslant 2 a_{1}, a_{2} \leqslant a_{3} \leqslant 2 a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n-1} \leqslant a_{n} \leqslant 2 a_{n-1} \text {. }
$$

Prove: In $S= \pm a_{1} \pm a_{2} \pm \cdots \pm a_{n}$, the signs can be chosen appropriately such that
$$
0 \leqslant S \leqslant a_{1} .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- 9„Éª199 Let real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ satisfy $n \geqslant 2$ and
$$
0 \leqslant a_{1} \leqslant a_{2} \leqslant 2 a_{1}, a_{2} \leqslant a_{3} \leqslant 2 a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n-1} \leqslant a_{n} \leqslant 2 a_{n-1} \text {. }
$$

Prove: In $S= \pm a_{1} \pm a_{2} \pm \cdots \pm a_{n}$, the signs can be chosen appropriately such that
$$
0 \leqslant S \leqslant a_{1} .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_166930 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n ‚â• 2)
    (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (ha : ‚àÄ i ‚àà Icc 1 n, 0 ‚â§ a i)
    (hinc : ‚àÄ i ‚àà Icc 1 (n - 1), a i ‚â§ a (i + 1)) (hbound : ‚àÄ i ‚àà Icc 1 (n - 1), a (i + 1) ‚â§ 2 * a i) :
    ‚àÉ s : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§, (‚àÄ i ‚àà Icc 1 n, s i = 1 ‚à® s i = -1) ‚àß
      0 ‚â§ ‚àë i ‚àà Icc 1 n, s i * a i ‚àß ‚àë i ‚àà Icc 1 n, s i * a i ‚â§ a 1 := by

soln_description:
1. We start with the given expression:
   \[
   \frac{b^n - 1}{b - 1} = b^{n-1} + b^{n-2} + \ldots + b + 1 = k^2
   \]
   where \( n, k \in \mathbb{N} \) and \( n > 1 \).

2. We can rewrite the equation as:
   \[
   k^2 - 1 = b \sum_{i=0}^{n-2} b^i
   \]
   This follows from the fact that:
   \[
   k^2 = b^{n-1} + b^{n-2} + \ldots + b + 1
   \]
   and subtracting 1 from both sides:
   \[
   k^2 - 1 = b^{n-1} + b^{n-2} + \ldots + b
   \]
   which can be factored as:
   \[
   k^2 - 1 = b \left( b^{n-2} + b^{n-3} + \ldots + 1 \right)
   \]

3. Since \( b \) is an even positive integer, we can write \( b = 2m \) for some integer \( m \). This implies \( b \equiv 0 \pmod{2} \).

4. From the left side of the equation \( k^2 - 1 \), we know that \( k \) must be odd because \( k^2 \) is odd if and only if \( k \) is odd. Therefore, we can write \( k = 2t - 1 \) for some integer \( t \).

5. Substituting \( k = 2t - 1 \) into the equation \( k^2 - 1 \), we get:
   \[
   (2t - 1)^2 - 1 = 4t^2 - 4t
   \]
   Thus, the equation becomes:
   \[
   4t(t - 1) = b \sum_{i=0}^{n-2} b^i
   \]

6. Notice that \( 4t(t - 1) \equiv 0 \pmod{8} \) because \( 4t(t - 1) \) is always divisible by 8 for any integer \( t \).

7. Now, consider the sum \( \sum_{i=0}^{n-2} b^i \). Since \( b \) is even, each term \( b^i \) for \( i \geq 1 \) is even, and the sum of an odd number of even numbers plus 1 (the first term) is odd. Therefore:
   \[
   \sum_{i=0}^{n-2} b^i \equiv 1 \pmod{2}
   \]

8. Since \( 4t(t - 1) \equiv 0 \pmod{8} \) and \( \sum_{i=0}^{n-2} b^i \equiv 1 \pmod{2} \), it follows that \( b \) must be divisible by 8 to satisfy the equation:
   \[
   4t(t - 1) = b \sum_{i=0}^{n-2} b^i
   \]

9. Therefore, we conclude that \( b \equiv 0 \pmod{8} \).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Let $ b$ be an even positive integer. Assume that there exist integer $ n > 1$ such that $ \frac {b^{n} \minus{} 1}{b \minus{} 1}$ is perfect square. 
Prove that $ b$ is divisible by 8.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $ b$ be an even positive integer. Assume that there exist integer $ n > 1$ such that $ \frac {b^{n} \minus{} 1}{b \minus{} 1}$ is perfect square. 
Prove that $ b$ is divisible by 8. -/
theorem number_theory_29675 (b : ‚Ñï) (hb : Even b) (h : ‚àÉ n > 1, IsSquare ((b ^ n - 1) / (b - 1))) :
    8 ‚à£ b := by

theorem inequalities_3668 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚àà Icc (-1) 1) :

soln_description:
(1) Substituting $\Delta=s r=\frac{(a+b+c) r}{2}$ into the inequality sequence in Example 6, we can obtain the first four inequality signs. The last inequality sign is derived from
$$
a+b+c \leqslant \sqrt{3} \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}
$$

The condition for equality is obvious.
(2) From (1), since
$$
r \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{3}}{18}(a+b+c)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{18} \cdot \frac{2 \Delta}{r},
$$

we have
$$
r^{2} \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{3}}{9} \Delta, \text { i.e., } 3 \sqrt{3} r^{2} \leqslant \Delta .
$$
(3) From (1) and Example 5, we have
$$
r \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{3}}{18}(a+b+c) \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{3}}{18} \cdot 3 \sqrt{3} R=\frac{R}{2},
$$

thus
$$
R \geqslant 2 r \text {. }
$$

Since the condition for equality in (1) and Example 5 is $a=b=c$, the condition for equality in (2) and (3) is also $a=b=c$.
There are also some generally significant propositions about such inequalities.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- „ÄêExample 7„ÄëIn $\triangle A B C$, prove:
(1)
$$
\begin{aligned}
r & \leqslant \frac{3}{2} \frac{a b c}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}(a+b+c)} \\
& \leqslant \frac{3}{2} \sqrt{3} \frac{a b c}{(a+b+c)^{2}} \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \frac{(a b c)^{2 / 3}}{(a+b+c)} \\
& \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{3}}{18}(a+b+c) \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$
(2) $\Delta \geqslant 3 \sqrt{3} r^{2}$;
(3) $R \geqslant 2 r$.

The equality holds if and only if $a=b=c$. -/
theorem inequalities_167915 (A B C : EuclideanSpace ‚Ñù (Fin 2))
  (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : a = dist B C) (hb : b = dist A C) (hc : c = dist A B)
  (r : ‚Ñù) (hr : r > 0) :
  r ‚â§ (3 / 2) * (a * b * c / (Real.sqrt (a^2 + b^2 + c^2) * (a + b + c))) ‚àß
  (3 / 2) * (a * b * c / (Real.sqrt (a^2 + b^2 + c^2) * (a + b + c))) ‚â§
  (3 / 2) * Real.sqrt 3 * (a * b * c / (a + b + c)^2) ‚àß
  (3 / 2) * Real.sqrt 3 * (a * b * c / (a + b + c)^2) ‚â§
  (Real.sqrt 3 / 2) * (a * b * c) ^ ((2 : ‚Ñù) / 3) / (a + b + c) ‚àß
  (Real.sqrt 3 / 2) * (a * b * c) ^ ((2 : ‚Ñù) / 3) / (a + b + c) ‚â§
  (Real.sqrt (a^2 + b^2 + c^2) / 6) ‚àß
  (3 / 2) * (a * b * c / (Real.sqrt (a^2 + b^2 + c^2) * (a + b + c))) ‚â•
  3 * Real.sqrt 3 * r^2 ‚àß
  (3 / 2) * (a * b * c / (Real.sqrt (a^2 + b^2 + c^2) * (a + b + c))) ‚â•
  2 * r := by

\text { 5. } \sqrt{3}-2 \text {. } \\
\text { From } f(x+2)[1-f(x)]=1+f(x) \text {, we get } f(x+2) \\
=\frac{1+f(x)}{1-f(x)} \text {. } \\
\therefore \quad f(x+4)=\frac{1+f(x+2)}{1-f(x+2)}=\frac{1+\frac{1+f(x)}{1-f(x)}}{1-\frac{1+f(x)}{1-f(x)}} \\
=-\frac{1}{f(x)} \text {. } \\
\therefore \quad f(x+8)=-\frac{1}{f(x+4)}=f(x) \text {. } \\
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $f(x)$ is a periodic function with a period of 8.

& =f(1+4)=-\frac{1}{f(1)} \\
& =-\frac{1}{2+\sqrt{3}}=\sqrt{3}-2 .
\end{aligned}
$$

$\frac{3 a+b+1}{a+2 b-2}=\frac{3\left(a+\frac{4}{5}\right)+\left(b-\frac{7}{5}\right)}{\left(a+\frac{4}{5}\right)+2\left(b-\frac{7}{5}\right)}$, let $u=\frac{b-\frac{7}{5}}{a+\frac{4}{5}} \Rightarrow \frac{3 a+b+1}{a+2 b-2}=\frac{3+u}{1+2 u}=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\frac{5}{2}}{1+2 u}$.
And $0 \leqslant f(x) \leqslant 1 \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}-1 \leqslant a+b \leqslant 0, \\ -1 \leqslant b-a \leqslant 0 .\end{array}\right.$

A. $\left[-\frac{1}{2}, 0\right]$

formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Given $a, b \in \mathbf{R}$, the function $f(x)=a x-b$. If for any $x \in[-1,1]$, we have $0 \leqslant f(x) \leqslant 1$, then the range of $\frac{3 a+b+1}{a+2 b-2}$ is
A. $\left[-\frac{1}{2}, 0\right]$
B. $\left[-\frac{4}{5}, 0\right]$
C. $\left[-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{2}{7}\right]$
D. $\left[-\frac{4}{5}, \frac{2}{7}\right]$ -/
theorem algebra_281570 (a b : ‚Ñù) (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : ‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Icc (-1) 1, 0 ‚â§ f x ‚àß f x ‚â§ 1)
    (h : f = fun x => a * x - b) :
    -4 / 5 ‚â§ (3 * a + b + 1) / (a + 2 * b - 2) ‚àß
    (3 * a + b + 1) / (a + 2 * b - 2) ‚â§ 2 / 7 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_281570 (a b : ‚Ñù) (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : ‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Icc (-1) 1, 0 ‚â§ f x ‚àß f x ‚â§ 1)
    (h : f = fun x => a * x - b) :
    -4 / 5 ‚â§ (3 * a + b + 1) / (a + 2 * b - 2) ‚àß
    (3 * a + b + 1) / (a + 2 * b - 2) ‚â§ 2 / 7 := by 
  have h1 := hf (-1) (Set.left_mem_Icc.mpr (by norm_num))
  have h2 := hf 1 (Set.right_mem_Icc.mpr (by norm_num))
  have h3 := hf 0 (by norm_num [Set.mem_Icc])
  simp [h] at h1 h2 h3 
  have h4 : a + b ‚â§ 0 := by linarith
  have h5 : a + b ‚â• -1 := by linarith
  have h6 : b ‚â§ 0 := by linarith
  have h7 : b ‚â• -1 := by linarith
  have h8 : a - b ‚â• 0 := by linarith
  have h9 : a - b ‚â§ 1 := by linarith 
  have h10 : a + 2 * b - 2 < 0 := by nlinarith 
  have h11 : -19 * a - 13 * b + 3 ‚â• 0 := by 
    nlinarith
  have h12 : 19 * a + 3 * b + 11 ‚â• 0 := by 
    nlinarith 
  constructor 
  ¬∑ -- Proving that (3a + b +1)/(a + 2b - 2) ‚â• -4/5 
    apply (le_div_iff_of_neg' h10).mpr 
    nlinarith
  ¬∑ -- Proving that (3a + b +1)/(a + 2b - 2) ‚â§ 2/7
    apply (div_le_iff_of_neg' h10).mpr 
    nlinarith

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=2 \frac{(\cos x)^{\prime} \cdot \sin ^{4} x-\cos x\left(\sin ^{4} x\right)^{\prime}}{\sin ^{8} x}+3 \frac{(\cos x)^{\prime} \cdot \sin ^{2} x-\cos x\left(\sin ^{2} x\right)^{\prime}}{\sin ^{4} x}= \\
& =2 \frac{-\sin ^{5} x-4 \sin ^{3} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{8} x}+3 \frac{-\sin ^{3} x-2 \sin x \cdot \cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{4} x}=2 \frac{-\sin ^{2} x-4 \cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{5} x}+3 \frac{-\sin ^{2} x-2 \cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{3} x}= \\
& =\frac{-2 \sin ^{2} x-8\left(1-\sin ^{2} x\right)}{\sin ^{5} x}+\frac{-3 \sin ^{2} x-6\left(1-\sin ^{2} x\right)}{\sin ^{3} x}= \\
& =\frac{-2 \sin ^{2} x-8+8 \sin ^{2} x}{\sin ^{5} x}+\frac{-3 \sin ^{2} x-6+6 \sin ^{2} x}{\sin ^{3} x}=\frac{6 \sin ^{2} x-8}{\sin ^{5} x}+\frac{3 \sin ^{2} x-6}{\sin ^{3} x}=\frac{6 \sin ^{2} x-8+3 \sin ^{4} x-6 \sin ^{2} x}{\sin ^{5} x}= \\
& =\frac{3}{\sin x}-\frac{8}{\sin ^{5} x}=3 \operatorname{cosec} x-8 \operatorname{cosec}^{5} x
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Kuznetsov Differentiation 15-27

soln_description:
Solution: Notice that
$$
\begin{array}{l}
n+2 \\
=\frac{2 a}{y \cos ^{n} x}+n \cos ^{2} x+\frac{2 b}{y \sin ^{n} x}+n \sin ^{2} x \\
\geqslant(n+2) \sqrt[n+2]{\left(\frac{a}{y \cos ^{n} x}\right)^{2}\left(\cos ^{2} x\right)^{n}}+ \\
(n+2) \sqrt[n+2]{\left(\frac{b}{y \sin ^{n} x}\right)^{2}\left(\sin ^{2} x\right)^{n}} \\
=(n+2) \frac{\sqrt[n+2]{a^{2}}+\sqrt[n+2]{b^{2}}}{\sqrt[n+2]{y^{2}}} . \\
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $y \geqslant\left(a^{\frac{2}{n+2}}+b^{\frac{2}{n+2}}\right)^{\frac{n+2}{2}}$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\Leftrightarrow \frac{a}{y \cos ^{n} x}=\cos ^{2} x, \text { and } \frac{b}{y \sin ^{n} x}=\sin ^{2} x \\
\Leftrightarrow \tan ^{n+2} x=\frac{b}{a}
\end{array}
$$
$\Leftrightarrow$ when $x=\arctan \sqrt[n+2]{\frac{b}{a}}$,
$$
y_{\text {min }}=\left(a^{\frac{2}{n+2}}+b^{\frac{2}{n+2}}\right)^{\frac{n+2}{2}} \text {. }
$$

soln_description:
## Solution.

Two real numbers have the same absolute value if and only if they are either equal or opposite numbers. Therefore, it holds that

$$
|x-2023|+2022 x=2022-|2023-x| \text { or }|x-2023|+2022 x=-2022+|2023-x| \text {. }
$$

Note that $|x-2023|=|2023-x|$. In the first case, we get the equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
2|x-2023| & =2022-2022 x, \text { i.e., } \\
|x-2023| & =1011-1011 x
\end{aligned}
$$

This equation will have a solution if $1011-1011 x \geqslant 0$, i.e., if $x \leqslant 1$. Then we have either

$$
\begin{aligned}
x-2023 & =1011-1011 x \\
1012 x & =3034 \\
x & =\frac{3034}{1012}>1,
\end{aligned}
$$

which is not a solution, or

$$
\begin{aligned}
x-2023 & =-1011+1011 x \\
-1010 x & =1012 \\
x & =-\frac{1012}{1010}=-\frac{506}{505}
\end{aligned}
$$

which is a solution.

In the second case, from $|x-2023|+2022 x=-2022+|2023-x|$ we get $2022 x=-2022$, so $x=-1$.

All solutions to the given equation are $x=-\frac{506}{505} \text{ and } x=-1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task B-1.2.

Solve the equation

$$
|| x-2023|+2022 x|=|2022-| 2023-x|| .
$$ -/
theorem algebra_233764 (x : ‚Ñù) : abs (abs (x - 2023) + 2022 * x) = abs (2022 - abs (2023 - x)) ‚Üî
    x = -506 / 505 - 1 := by

soln_description:
Analysis: The key to solving this problem successfully is to organize and process it using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality.

Proof: For \( n \geqslant 2 \), let \( \varphi(1), \varphi(2), \cdots, \varphi(n) \) be a permutation of \( 1, 2, \cdots, n \) such that:
\[ 0 \leqslant a_{\varphi(1)} < a_{\varphi(2)} < \cdots < a_{\varphi(n)} \leqslant c \]

Thus, \( c \geqslant a_{\varphi(n)} - a_{\varphi(1)} = \left(a_{\varphi(n)} - a_{\varphi(n-1)}\right) + \left(a_{\varphi(n-1)} - a_{\varphi(n-2)}\right) + \cdots + \left(a_{\varphi(2)} - a_{\varphi(1)}\right) \)
\[ \begin{array}{l}
\geqslant \frac{1}{\varphi(n) + \varphi(n-1)} + \frac{1}{\varphi(n-1) + \varphi(n-2)} + \cdots + \frac{1}{\varphi(2) + \varphi(1)} \\
\geqslant \frac{(n-1)^2}{2 \sum_{i=1}^{n} \varphi(i) - \varphi(1) - \varphi(n)} \text{ (Cauchy-Schwarz inequality) }
\end{array} \]

Therefore, \( c \geqslant \frac{(n-1)^2}{n(n-1) - \varphi(1) - \varphi(n)} \geqslant \frac{(n-1)^2}{n^2 + n - 1} \geqslant \frac{n-1}{n+3} = 1 - \frac{4}{n+3} \) for all \( n \geqslant 2 \). Hence, it must be that \( c \geqslant 1 \).
informal_statement:
For example, let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots$ be an infinite sequence of real numbers. For all positive integers $i$, there exists a real number $c$ such that $0 \leqslant$ $a_{i} \leqslant c$ and $\left|a_{i}-a_{j}\right| \geqslant \frac{1}{i+j}$ for all positive integers $i, j(i \neq j)$. Prove: $c \geqslant 1$.
(43rd IMO Shortlist Problem)

Prove: $c \geqslant 1$.

[Trigonometric Identities (Trigonometry).]  [Sines and Cosines of Angles in a Triangle]

Prove the equalities:

a) $\sin 15^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{6}-\sqrt{2}}{4}, \quad \cos 15^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{6}+\sqrt{2}}{4}$

b) $\sin 18^{\circ}=\frac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{4}, \quad \cos 18^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{10+2 \sqrt{5}}}{4}$.

b) $\sin 18^{\circ}=\frac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{4}, \quad \cos 18^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{10+2 \sqrt{5}}}{4}$. -/
theorem algebra_261861 :
  sin (œÄ / 12) = (sqrt 6 - sqrt 2) / 4 ‚àß
  cos (œÄ / 12) = (sqrt 6 + sqrt 2) / 4 ‚àß
  sin (œÄ / 10) = (-1 + sqrt 5) / 4 ‚àß
  cos (œÄ / 10) = sqrt (10 + 2 * sqrt 5) / 4 := by

soln_description:
„ÄêSolution„ÄëSolution: Let the original side length of the square be $x \mathrm{~cm}$, according to the problem, we have:
$$
\begin{aligned}
1.2 x(x-2)-x^{2} & =0, \\
1.2 x-2.4-x & =0, \\
1.2 x-x & =2.4, \\
0.2 x & =2.4, \\
x & =12 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: The side length of the square is $12 \mathrm{~cm}$.
Therefore, the answer is: 12 .
informal_statement: 6. (3 points) Reduce one side of a square by $2 \mathrm{~cm}$ and increase the other side by $20 \%$, resulting in a rectangle with the same area as the original square. What is the side length of the square? $\qquad$ $\mathrm{cm}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. (3 points) Reduce one side of a square by $2 \mathrm{~cm}$ and increase the other side by $20 \%$, resulting in a rectangle with the same area as the original square. What is the side length of the square? $\qquad$ $\mathrm{cm}$. -/
theorem algebra_248599 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (h : (x - 2) * (x * 1.2) = x * x) :
    x = 12 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_248599 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (h : (x - 2) * (x * 1.2) = x * x) :
    x = 12 := by 
  ring_nf at h
  have h2 : x * (x - 12) = 0 := by 
    linarith
  cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h2) with h3 h4
  ¬∑ -- Case x = 0, contradicts x > 0
    linarith
  ¬∑ -- Case x - 12 = 0, thus x = 12
    linarith

soln_description: Prove that if $A_{1}=x q-y p, A_{2}=y p-x q$, then $A_{1} \geqslant 0, A_{1}+A_{2}=0$. Let $B_{1}=x p$, $B_{2}=y q$, then $B_{1} \leqslant B_{2}$. By Theorem (1), $T_{2}=A_{1} B_{1}+A_{2} B_{2} \leqslant 0$, i.e., $x p(x q-y p)+y q(y p-x q) \leqslant 0$. Dividing both sides of the above inequality by $x y p q$ yields the desired result.
informal_statement: Example 1. Let $0
formal_statement: import Mathlib /- Example 1. Let $0
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_308233 (p q x y : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : 0 < p) (h‚ÇÅ : p ‚â§ x) (h‚ÇÇ : x ‚â§ y) (h‚ÇÉ : y ‚â§ q) :
    x / y + y / x ‚â§ p / q + q / p := by 
  have h4 : 0 < y := by linarith
  have h5 : 0 < x := by linarith
  have h6 : 0 < q := by linarith
  have h7 : 0 < x * y := by positivity
  have h8 : 0 < p * q := by positivity
  have h9 : 0 < x * y * p * q := by positivity
  have h10 : x / y + y / x - (p / q + q / p) ‚â§ 0 := by
    have h11 : x / y + y / x - (p / q + q / p) =
        ( (x^2 + y^2) * (p * q) - (p^2 + q^2) * (x * y) ) / (x * y * p * q) := by
      field_simp
      ring
    have h12 : (x^2 + y^2) * (p * q) - (p^2 + q^2) * (x * y) ‚â§ 0 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x * q - y * p), sq_nonneg (x * p - y * q), 
          mul_nonneg (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ x - p by linarith) (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ y - x by linarith),
          mul_nonneg (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ y - x by linarith) (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ q - y by linarith),
          mul_pos h‚ÇÄ h6, 
          sq_nonneg (x - y), 
          sq_nonneg (p - q)]
    have h13 : ( (x^2 + y^2) * (p * q) - (p^2 + q^2) * (x * y) ) / (x * y * p * q) ‚â§ (0 : ‚Ñù) := by
      apply div_nonpos_of_nonpos_of_nonneg h12 (by positivity)
    linarith [h11, h13]
  linarith

soln_description:
Denote $P = \left( x , y \right)$.
Because $\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{a^2-16} = 1$, $P$  is on an ellipse whose center is $\left( 0 , 0 \right)$ and foci are $\left( - 4 , 0 \right)$ and $\left( 4 , 0 \right)$.
Hence, the sum of distance from $P$ to $\left( - 4 , 0 \right)$ and $\left( 4 , 0 \right)$ is equal to twice the major axis of this ellipse, $2a$.
Because $\frac{(x-20)^2}{b^2-1}+\frac{(y-11)^2}{b^2} = 1$, $P$  is on an ellipse whose center is $\left( 20 , 11 \right)$ and foci are $\left( 20 , 10 \right)$ and $\left( 20 , 12 \right)$.
Hence, the sum of distance from $P$ to $\left( 20 , 10 \right)$ and $\left( 20 , 12 \right)$ is equal to twice the major axis of this ellipse, $2b$.
Therefore, $2a + 2b$ is the sum of the distance from $P$ to four foci of these two ellipses.
To make this minimized, $P$ is the intersection point of the line that passes through $\left( - 4 , 0 \right)$ and $\left( 20 , 10 \right)$, and the line that passes through $\left( 4 , 0 \right)$ and $\left( 20 , 12 \right)$.
The distance between $\left( - 4 , 0 \right)$ and $\left( 20 , 10 \right)$ is $\sqrt{\left( 20 + 4 \right)^2 + \left( 10 - 0 \right)^2} = 26$.
The distance between $\left( 4 , 0 \right)$ and $\left( 20 , 12 \right)$ is $\sqrt{\left( 20 - 4 \right)^2 + \left( 12 - 0 \right)^2} = 20$.
Hence, $2 a + 2 b = 26 + 20 = 46$.
Therefore, $a + b = \boxed{\textbf{(023) }}.$
~Steven Chen (www.professorchenedu.com)
informal_statement: Let $a, b, x,$ and $y$ be real numbers with $a>4$ and $b>1$ such that\[\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{a^2-16}=\frac{(x-20)^2}{b^2-1}+\frac{(y-11)^2}{b^2}=1.\]Find the least possible value of $a+b.$

import Mathlib

/- Let $a, b, x,$ and $y$ be real numbers with $a>4$ and $b>1$ such that\[\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{a^2-16}=\frac{(x-20)^2}{b^2-1}+\frac{(y-11)^2}{b^2}=1.\]Find the least possible value of $a+b.$ -/
theorem algebra_98626 :
    IsLeast {z : ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ a b x y : ‚Ñù, a > 4 ‚àß b > 1 ‚àß z = a + b ‚àß
      x ^ 2 / a ^ 2 + y ^ 2 / (a ^ 2 - 16) = 1 ‚àß
      (x - 20) ^ 2 / (b ^ 2 - 1) + (y - 11) ^ 2 / (b ^ 2) = 1} 23 := by

soln_description:
Solve: From equation (1), we get
$$
a!>5(f!) \geqslant 5 \Rightarrow a \geqslant 3 \text {. }
$$

From $a>b \Rightarrow a!\geqslant a(b!)$.
Combining $a!=b!+c!+d!+e!+f!\leqslant 5 b!$, we get $a \leqslant 5$.
When $a=3$, it is not difficult to determine the positive integer tuple as $(3,2,1,1,1,1)$.
When $a=4$,
(1) If $b=3$, then $c!+d!+e!+f!=18$.

From $4(2!)$ $<18$, we get $c=3$.
Thus, $d!+e!+f!=12$.
From $3(2!)<12$, we get $d=3$.
Therefore, $e!+f!=6$, which clearly has no solution.
(2) If $b \leqslant 2$, from
$$
b!+c!+d!+e!+f!\leqslant 5(2!),
$$

we know there is no solution in this case.
When $a=5$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
120=b!+c!+d!+e!+f! \\
\leqslant 5(b!) \leqslant 5(4!)=120 .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $b=c=d=e=f=4$.
Therefore, the positive integer tuple is $(5,4,4,4,4,4)$.
In summary, the positive integer tuples that satisfy the conditions are
$$
(3,2,1,1,1,1),(5,4,4,4,4,4) \text {. }
$$
informal_statement:
Example 6 For a positive integer $n$, denote $n!=1 \times 2 \times \cdots \times n$. Find all positive integer tuples $(a, b, c, d, e, f)$, such that
$$
a!=b!+c!+d!+e!+f!,
$$

and $a>b \geqslant c \geqslant d \geqslant e \geqslant f .{ }^{[1]}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6 For a positive integer $n$, denote $n!=1 \times 2 \times \cdots \times n$. Find all positive integer tuples $(a, b, c, d, e, f)$, such that
$$
a!=b!+c!+d!+e!+f!,
$$

and $a>b \geqslant c \geqslant d \geqslant e \geqslant f .{ }^{[1]}$ -/
theorem number_theory_319464 (a b c d e f : ‚Ñï) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (hd : 0 < d) (he : 0 < e) (hf : 0 < f) (h : Nat.factorial a = Nat.factorial b + Nat.factorial c +
    Nat.factorial d + Nat.factorial e + Nat.factorial f) (hord : a > b ‚àß b ‚â• c ‚àß c ‚â• d ‚àß d ‚â• e ‚àß e ‚â• f) :
    (a, b, c, d, e, f) = (3, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1) ‚à® (a, b, c, d, e, f) = (5, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4) := by

import Mathlib

/- The number of correct propositions below is (   ).

(1) The graph of the function $y=4\sin 2x$ is shifted to the left by $\frac{\pi }{3}$ units to obtain the graph of the function $y=4\sin \left( 2x+\frac{\pi }{3} \right)$;

(2) The graph of the function $y=4\cos (2x+\varphi )$ is symmetric about the point $\left( \frac{\pi }{6},0 \right)$ if and only if $\varphi =k\pi +\frac{\pi }{6}(k\in \mathbb{Z})$;

(3) The period of the function $y=\frac{4\tan x}{1-{{\tan }^{2}}x}$ is $\frac{\pi }{2}$;

(4) Simplifying $\sqrt{1+\sin 2}-\sqrt{1-\sin 2}$ equals $2\sin 1$.

A: $3$

B: $2$

C: $1$

D: $0$ -/
theorem algebra_9342 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : f = fun x => 4 * Real.sin (2 * x + Real.pi / 3)) :
    ‚àÄ x, f x = 4 * Real.sin (2 * (x + Real.pi / 3) + Real.pi / 3) := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let $[x]$ be the greatest integer not exceeding $x$, and $\{x\}$ be the smallest integer not less than $x$.
Obviously, $\quad[x] \leqslant x<[x]+1$,

and $\quad\{x\}-1<x \leqslant\{x\}$,
Adding the above two inequalities, we get $[x]+\{x\}-1<2 x<[x]+\{x\}+1$,
Given that $[x]+\{x\}=5$, then
$$
4<2 x<6 \text {, or } 2<x<3 \text {. }
$$

Therefore, the answer is $(E)$.
informal_statement:
$33 \cdot 32$ is less than or equal to $x$'s maximum integer and the minimum integer greater than or equal to $x$ sum to 5, then the solution set of $x$ is
(A) $\{5 / 2\}$.
(B) $\{x \mid 2 \leqslant x \leqslant 3\}$.
(C) $\{x \mid 2 \leqslant x<3\}$.
(D) $\{x \mid 2<x \leqslant 3\}$.
(E) $\{x \mid 2<x<3\}$.
(37th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1986)

soln_description:
„ÄêSolution„ÄëSolution: If Party A's speed decreases to $80 \%$ of the original, and arrives at location $A$ simultaneously with Party C, then the speed ratio of Party A to Party C is: $5: 4$. Therefore, if Party A walks 900 meters from $C$ to $D$, then Party C walks from $B$ to $D$:
$$
900 \times \frac{4}{5}=720 \text{ meters }
$$

Party A walks two (full distance - 720 meters) back to $A$, while Party B walks one (full distance - 720 meters) in the same time. Party A walks the second (full distance - 720 meters) at $80 \%$ of the original speed, which is equivalent to walking $\frac{9}{4}$ (full distance - 720 meters) at the original speed. Therefore, the speed ratio of Party A to Party B is: $9: 4$. When Party A and Party B meet, Party B has walked from $B$ to $C$:
$$
900+720=1620 \text{ meters }
$$

Thus, the full distance is:
$$
1620 \times \frac{4+9}{4}=5265 \text{ meters }
$$

Answer: The distance between $A$ and $B$ is 5265 meters.
The answer is: 5265.
informal_statement: 12. (12 points) Person A and Person B start from points A and B respectively at the same time, moving towards each other at a constant speed. When A and B meet at point C, Person C starts from B, moving at a constant speed towards A. When A and C meet at point D, A immediately turns around and reduces their speed to 80% of the original speed. When A and C arrive at A at the same time, B is still 720 meters away from A. If the distance between C and D is 900 meters, then the distance between A and B is $\qquad$ meters.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 12. (12 points) Person A and Person B start from points A and B respectively at the same time, moving towards each other at a constant speed. When A and B meet at point C, Person C starts from B, moving at a constant speed towards A. When A and C meet at point D, A immediately turns around and reduces their speed to 80% of the original speed. When A and C arrive at A at the same time, B is still 720 meters away from A. If the distance between C and D is 900 meters, then the distance between A and B is $\qquad$ meters. -/
theorem algebra_269245 (a b c d : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d) (h1 : a * b = c * d) (h2 : a * 0.8 = b * 720 / d)
    (h3 : c * d = 900) :
    a * b = 5265 := by

soln_description:
Solution.

We have:

$\left(\sin ^{2} x+2 \sin x \cos x+\cos ^{2} x\right)^{2}+\left(\sin ^{2} x-2 \sin x \cos x+\cos ^{2} x\right)^{2}=$

$=3-\sin 4 x \Leftrightarrow(1+\sin 2 x)^{2}+(1-\sin 2 x)^{2}=3-\sin 4 x \Leftrightarrow$

$\Leftrightarrow 1+2 \sin 2 x+\sin ^{2} 2 x+1-2 \sin 2 x+\sin ^{2} 2 x=3-\sin 4 x \Leftrightarrow$

$\Leftrightarrow 2 \sin ^{2} 2 x-1+\sin 4 x=0 \Leftrightarrow-\cos 4 x+\sin 4 x=0 \Leftrightarrow \operatorname{tg} 4 x=1$,

$4 x=\frac{\pi}{4}+\pi k, x=\frac{\pi}{16}+\frac{\pi k}{4}=\frac{\pi}{16}(4 k+1), k \in Z$.

Answer: $x=\frac{\pi}{16}(4 k+1), k \in Z$.

soln_description:
## Solution.

Domain of definition: $m \geq 3$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\sqrt{\sqrt{m}-\sqrt{\frac{m^{2}-9}{m}}}+\sqrt{\sqrt{m}+\sqrt{\frac{m^{2}-9}{m}}}\right)^{2} \cdot \sqrt[4]{\frac{m^{2}}{4}}= \\
& =\left(\sqrt{\sqrt{m}-\sqrt{\frac{m^{2}-9}{m}}}+2 \sqrt{\left(\sqrt{m}-\sqrt{\frac{m^{2}-9}{m}}\right)}\left(\sqrt{m}+\sqrt{\frac{m^{2}-9}{m}}\right)+\sqrt{m}+\sqrt{\frac{m^{2}-9}{m}}\right) \times \\
& \times \sqrt{\frac{m}{2}}=\left(2 \sqrt{m}+2 \sqrt{m-\frac{m^{2}-9}{m}}\right) \cdot \sqrt{\frac{m}{2}}=\left(2 \sqrt{m}+\frac{6}{\sqrt{m}}\right) \cdot \frac{\sqrt{m}}{\sqrt{2}}= \\
& =m \sqrt{2}+\frac{6}{\sqrt{2}}=\sqrt{2}(m+3) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: $\sqrt{2}(m+3)$.
informal_statement: 2.079. $\left(\sqrt{\sqrt{m}-\sqrt{\frac{m^{2}-9}{m}}}+\sqrt{\sqrt{m}+\sqrt{\frac{m^{2}-9}{m}}}\right)^{2} \cdot \sqrt[4]{\frac{m^{2}}{4}}$.

theorem algebra_184658 (m : ‚Ñù) (hm : m ‚â† 0) :
    (Real.sqrt (Real.sqrt m - Real.sqrt ((m^2 - 9)/m)) +
     Real.sqrt (Real.sqrt m + Real.sqrt ((m^2 - 9)/m)))^2 *
    ((m^2)/4)^(1/4) = Real.sqrt 2 * (3 + Real.sqrt 2) := by

soln_description:
1. **Given Equation:**
   \[
   f(-x) + \int_0^x t f(x-t) \, dt = x, \quad \forall x \in \mathbb{R}
   \]

2. **Rewriting the Integral:**
   \[
   f(-x) = x - \int_0^x t f(x-t) \, dt \quad \text{(1)}
   \]

3. **Changing the Variable in the Integral:**
   Let \( u = x - t \). Then \( du = -dt \) and when \( t = 0 \), \( u = x \), and when \( t = x \), \( u = 0 \). Thus,
   \[
   \int_0^x t f(x-t) \, dt = \int_x^0 (x-u) f(u) \, (-du) = \int_0^x (x-u) f(u) \, du
   \]

4. **Simplifying the Integral:**
   \[
   \int_0^x (x-u) f(u) \, du = x \int_0^x f(u) \, du - \int_0^x u f(u) \, du
   \]

5. **Substituting Back into the Equation:**
   \[
   f(-x) = x - \left( x \int_0^x f(u) \, du - \int_0^x u f(u) \, du \right)
   \]
   \[
   f(-x) = x - x \int_0^x f(u) \, du + \int_0^x u f(u) \, du
   \]

6. **Differentiating Both Sides with Respect to \( x \):**
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} f(-x) = -f'(-x)
   \]
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} \left( x - x \int_0^x f(u) \, du + \int_0^x u f(u) \, du \right)
   \]
   Using the Leibniz rule for differentiation under the integral sign:
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} \left( x \int_0^x f(u) \, du \right) = \int_0^x f(u) \, du + x f(x)
   \]
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} \left( \int_0^x u f(u) \, du \right) = x f(x)
   \]
   Therefore,
   \[
   -f'(-x) = 1 - \int_0^x f(u) \, du \quad \text{(2)}
   \]

7. **Differentiating Equation (2) Again:**
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} \left( -f'(-x) \right) = -f''(-x)
   \]
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} \left( 1 - \int_0^x f(u) \, du \right) = -f(x)
   \]
   Thus,
   \[
   f''(-x) = -f(x) \quad \text{(3)}
   \]

8. **Differentiating Equation (3) Twice:**
   \[
   \frac{d^2}{dx^2} f''(-x) = f^{(4)}(-x)
   \]
   \[
   \frac{d^2}{dx^2} (-f(x)) = -f''(x)
   \]
   Therefore,
   \[
   f^{(4)}(-x) = -f''(x) \quad \text{(4)}
   \]

9. **Changing \( x \) to \( -x \) in Equation (4):**
   \[
   f^{(4)}(x) = f(x)
   \]
   This is a linear differential equation with the general solution:
   \[
   f(x) = c_1 e^x + c_2 e^{-x} + c_3 \cos x + c_4 \sin x \quad \text{(5)}
   \]

10. **Using Initial Conditions:**
    From Equation (3) and (5):
    \[
    f''(-x) = -f(x) \implies c_1 = -c_2, \quad c_4 = 0
    \]
    Since \( f(0) = 0 \):
    \[
    c_3 = 0
    \]
    Since \( f'(0) = -1 \):
    \[
    c_1 - c_2 = -1 \implies c_1 = -\frac{1}{2}, \quad c_2 = \frac{1}{2}
    \]
    Therefore,
    \[
    f(x) = -\frac{1}{2} e^x + \frac{1}{2} e^{-x} = -\sinh(x)
    \]

11. **Verification:**
    Substitute \( f(x) = -\sinh(x) \) back into the original equation to verify it satisfies the given condition.

The final answer is \( \boxed{ f(x) = -\sinh(x) } \).
informal_statement: Find all continuous functions $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ such that$$f(-x)+\int \limits_0^xtf(x-t)dt=x,\ \forall\ x\in \mathbb{R}$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all continuous functions $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ such that$$f(-x)+\int \limits_0^xtf(x-t)dt=x,\ \forall\ x\in \mathbb{R}$$ -/
theorem calculus_88057 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : Continuous f)
    (h : ‚àÄ x, f (-x) + ‚à´ t in Set.Ioo 0 x, t * f (x - t) = x) :
    ‚àÄ x, f x = -Real.sinh x := by

soln_description:
12. The original inequality is equivalent to proving:
$$
2 \sin \frac{1}{n}+\tan \frac{1}{n}>\frac{3}{n}\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right) \text {. }
$$

Define the function
$$
f(x)=2 \sin x+\tan x-3 x(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 1) \text {. }
$$

We only need to prove that $f(x)>0$.
Clearly, $f(0)=0$, and
$$
\begin{array}{c}
f^{\prime}(x)=2 \cos x+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} x}-3 \\
=\frac{2 \cos ^{3} x-3 \cos ^{2} x+1}{\cos ^{2} x} .
\end{array}
$$

Define the function
$$
\begin{array}{l}
g(x)=2 \cos ^{3} x-3 \cos ^{2} x+1, \\
g(0)=0 .
\end{array}
$$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Then } g^{\prime}(x)=-6 \cos ^{2} x \cdot \sin x+6 \cos x \cdot \sin x \\
=6 \sin x \cdot \cos x(1-\cos x)>0 \\
\Rightarrow g(x)>0 \text {. }
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $f^{\prime}(x)>0$, and $f(x)$ is monotonically increasing. Therefore, $f(x)>0$, which means the inequality to be proven holds.

soln_description:
1. **Assume for contradiction**: Suppose there exists a police emergency number that does not have a prime factor larger than 7. This means the number can be expressed as a product of the primes 2, 3, 5, and 7. Let the number be \( N \). Therefore, we can write:
   \[
   N = 2^a \cdot 3^b \cdot 5^c \cdot 7^d
   \]
   where \( a, b, c, \) and \( d \) are non-negative integers.

2. **Form of the number**: Since \( N \) ends in 133, we have:
   \[
   N \equiv 133 \pmod{1000}
   \]

3. **Modulo 8 analysis**: First, consider \( N \pmod{8} \). Note that:
   \[
   133 \equiv 5 \pmod{8}
   \]
   We need to check the possible values of \( 2^a \pmod{8} \):
   - If \( a \geq 3 \), then \( 2^a \equiv 0 \pmod{8} \).
   - If \( a = 2 \), then \( 2^a \equiv 4 \pmod{8} \).
   - If \( a = 1 \), then \( 2^a \equiv 2 \pmod{8} \).
   - If \( a = 0 \), then \( 2^a \equiv 1 \pmod{8} \).

   Since \( N \equiv 5 \pmod{8} \), \( 2^a \) must be 1, 2, or 4. Therefore, \( a \) must be 0, 1, or 2.

4. **Modulo 5 analysis**: Next, consider \( N \pmod{5} \). Note that:
   \[
   133 \equiv 3 \pmod{5}
   \]
   We need to check the possible values of \( 5^c \pmod{5} \):
   - If \( c \geq 1 \), then \( 5^c \equiv 0 \pmod{5} \).
   - If \( c = 0 \), then \( 5^c \equiv 1 \pmod{5} \).

   Since \( N \equiv 3 \pmod{5} \), \( 5^c \) must be 1. Therefore, \( c \) must be 0.

5. **Combining results**: Now, we have:
   \[
   N = 2^a \cdot 3^b \cdot 7^d
   \]
   with \( a \in \{0, 1, 2\} \) and \( c = 0 \).

6. **Modulo 7 analysis**: Finally, consider \( N \pmod{7} \). Note that:
   \[
   133 \equiv 0 \pmod{7}
   \]
   We need to check the possible values of \( 7^d \pmod{7} \):
   - If \( d \geq 1 \), then \( 7^d \equiv 0 \pmod{7} \).
   - If \( d = 0 \), then \( 7^d \equiv 1 \pmod{7} \).

   Since \( N \equiv 0 \pmod{7} \), \( 7^d \) must be 0. Therefore, \( d \) must be at least 1.

7. **Contradiction**: Given that \( d \geq 1 \), \( N \) must be divisible by 7. However, we have already established that \( N \equiv 5 \pmod{8} \) and \( N \equiv 3 \pmod{5} \), which cannot be satisfied simultaneously with \( N \equiv 0 \pmod{7} \).

Therefore, our initial assumption that \( N \) does not have a prime factor larger than 7 leads to a contradiction. Hence, every police emergency number must have a prime factor larger than 7.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
A [i]police emergency number[/i] is a positive integer that ends with the digits $133$ in decimal representation.  Prove that every police emergency number has a prime factor larger than $7$.

(In Austria, $133$ is the emergency number of the police.)

(Robert Geretschl√§ger)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

(In Austria, $133$ is the emergency number of the police.)

(Robert Geretschl√§ger) -/
theorem number_theory_83227 (n : ‚Ñï) (h : n > 0) (h' : n % 1000 = 133) :
    ‚àÉ p, Nat.Prime p ‚àß p > 7 ‚àß p ‚à£ n := by

soln_description:
## Solution

We can rewrite the equation in the form

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{p r+p-4 q}{q(r+1)}=1 \Rightarrow p r+p-4 q=q r+q \\
p r-q r=5 q-p \Rightarrow r(p-q)=5 q-p
\end{gathered}
$$

It follows that $p \neq q$ and

$$
\begin{gathered}
r=\frac{5 q-p}{p-q}=\frac{4 q+q-p}{p-q} \\
r=\frac{4 q}{p-q}-1
\end{gathered}
$$

As $p$ is prime, $p-q \neq q, p-q \neq 2 q, p-q \neq 4 q$.

We have $p-q=1$ or $p-q=2$ or $p-q=4$

i) If $p-q=1$ then

$$
q=2, p=3, r=7
$$

ii) If $p-q=2$ then $p=q+2, r=2 q-1$

If $q=1(\bmod 3)$ then $q+2 \equiv 0(\bmod 3)$

$$
q+2=3 \Rightarrow q=1
$$

contradiction.

If $q \equiv-1(\bmod 3)$ then $r \equiv-2-1 \equiv 0(\bmod 3)$

$$
\begin{gathered}
r=3 \\
r=2 q-1=3 \\
q=2 \\
p=4
\end{gathered}
$$

contradiction.

Hence $q=3, p=5, r=5$.

iii) If $p-q=4$ then $p=q+4$.

$r=q-1$

Hence $q=3, p=7, r=2$.

import Mathlib

NT12 Solve the equation $\frac{p}{q}-\frac{4}{r+1}=1$ in prime numbers.

 -/
theorem number_theory_109149 (p q r : ‚Ñï) (hpqr : p.Prime ‚àß q.Prime ‚àß r.Prime) :
    (p / q : ‚Ñö) - 4 / (r + 1) = 1 ‚Üî (p = 3 ‚àß q = 2 ‚àß r = 7) := by

soln_description:
Solution. If Marco collected $x$ stickers, then Jarko collected $\frac{2}{3} x$ stickers and Darko collected $\frac{3}{8}\left(x+\frac{2}{3} x\right)$ stickers. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x+\frac{2}{3} x+\frac{3}{8}\left(x+\frac{2}{3} x\right)=1650 \\
& x+\frac{2}{3} x+\frac{3}{8} x+\frac{1}{4} x=1650 \\
& \frac{24 x+8 x+9 x+6 x}{24}=1650 \\
& \frac{55 x}{24}=1650 \\
& x=720
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, Marco collected 720 stickers, Jarko collected $\frac{2}{3} \cdot 720=480$ and Darko collected $\frac{3}{8}(720+480)=450$ stickers.
informal_statement: 1. Marco, Zharko, and Darko collected stickers in an album. Together, they collected 1650 stickers. Zharko collected $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of stickers Marco collected, and Darko collected $\frac{3}{8}$ of the number of stickers collected by Marco and Zharko together. How many stickers did each child collect?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Marco, Zharko, and Darko collected stickers in an album. Together, they collected 1650 stickers. Zharko collected $\frac{2}{3}$ of the number of stickers Marco collected, and Darko collected $\frac{3}{8}$ of the number of stickers collected by Marco and Zharko together. How many stickers did each child collect? -/
theorem algebra_240571 (m z d : ‚Ñï) (h : m + z + d = 1650)
    (h1 : z = (2 / 3 : ‚Ñö) * m) (h2 : d = (3 / 8 : ‚Ñö) * (m + z)) :
    m = 720 ‚àß z = 480 ‚àß d = 450 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_240571 (m z d : ‚Ñï) (h : m + z + d = 1650)
    (h1 : z = (2 / 3 : ‚Ñö) * m) (h2 : d = (3 / 8 : ‚Ñö) * (m + z)) :
    m = 720 ‚àß z = 480 ‚àß d = 450 := by
  have eq1 : (m : ‚Ñö) + (z : ‚Ñö) + (d : ‚Ñö) = (1650 : ‚Ñö) := by
    exact_mod_cast h
  have h3 : 3 * (z : ‚Ñö) = 2 * (m : ‚Ñö) := by
    linarith [h1]
  have h4 : 3 * z = 2 * m := by
    exact_mod_cast h3
  have h5 : 8 * (d : ‚Ñö) = 3 * ((m : ‚Ñö) + (z : ‚Ñö)) := by
    linarith [h2]
  have h6 : 8 * d = 3 * (m + z) := by
    exact_mod_cast h5
  have hm : m = 720 := by
    omega
  have hz : z = 480 := by
    omega
  have hd : d = 450 := by
    omega
  exact ‚ü®hm, hz, hd‚ü©

soln_description:
To find the number of trailing zeros at the end of the base-$10$ representation of the integer $525^{25^2} \cdot 252^{52^5}$, we need to determine the minimum of the powers of $2$ and $5$ in the prime factorization of the number. This is because a trailing zero is produced by a factor of $10$, which is $2 \times 5$.

1. **Prime Factorization of $525$ and $252$:**
   - $525 = 5 \times 105 = 5 \times 5 \times 21 = 5^2 \times 3 \times 7$
   - $252 = 2^2 \times 126 = 2^2 \times 2 \times 63 = 2^2 \times 3^2 \times 7$

2. **Prime Factorization of $525^{25^2}$:**
   - $525^{25^2} = (5^2 \times 3 \times 7)^{25^2} = 5^{2 \cdot 25^2} \times 3^{25^2} \times 7^{25^2}$
   - Therefore, the power of $5$ in $525^{25^2}$ is $2 \cdot 25^2$.

3. **Prime Factorization of $252^{52^5}$:**
   - $252^{52^5} = (2^2 \times 3^2 \times 7)^{52^5} = 2^{2 \cdot 52^5} \times 3^{2 \cdot 52^5} \times 7^{52^5}$
   - Therefore, the power of $2$ in $252^{52^5}$ is $2 \cdot 52^5$.

4. **Combining the Factors:**
   - The total power of $2$ in the product $525^{25^2} \cdot 252^{52^5}$ is $2 \cdot 52^5$.
   - The total power of $5$ in the product $525^{25^2} \cdot 252^{52^5}$ is $2 \cdot 25^2$.

5. **Finding the Minimum Power:**
   - To determine the number of trailing zeros, we take the minimum of the powers of $2$ and $5$.
   - $2 \cdot 52^5$ and $2 \cdot 25^2$ need to be compared.
   - Clearly, $2 \cdot 25^2 = 2 \cdot 625 = 1250$.
   - $2 \cdot 52^5$ is a much larger number than $1250$.

6. **Conclusion:**
   - The number of trailing zeros is determined by the smaller power, which is $2 \cdot 25^2 = 1250$.

The final answer is $\boxed{1250}$
informal_statement:
Find the number of trailing zeros at the end of the base-$10$ representation of the integer $525^{25^2}
\cdot 252^{52^5}$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the number of trailing zeros at the end of the base-$10$ representation of the integer $525^{25^2}
\cdot 252^{52^5}$ . -/
theorem number_theory_54048 : (525^(25^2) * 252^(52^5)) % 10^1250 = 0 := by
formal_proof:

theorem number_theory_54048 : (525^(25^2) * 252^(52^5)) % 10^1250 = 0 := by 
  native_decide

informal_statement:
The following expressions that are equal in value to the fraction $\frac{-a}{a-b}$ are (   ).

A: $\frac{-a}{-a-b}$

B: $\frac{a}{a+b}$

C: $\frac{a}{b-a}$

D: $\frac{-a}{b-a}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The following expressions that are equal in value to the fraction $\frac{-a}{a-b}$ are (   ).

A: $\frac{-a}{-a-b}$

B: $\frac{a}{a+b}$

C: $\frac{a}{b-a}$

D: $\frac{-a}{b-a}$ -/
theorem algebra_2560 {a b : ‚Ñù} (h : a ‚â† b) : -a / (a - b) = a / (b - a) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_2560 {a b : ‚Ñù} (h : a ‚â† b) : -a / (a - b) = a / (b - a) := by
  have h1 : a - b ‚â† 0 := by
    intro h2
    apply h
    linarith
  have h2 : b - a ‚â† 0 := by
    intro h3
    have h4 : a - b = 0 := by linarith
    contradiction
  field_simp [h1, h2]
  <;> ring

soln_description: Let $n=\overline{a_{k} a_{k-1} \ldots a_{0}}$ be an integer equal to the sum of squares of its own digits. Then $n=10^{k} a_{k}+10^{k-1} a_{k-1}+$ $\cdots+a_{0}$. On the other hand $a_{0}^{2}+a_{1}^{2}+\cdots+a_{k}^{2} \leq 9^{2} \cdot(k+1)=81 \cdots(k+1)<10^{k}$ for $k \geq 4$ (the last inequality is easy to prove by induction because it holds for $k=4$ and if it holds for some $k$ then $81 \cdot(k+2)=81 \cdot(k+1)+81 \leq 10^{k}+81<$ $10^{k}+10^{k}<10^{k+1}$ ).
informal_statement: Prove that no integer greater than 2008 can be equal to the sum of squares of its digits.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that no integer greater than 2008 can be equal to the sum of squares of its digits. -/

informal_statement:
229. Cubic Diophantine Equation. Solve the equation in integers

$$
x^{3}+1=y^{2}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 229. Cubic Diophantine Equation. Solve the equation in integers

$$
x^{3}+1=y^{2}
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_270655 : {(x, y) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | x ^ 3 + 1 = y ^ 2} = {(x, y) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | (x = -1 ‚àß y = 0) ‚à® (x = 0 ‚àß y = 1) ‚à® (x = 2 ‚àß y = 3)} := by

soln_description:
Proof. Obviously, if (2) holds, then (1) holds, so we only need to prove (2).

If $k$ can be divided by $2^{a}$ but not by $2^{a+1}$ $(\alpha \in \mathbb{N})$, then $\alpha$ is called the "parity exponent" of $k$. $2^{*}, 3 \cdot 2^{*}, 5 \cdot 2^{*}, 7 \cdot 2^{\infty}$, $\cdots$ are numbers with a parity exponent of $\alpha$; and the numbers $2 \cdot 2^{\infty}, 4 \cdot 2^{a}, 6 \cdot 2^{a}$, $\cdots$ are located between two adjacent numbers in the above sequence, so there must be a number with a higher parity exponent between any two numbers with the same parity exponent. Therefore, among $m, m+1, \cdots, n-1, n$, there is only one number with the highest parity exponent, let this number be $q$, and its parity exponent be $\mu$.

Let $k=2^{*} l_{k}$ (where $\alpha_{k} \geqslant 0, \alpha_{k} \in \mathbb{Z}, l_{k} \in \mathbb{N}$, and $l_{k}$ is an odd number $(n \leqslant k \leqslant m)$), and $I = l_{m} l_{m+1} \cdots l_{n}$. Multiplying both sides of $H(m, n)=\frac{1}{m} + \frac{1}{m+1} + \cdots + \frac{1}{n}$ by $2^{\mu} L$, in the expanded terms on the right side, except for $\frac{2^{\mu} L}{q}$ which is odd, all other terms are even. Therefore, $2^{\mu} L H(m, n)$ is odd. Let $2^{\mu} I H(m, n) = 2r - 1 (r \in \mathbb{N})$, then $H(m, n) = \frac{2r - 1}{2^{\mu} L} = \frac{q}{p}$.
From this, we can see: $p$ is even, and $q$ is odd.
informal_statement:
Example 1. Prove: (1) $H(m, n)$ is not an integer;
(2) If $H(m, n)$ is written as a reduced fraction $\frac{q}{p},(p, q)=1$, then $p$ is even, and $q$ is odd ${ }^{[1]}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 1. Prove: (1) $H(m, n)$ is not an integer;
(2) If $H(m, n)$ is written as a reduced fraction $\frac{q}{p},(p, q)=1$, then $p$ is even, and $q$ is odd ${ }^{[1]}$. -/
theorem number_theory_296723 {H : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
  (hH : H = Œª m n => m * n / (2 * (m + n))) :
  ¬¨ ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, H m n = k ‚àß
  (‚àÉ p q : ‚Ñ§, p.gcd q = 1 ‚àß H m n = q / p ‚àß Even p ‚àß Odd q) :=

informal_statement: There are three classes in the kindergarten, Class A has 4 more students than Class B, and Class B has 4 more students than Class C. The teacher distributes dates to the children. Each child in Class A gets 3 fewer dates than each child in Class B; each child in Class B gets 5 fewer dates than each child in Class C. As a result, Class A gets a total of 3 more dates than Class B; Class B gets a total of 5 more dates than Class C. How many dates were distributed in total among the three classes?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- There are three classes in the kindergarten, Class A has 4 more students than Class B, and Class B has 4 more students than Class C. The teacher distributes dates to the children. Each child in Class A gets 3 fewer dates than each child in Class B; each child in Class B gets 5 fewer dates than each child in Class C. As a result, Class A gets a total of 3 more dates than Class B; Class B gets a total of 5 more dates than Class C. How many dates were distributed in total among the three classes? -/
theorem algebra_551
  (class_a_students class_b_students class_c_students child_a child_b child_c : ‚Ñï)
  (h‚ÇÄ : class_a_students = class_b_students + 4)
  (h‚ÇÅ : class_b_students = class_c_students + 4)
  (h‚ÇÇ : child_a = child_b - 3)
  (h‚ÇÉ : child_b = child_c - 5)
  (h‚ÇÑ : class_a_students * child_a = class_b_students * child_b + 3)
  (h‚ÇÖ : class_b_students * child_b = class_c_students * child_c + 5) :
  child_a * class_a_students + child_b * class_b_students + child_c * class_c_students = 673 := by

soln_description:
$$
\tan x=\frac{11}{10} \Rightarrow \sin 2 x=\frac{2 \tan x}{1+\tan ^{2} x}=\frac{\frac{11}{5}}{1+\frac{121}{100}}=\frac{220}{221} \text {, }
$$

Then $\left(\frac{1}{\sin x \cos x}-1\right)^{7}=\left(\frac{2}{\sin 2 x}-1\right)^{7}=\left(1+\frac{1}{110}\right)^{7} \in(1,2)$, so the answer is 1.
informal_statement: 1. Given that the real number $x$ satisfies $20 \sin x=22 \cos x$, then the greatest integer not exceeding the real number $\left(\frac{1}{\sin x \cos x}-1\right)^{7}$ is $\qquad$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 1. Given that the real number $x$ satisfies $20 \sin x=22 \cos x$, then the greatest integer not exceeding the real number $\left(\frac{1}{\sin x \cos x}-1\right)^{7}$ is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_188056 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : 20 * sin x = 22 * cos x) :
    ‚åä((1 / (sin x * cos x) - 1)^7 : ‚Ñù)‚åã = 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

theorem algebra_188056 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : 20 * sin x = 22 * cos x) :
    ‚åä((1 / (sin x * cos x) - 1)^7 : ‚Ñù)‚åã = 1 := by
  have h1 : sin x ‚â† 0 := by
    by_contra h
    rw [h] at hx
    have h2 : cos x = 0 := by nlinarith [Real.cos_sq_add_sin_sq x]
    have h3 : cos x ^ 2 + sin x ^ 2 = 1 := Real.cos_sq_add_sin_sq x
    rw [h, h2] at h3
    norm_num at h3
  have h2 : cos x ‚â† 0 := by
    by_contra h
    rw [h] at hx
    have h1 : sin x = 0 := by nlinarith [Real.cos_sq_add_sin_sq x]
    have h3 : cos x ^ 2 + sin x ^ 2 = 1 := Real.cos_sq_add_sin_sq x
    rw [h, h1] at h3
    norm_num at h3
  have h3 : sin x = (11 / 10) * cos x := by
    linarith [hx]
  have h4 : sin x ^ 2 + cos x ^ 2 = 1 := Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq x
  rw [h3] at h4
  have h5 : cos x ^ 2 = 100 / 221 := by
    nlinarith
  have h6 : sin x * cos x = 110 / 221 := by
    have h7 : sin x * cos x = (11 / 10) * cos x ^ 2 := by
      rw [h3]
      ring
    rw [h7, h5]
    norm_num
  have h8 : (1 / (sin x * cos x) - 1 : ‚Ñù) = (111 / 110 : ‚Ñù) := by
    rw [show sin x * cos x = (110 / 221 : ‚Ñù) by linarith [h6]]
    norm_num
  rw [h8]
  norm_num [Int.floor_eq_iff]

soln_description:
„ÄêKey Points„ÄëJourney
„ÄêAnswer„Äë216 kilometers
„ÄêAnalysis„ÄëProportion Method
(1) Original speed: Later speed $=5: 6$
Original time: Later time $=6: 5$
Original time $=6 \times 20=120$ minutes $=2$ hours, total time is $2+1=3$ hours;
(2) Original speed: Later speed $=3: 4$
Original time: Later time $=4: 3$
Original time $=4 \times 30=120$ minutes $=2$ hours, the time taken to travel 72 kilometers at the original speed is $3-1=1$ hour; the distance from the school to the Martyrs' Cemetery is $72 \div 1 \times 3=216$ kilometers.
informal_statement: 11. On Qingming Festival, the students take a bus to the martyrs' cemetery to pay respects. If the bus increases its speed by one-fifth after driving for 1 hour, it can arrive 20 minutes earlier than the scheduled time; if the bus first travels 72 kilometers at the original speed and then increases its speed by one-third, it can arrive 30 minutes earlier than the scheduled time. How many kilometers is it from the school to the martyrs' cemetery?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 11. On Qingming Festival, the students take a bus to the martyrs' cemetery to pay respects. If the bus increases its speed by one-fifth after driving for 1 hour, it can arrive 20 minutes earlier than the scheduled time; if the bus first travels 72 kilometers at the original speed and then increases its speed by one-third, it can arrive 30 minutes earlier than the scheduled time. How many kilometers is it from the school to the martyrs' cemetery? -/
theorem algebra_255768 (d v : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : d > 0) (h‚ÇÅ : v > 0)
    (h‚ÇÇ : d / (1 + v / 5) = d / v - 20 / 60) (h‚ÇÉ : d / (1 + 72 / v) = d / v - 30 / 60) :
    d = 216 := by

    (ha2 : a 2 = 1)

soln_description:
Solution: We find the derivative: $g^{\prime}(x)=8 \sin ^{7} x \cos x-64 \cos ^{7} x \sin x=8 \sin x \cos x\left(\sin ^{6} x-8 \cos ^{6} x\right)$. The critical points of this function are the roots of the equations $\sin x=0, \cos x=0$ and $\sin ^{6} x=8 \cos ^{6} x$, from which $x=k \pi, x=\frac{\pi}{2}+k \pi, x= \pm \operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{2}+k \pi, k \in Z$.

If $x=k \pi$, then $g(x)=8$.

If $x=\frac{\pi}{2}+k \pi$, then $g(x)=1$.

If $x= \pm \operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{2}+k \pi$, then $|\sin x|=\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}},|\cos x|=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$, therefore, $g(x)=\frac{16}{81}+8 \cdot \frac{1}{81}=\frac{8}{27}$.

Thus, $g_{\min }=\frac{8}{27}, g_{\max }=8$.
informal_statement:

Answer. $g_{\min }=\frac{8}{27}, g_{\max }=8$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 5. Find the maximum and minimum values of the function $g(x)=\sin ^{8} x+8 \cos ^{8} x$.

Answer. $g_{\min }=\frac{8}{27}, g_{\max }=8$. -/
theorem algebra_241384 (g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hg : g = Œª x => sin x ^ 8 + 8 * cos x ^ 8) :
    IsLeast (range g) (8 / 27) ‚àß IsGreatest (range g) 8 :=

soln_description:
1. We start by noting that a positive integer \( n \) is called *cool* if it can be expressed in the form \( a! \cdot b! + 315 \) where \( a \) and \( b \) are positive integers.
2. We need to find the sum of all cool numbers that are also prime numbers.
3. First, observe that \( 315 = 3^2 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \). This means that any cool number \( n = a! \cdot b! + 315 \) must be checked for primality.
4. Without loss of generality, assume \( a \leq b \). This simplifies our search since we only need to consider cases where \( a \leq b \).

### Case Analysis:
- **Case 1: \( a = 1 \)**
  - If \( a = 1 \), then \( n = 1! \cdot b! + 315 = b! + 315 \).
  - Check for \( b = 1 \):
    \[
    n = 1! \cdot 1! + 315 = 1 + 315 = 316 \quad (\text{not prime})
    \]
  - Check for \( b = 2 \):
    \[
    n = 1! \cdot 2! + 315 = 2 + 315 = 317 \quad (\text{prime})
    \]
  - Check for \( b = 3 \):
    \[
    n = 1! \cdot 3! + 315 = 6 + 315 = 321 \quad (\text{not prime, divisible by 3})
    \]
  - For \( b \geq 4 \), \( b! \) grows very quickly, and the resulting number \( b! + 315 \) will be much larger and not prime.

- **Case 2: \( a = 2 \)**
  - If \( a = 2 \), then \( n = 2! \cdot b! + 315 = 2 \cdot b! + 315 \).
  - Check for \( b = 2 \):
    \[
    n = 2! \cdot 2! + 315 = 4 + 315 = 319 \quad (\text{not prime, divisible by 11})
    \]
  - Check for \( b = 3 \):
    \[
    n = 2! \cdot 3! + 315 = 12 + 315 = 327 \quad (\text{not prime, divisible by 3})
    \]
  - For \( b \geq 4 \), \( 2 \cdot b! \) grows very quickly, and the resulting number \( 2 \cdot b! + 315 \) will be much larger and not prime.

- **Case 3: \( a \geq 3 \)**
  - For \( a \geq 3 \), \( a! \) grows very quickly, and the resulting number \( a! \cdot b! + 315 \) will be much larger and not prime.

### Conclusion:
The only cool number that is also a prime number is \( 317 \).

The final answer is \(\boxed{317}\).
informal_statement:
A positive integer is called [i]cool[/i] if it can be expressed in the form $a!\cdot b!+315$ where $a,b$ are positive integers. For example, $1!\cdot 1!+315=316$ is a cool number. Find the sum of all cool numbers that are also prime numbers.

[i]Proposed by Evan Fang
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def isCool (n : ‚Ñï) := ‚àÉ a b, a > 0 ‚àß b > 0 ‚àß n = Nat.factorial a * Nat.factorial b + 315

/- A positive integer is called [i]cool[/i] if it can be expressed in the form $a!\cdot b!+315$ where $a,b$ are positive integers. For example, $1!\cdot 1!+315=316$ is a cool number. Find the sum of all cool numbers that are also prime numbers.

[i]Proposed by Evan Fang -/
theorem number_theory_30999 :
    ‚àë·∂† n ‚àà {n | 0 < n ‚àß isCool n ‚àß Nat.Prime n}, n = 317 := by

import Mathlib

/- Find the last two digits of ${{2017}^{({{5}^{14}})}}$. -/
theorem number_theory_4415 : (2017 ^ ((5 ^ 14) : ‚Ñï)) % 100 = 7 := by

soln_description:
Solution.

a) We have $f(-1) f(-1)=f((-1)(-1))=f(1)=1$ and thus $f(-1)= \pm 1$. Since both $f(x)=x$ and $f(x)=|x|$ are endomorphisms, both values can be taken. I thought that "to determine" had a stricter connotation... it might have been more appropriate to ask for "finding" all possible values of $f(-1)$.

b) Since any positive rational number can be written as a product of distinct prime numbers raised to integer exponents, and any endomorphism commutes with products, it follows that $f(r)=r$ for any $r \in \mathbb{Q}_{+}^{*}$. Since then we also have $f(-r)=f(-1) f(r)=f(-1) r$, in accordance with part a) we can only have $f(x)=x$ or $f(x)=|x|$ (exactly the two examples given above).

The official solution is poorly written. It suffers from the use of $\mathbb{Q}^{*}$ when it was clearly intended to use $\mathbb{Q}_{+}^{*}$; it then directly admits the values $f(-1)= \pm 1$ from algebraic operations, without verifying that both values are allowed (this is partially "fixed" at the end, when the two possible endomorphisms are constructed); finally, it juggles undeclared symbols, such as $q$ and $r$. The problem is remarkably trivial, the endomorphisms $f$ being "fixed" over $\mathbb{Q}_{+}^{*}$, with the only possible variation given by the value at the point -1.
informal_statement:
Subject (1). Let $f: \mathbb{Q}^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{Q}^{*}$ be an endomorphism of the group $\left(\mathbb{Q}^{*}, \cdot\right)$.

a) Determine $f(-1)$.

b) Determine all endomorphisms $f$ with the property that $f(p)=p$, for any $p>0$, $p$ a prime number.

MARCEL ≈¢ENA
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Subject (1). Let $f: \mathbb{Q}^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{Q}^{*}$ be an endomorphism of the group $\left(\mathbb{Q}^{*}, \cdot\right)$.

a) Determine $f(-1)$.

b) Determine all endomorphisms $f$ with the property that $f(p)=p$, for any $p>0$, $p$ a prime number.

MARCEL ≈¢ENA -/
theorem algebra_113033 {f : ‚Ñö ‚Üí ‚Ñö} (hf : ‚àÄ x, f x ‚â† 0) :
    f (-1) = 1 ‚à® f (-1) = -1 ‚àß
    (‚àÄ p, Prime p ‚Üí p > 0 ‚Üí f p = p) ‚Üî ‚àÄ x, f x = x ‚à® f x = abs x := by

soln_description:
3. Let $p=10 a \pm b(a, b \in \mathbf{Z}, 1 \leqslant b \leqslant 5)$, then
$p^{2} \equiv 10 \cdot( \pm 2 a b)+b^{2}(\bmod 100)$.
It can be verified that when $b=1,3,4,5$, the tens and units digits of $p^{2}$ have opposite parity; only when $b=2$, the last two digits of $p^{2}$ have the same parity. Therefore, the required $P$ must be of the form $10 a \pm 2$, and for $p=12, p^{2}=144$, the last two digits are 4.
By calculating $12^{2}, 18^{2}, 22^{2}, 28^{2}, 32^{2}, 38^{2}$, we find that the smallest positive integer with the last three non-zero digits being the same is 38.
