soln_description: 205 o Solution The steak temperature is obviously A - Be -kt , where A is the oven temperature, B and k are constants and t is the time. (One can write down the differential equation and solve it). Put h = e -15k . So we have A - B = 5, A - Bh = 45, A - Bh2 = 77. Subtracting, B(1 - h) = 40, Bh(1 - h) = 32. Hence h = 4/5, B = 200, A = 205. 12th Swedish 1972 ¬© John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 13 February 2004 Last corrected/updated 13 Feb 04
informal_statement: 12th Swedish 1972 Problem 3 A steak temperature 5 o is put into an oven. After 15 minutes, it has temperature 45 o . After another 15 minutes it has temperature 77 o . The oven is at a constant temperature. The steak changes temperature at a rate proportional to the difference between its temperature and that of the oven. Find the oven temperature.

The oven is at a constant temperature. The steak changes temperature at a rate proportional to the difference between its temperature and that of the oven. Find the oven temperature. -/

  linarith

soln_description:
# Solution:

Since $\quad$ $\cos (\pi-\arcsin (-0.6))=\cos (\pi+\arcsin 0.6)=-\cos (\arcsin 0.6)=-0.8, \quad$ then $x \in[1.25(\operatorname{arctg} 0.25) \cos (\pi-\arcsin (-0.6)) ; \operatorname{arctg} 3]=[-\operatorname{arctg} 0.25 ; \operatorname{arctg} 3] \quad$ Therefore, $2 x \in[-2 \operatorname{arctg} 0.25 ; 2 \operatorname{arctg} 3]$ Since $\quad 0<\operatorname{arctg} 0.25<\operatorname{arctg} 1=\pi / 4, \quad 0<2 \operatorname{arctg} 0.25<\pi / 2$, $-\pi / 2<-2 \operatorname{arctg} 0.25<0, \quad$ and $\quad \pi / 4<\operatorname{arctg} 3<\pi / 2, \quad \pi / 2<2 \operatorname{arctg} 3<\pi, \quad$ then $\cos 2 x \in[\cos (2 \operatorname{arctg} 3) ; 1] . \quad$ Using $\quad$ the formula $\cos 2 \alpha=\frac{1-\operatorname{tg}^{2} \alpha}{1+\operatorname{tg}^{2} \alpha}, \quad$ we get $\cos (2 \operatorname{arctg} 3)=-0.8, \quad$ and $\cos 2 x \in[-0.8 ; 1]$. From this, we have $10 \cos 2 x+17 \in[9 ; 27]$, and $f(x)=\log _{3}(10 \cos 2 x+17) \in\left[\log _{3} 9 ; \log _{3} 27\right]=[2 ; 3]$.

The interval $[2 ; 3]$ is the range of the function $f(x)=\log _{3}(10 \cos 2 x+17)$ for $x \in[1.25(\operatorname{arctg} 0.25) \cos (\pi-\arcsin (-0.6)) ; \operatorname{arctg} 3]$.

The sum of the integers in the interval $[2 ; 3]$ is 5.

Answer: $E_{f}=[2 ; 3]$, the sum of the integers is 5.
informal_statement: 6. Find the sum of the integers that belong to the set of values of the function $f(x)=\log _{3}(10 \cos 2 x+17)$ for $x \in[1,25(\operatorname{arctg} 0.25) \cos (\pi-\arcsin (-0.6)) ; \operatorname{arctg} 3] . \quad(10$ points $)$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 6. Find the sum of the integers that belong to the set of values of the function $f(x)=\log _{3}(10 \cos 2 x+17)$ for $x \in[1,25(\operatorname{arctg} 0.25) \cos (\pi-\arcsin (-0.6)) ; \operatorname{arctg} 3] . \quad(10$ points $)$ -/
theorem algebra_263985 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : f = Œª x => logb 3 (10 * cos (2 * x) + 17)) :
    ‚àë·∂† x ‚àà {x | 1 ‚â§ x ‚àß x ‚â§ 25 * (arctan 0.25) * cos (œÄ - arcsin (-0.6)) ‚àß
      x ‚àà Icc 1 (arctan 3)}, f x = 5 := by

soln_description:
1. Since $32 \% 35717$ ‚Äª can be divided by 72, it can be divided by 8 and 9.

If a number can be divided by 8, then the last three digits of this number can be divided by 8. Clearly, the last three digits are 176, so the last ‚Äª is 6.
If a number can be divided by 9, then the sum of the digits of this number can be divided by 9, that is,
$$
3+2+‚Äª+3+5+7+1+7+6=34+‚Äª,
$$

thus the ‚Äª is 2.
Therefore, the two star digits are 2 and 6.
informal_statement: 1. (1963 Kyiv Mathematical Olympiad) Given that the number 32 ‚Äª 35717 ‚Äª can be divided by 72, find the digits represented by these two asterisks.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. (1963 Kyiv Mathematical Olympiad) Given that the number 32 ‚Äª 35717 ‚Äª can be divided by 72, find the digits represented by these two asterisks. -/
theorem number_theory_120277 (n m : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : n < 10) (h‚ÇÅ : m < 10)
    (h‚ÇÇ : 72 ‚à£ 32000 + 3500 + 100 * n + 10 * m + 17) :
    n = 2 ‚àß m = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_120277 (n m : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : n < 10) (h‚ÇÅ : m < 10)
    (h‚ÇÇ : 72 ‚à£ 32000 + 3500 + 100 * n + 10 * m + 17) :
    n = 2 ‚àß m = 6 := by 
  interval_cases n <;> interval_cases m 
  <;> norm_num at h‚ÇÇ 
  <;> omega

informal_statement: Determine the minimum real number $M$ such that the inequality \[ \left(\frac{1}{(a+b)^2} + \frac{1}{(b+c)^2} + \frac{1}{(c+a)^2}\right)(a-bc)(b-ca)(c-ab) \leq Mabc \] holds for all positive real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfying $a + b + c = 1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Determine the minimum real number $M$ such that the inequality \[ \left(\frac{1}{(a+b)^2} + \frac{1}{(b+c)^2} + \frac{1}{(c+a)^2}\right)(a-bc)(b-ca)(c-ab) \leq Mabc \] holds for all positive real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfying $a + b + c = 1$. -/
theorem inequalities_2548 (M : ‚Ñù) :
    IsLeast {M | ‚àÄ a b c : ‚Ñù, a > 0 ‚Üí b > 0 ‚Üí c > 0 ‚Üí a + b + c = 1 ‚Üí
      (1 / (a + b)^2 + 1 / (b + c)^2 + 1 / (c + a)^2) * (a - b * c) * (b - c * a) * (c - a * b) ‚â§
        M * a * b * c} 2 := by

soln_description:
Solution. a) We have

$$
A C-B D+i(A D+B C)=I_{n} \Leftrightarrow(A+i B)(C+i D)=I_{n}
$$

which implies that the matrices $A+i B$ and $C+i D$ are inverses to one another. Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
(C+i D)(A+i B)=I_{n} & \Leftrightarrow C A-D B+i(D A+C B)=I_{n} \\
& \Leftrightarrow C A-D B=I_{n}, D A+C B=O_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

b) We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{det}((A+i B) C)=\operatorname{det}(A C+i B C) \\
& A D+B C=O_{n} \\
&=\operatorname{det}(A C-i A D) \\
&=\operatorname{det}(A(C-i D)
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{det} C \stackrel{(C+i D)(A+i B)=I_{n}}{=} \operatorname{det}((C+i D)(A+i B) C)=\operatorname{det}((C+i D) A(C-i D)) \\
&=\operatorname{det}(A)|\operatorname{det}(C+i D)|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus,

$$
\operatorname{det}(A C)=(\operatorname{det} A)^{2}|\operatorname{det}(C+i D)|^{2} \geq 0
$$

Similarly

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{det}((A+i B) D) & =\operatorname{det}(A D+i B D) \\
A D+ & B C=O_{n} \\
& =\operatorname{det}(-B C+i B D) \\
& =(-1)^{n} \operatorname{det}(B(C-i D))
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{det} D \stackrel{(C+i D)(A+i B)=I_{n}}{=} \operatorname{det}((C+i D)(A+i B) D)=(-1)^{n} \operatorname{det}((C+i D) B(C-i D)) \\
&=(-1)^{n} \operatorname{det}(B)|\operatorname{det}(C+i D)|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $(-1)^{n} \operatorname{det}(B D)=(\operatorname{det} B)^{2}|\operatorname{det}(C+i D)|^{2} \geq 0$.
informal_statement:
Problem 3. For an integer $n>2$, let $A, B, C, D \in M_{n}(\mathbb{R})$ be matrices satisfying:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A C-B D=I_{n} \\
& A D+B C=O_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $I_{n}$ is the identity matrix and $O_{n}$ is the zero matrix in $M_{n}(\mathbb{R})$.

Prove that:
a) $C A-D B=I_{n}$ and $D A+C B=O_{n}$,
b) $\operatorname{det}(A C) \geq 0$ and $(-1)^{n} \operatorname{det}(B D) \geq 0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 3. For an integer $n>2$, let $A, B, C, D \in M_{n}(\mathbb{R})$ be matrices satisfying:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A C-B D=I_{n} \\
& A D+B C=O_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $I_{n}$ is the identity matrix and $O_{n}$ is the zero matrix in $M_{n}(\mathbb{R})$.

Prove that:
a) $C A-D B=I_{n}$ and $D A+C B=O_{n}$,
b) $\operatorname{det}(A C) \geq 0$ and $(-1)^{n} \operatorname{det}(B D) \geq 0$. -/
theorem algebra_256287 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n > 2) (A B C D : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ‚Ñù)
    (h1 : A * C - B * D = 1) (h2 : A * D + B * C = 0) :
    C * A - D * B = 1 ‚àß D * A + C * B = 0 ‚àß
    0 ‚â§ (A * C).det ‚àß (-1 : ‚Ñù)^n * (B * D).det ‚â• 0 := by

soln_description: 433. For example, 1) $y=\frac{1}{1+x}$ or 2) $y=2^{-x}$. 3) Establish a one-to-one correspondence between a segment of length 1, taken on the y-axis, and the positive half of the x-axis. Let $S$ be the point whose coordinates are ( $-\boldsymbol{a}$, 0), where $\boldsymbol{a}$ is an arbitrary number, $\boldsymbol{M}$ any point on the segment 01 of the $y$-axis, $N$ the point of intersection of the ray $S M$ with the $x$-axis; $O M=y, O N=x$. Then $x=\frac{y}{1-y} a$.
informal_statement:
433. Establish a one-to-one correspondence by formula between all positive real numbers \( x (0 < x < +\infty) \) and real numbers \( y \) confined within the interval between 0 and 1 \( (0 < y < 1) \).

## V. Functions of an integer variable.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 433. Establish a one-to-one correspondence by formula between all positive real numbers \( x (0 < x < +\infty) \) and real numbers \( y \) confined within the interval between 0 and 1 \( (0 < y < 1) \).

## V. Functions of an integer variable. -/
theorem algebra_246487 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) :
    ‚àÉ! y : ‚Ñù, 0 < y ‚àß y < 1 ‚àß x = y / (1 - y) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_246487 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) :
    ‚àÉ! y : ‚Ñù, 0 < y ‚àß y < 1 ‚àß x = y / (1 - y) := by
  use x / (1 + x)
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Verify that 0 < y, y < 1 and x = y / (1 - y).
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Show that 0 < x / (1 + x).
      apply div_pos
      linarith
      linarith
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Show that x / (1 + x) < 1.
      have h1 : x / (1 + x) < 1 := by 
        have h2 : 0 < 1 + x := by linarith 
        apply (div_lt_iff‚ÇÄ h2).mpr 
        nlinarith 
      linarith 
    ¬∑ -- Verify that x = y / (1 - y).
      field_simp [(show 1 + x ‚â† 0 by linarith), (show 1 - x / (1 + x) ‚â† 0 by 
        have h1 : 0 < x := hx 
        have h2 : 0 < 1 + x := by nlinarith 
        have h3 : x / (1 + x) < 1 := by 
          have h4 : 0 < 1 + x := by nlinarith 
          apply (div_lt_iff‚ÇÄ h4).mpr 
          nlinarith 
        nlinarith 
      )]
      <;> nlinarith 
  ¬∑ -- Verify that y is unique.
    intro y' ‚ü®hy_pos, hy_lt_1, hx_eq‚ü© 
    have eq1 : y' / (1 - y') = x := by linarith 
    have eq2 : y' = x / (1 + x) := by 
      have h1 : 1 - y' ‚â† 0 := by 
        linarith 
      field_simp [h1] at eq1 ‚ä¢ 
      <;> nlinarith 
    have eq3 : y' = x / (1 + x) := eq2 
    linarith [eq3]

soln_description:
Prove: From the problem, we have
\[
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
a \cos \alpha + b \sin \alpha = c, \\
a \cos \beta + b \sin \beta = c.
\end{array}
\right.
\]
Since \(\sin \beta \cos \alpha - \cos \beta \sin \alpha = \sin (\beta - \alpha) \neq 0\), solving the above system of equations, we get
\[
a = \frac{c (\sin \beta - \sin \alpha)}{\sin (\beta - \alpha)}, \quad b = \frac{c (\cos \beta - \cos \alpha)}{\sin (\beta - \alpha)}.
\]

Thus, \(a^2 + b^2 = \frac{c^2}{\cos^2 \frac{\alpha - \beta}{2}}\), which means \(\cos^2 \frac{\alpha - \beta}{2} = \frac{c^2}{a^2 + b^2}\).
informal_statement: Example 6 Let $\alpha, \beta$ be the distinct roots of the equation $a \cos x + b \sin x - c = 0 \left(a^{2} + b^{2} \neq 0\right)$, and $\alpha \neq \beta + 2 k \pi \quad(k \in Z)$, prove that: $\cos ^{2} \frac{\alpha-\beta}{2}=\frac{c^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6 Let $\alpha, \beta$ be the distinct roots of the equation $a \cos x + b \sin x - c = 0 \left(a^{2} + b^{2} \neq 0\right)$, and $\alpha \neq \beta + 2 k \pi \quad(k \in Z)$, prove that: $\cos ^{2} \frac{\alpha-\beta}{2}=\frac{c^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}$. -/
theorem algebra_171074 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (ha : a^2 + b^2 ‚â† 0) (Œ± Œ≤ : ‚Ñù)
    (h‚ÇÅ : a * Real.cos Œ± + b * Real.sin Œ± - c = 0) (h‚ÇÇ : a * Real.cos Œ≤ + b * Real.sin Œ≤ - c = 0)
    (h‚ÇÉ : Œ± ‚â† Œ≤) (h‚ÇÑ : ¬¨‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, Œ± = Œ≤ + 2 * k * Real.pi) :
    (Real.cos ((Œ± - Œ≤) / 2))^2 = c^2 / (a^2 + b^2) := by

/- 23.17. (Jury, 81). The polynomial $P(x)$ of degree $n$ satisfies the equalities $P(k)=1 / C_{n+1}^{k}$ for $k=0,1, \ldots, n$. Find $P(n+1)$. -/

soln_description:
a) The volumes are $V=229.336 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ and $V^{\prime}=226.980 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$.

b) The error is $1.03 \%$.

c) If we substitute the formulas for $d_{1}$ and $d_{2}$ into the equation for $V$, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
V=\frac{\pi h}{12}\left((d+\delta)^{2}+(d+\delta)(d-\delta)+(d-\delta)^{2}\right) \\
V=\frac{\pi h}{12}\left(d^{2}+2 d \delta+\delta^{2}+d^{2}-\delta^{2}+d^{2}-2 d \delta+\delta^{2}\right) \\
V=\frac{\pi h}{12}\left(3 d^{2}+\delta^{2}\right)=\frac{\pi h}{4} d^{2}+\frac{\pi h}{12} \delta^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

The relative error is then

$$
\frac{V-V^{\prime}}{V}=\frac{\frac{\pi h}{12} \delta^{2}}{\frac{\pi h}{12}\left(3 d^{2}+\delta^{2}\right)}=\frac{\delta^{2}}{3 d^{2}+\delta^{2}}
$$

This results in $\frac{3}{292}$, which corresponds to the 1.03\% from above.
informal_statement:
## Task 2 - V10932

The volume of a wooden pole for telegraph lines is calculated using the following formula:

$$
V=\frac{\pi h}{12}\left(d_{1}^{2}+d_{1} d_{2}+d_{2}^{2}\right)
$$

Here, $h$ is the height, $d_{1}$ is the lower diameter, and $d_{2}$ is the upper diameter. In practice, however, the following approximate formula is often used:

$$
V^{\prime}=\frac{\pi h}{4} d^{2}
$$

where $d$ is the average diameter of the wooden pole:

$$
d=\frac{d_{1}+d_{2}}{2}
$$

a) Calculate the volume of a wooden pole for which the following values are given, using both the exact and the approximate formula:

$h=10 \mathrm{~m}, d_{1}=20 \mathrm{~cm}, d_{2}=14 \mathrm{~cm}!$

b) What percentage is the error when using the approximate formula?

c) Derive a formula for $\frac{V-V^{\prime}}{V}$ by setting $d_{1}=d+\delta$ and $d_{2}=d-\delta$!

What value does this expression yield when using the values given in part a)?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## Task 2 - V10932

The volume of a wooden pole for telegraph lines is calculated using the following formula:

$$
V=\frac{\pi h}{12}\left(d_{1}^{2}+d_{1} d_{2}+d_{2}^{2}\right)
$$

Here, $h$ is the height, $d_{1}$ is the lower diameter, and $d_{2}$ is the upper diameter. In practice, however, the following approximate formula is often used:

$$
V^{\prime}=\frac{\pi h}{4} d^{2}
$$

where $d$ is the average diameter of the wooden pole:

$$
d=\frac{d_{1}+d_{2}}{2}
$$

a) Calculate the volume of a wooden pole for which the following values are given, using both the exact and the approximate formula:

$h=10 \mathrm{~m}, d_{1}=20 \mathrm{~cm}, d_{2}=14 \mathrm{~cm}!$

b) What percentage is the error when using the approximate formula?

c) Derive a formula for $\frac{V-V^{\prime}}{V}$ by setting $d_{1}=d+\delta$ and $d_{2}=d-\delta$!

What value does this expression yield when using the values given in part a)? -/
theorem algebra_176096 {h : ‚Ñù} {d1 d2 : ‚Ñù} (hh : h = 10) (hd1 : d1 = 20) (hd2 : d2 = 14)
    (V V' : ‚Ñù) (hV : V = œÄ * h / 12 * (d1 ^ 2 + d1 * d2 + d2 ^ 2)) (hV' : V' = œÄ * h / 4 * ((d1 + d2) / 2) ^ 2)
    (hV'' : V'' = V - V') :
    V'' / V = 3 / 292 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem algebra_176096 {h : ‚Ñù} {d1 d2 : ‚Ñù} (hh : h = 10) (hd1 : d1 = 20) (hd2 : d2 = 14)
    (V V' : ‚Ñù) (hV : V = œÄ * h / 12 * (d1 ^ 2 + d1 * d2 + d2 ^ 2)) (hV' : V' = œÄ * h / 4 * ((d1 + d2) / 2) ^ 2)
    (hV'' : V'' = V - V') :
    V'' / V = 3 / 292 := by 
  subst hh
  subst hd1
  subst hd2
  subst hV
  subst hV'
  subst hV''
  field_simp
  ring_nf
  <;> linarith [Real.pi_pos]

soln_description:
## First solution.

The given conditions can be written as one equation

$$
\frac{1}{1-z}=2-i
$$

from which it follows

$$
\begin{array}{rl}
1-z=\frac{1}{2-i} & 1 \text { point } \\
1-z=\frac{2}{5}+\frac{1}{5} i & 2 \text { points } \\
z=\frac{3}{5}-\frac{1}{5} i . & 1 \text { point }
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
## Task A-2.2.

Determine the complex number $z$ such that

$$
\operatorname{Re} \frac{1}{1-z}=2 \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Im} \frac{1}{1-z}=-1
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task A-2.2.

Determine the complex number $z$ such that

$$
\operatorname{Re} \frac{1}{1-z}=2 \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Im} \frac{1}{1-z}=-1
$$ -/
theorem algebra_247432 {z : ‚ÑÇ} (hz : z ‚â† 1) :
    (1 / (1 - z)).re = 2 ‚àß (1 / (1 - z)).im = -1 ‚Üî
    z = (3 / 5 - 1 / 5 * Complex.I) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_247432 {z : ‚ÑÇ} (hz : z ‚â† 1) :
    (1 / (1 - z)).re = 2 ‚àß (1 / (1 - z)).im = -1 ‚Üî
    z = (3 / 5 - 1 / 5 * Complex.I) := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Forward direction: conditions imply z value
    intro h
    rcases h with ‚ü®h‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÇ‚ü©
    have eq3 : (1 / (1 - z)).re = (1 - z.re) / ((1 - z.re)^2 + (z.im)^2) := by
      simp [Complex.div_re, Complex.normSq, Complex.re, Complex.im, sub_eq_zero, pow_two]
      <;> ring
    have eq4 : (1 / (1 -z)).im = (z.im) / ((1 - z.re)^2 + (z.im)^2) := by
      simp [Complex.div_im, Complex.normSq, Complex.re, Complex.im, sub_eq_zero, pow_two]
      <;> ring
    rw [eq3] at h‚ÇÅ 
    rw [eq4] at h‚ÇÇ
    have h3 : (1 - z.re)^2 + (z.im)^2 ‚â† 0 := by
      by_contra h
      have h4 : (1 - z.re)^2 = 0 := by
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (1 - z.re), sq_nonneg z.im]
      have h5 : z.re = 1 := by
        nlinarith
      have h6 : z.im = 0 := by
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (1 - z.re), sq_nonneg z.im]
      have h7 : z = 1 := by
        simp [Complex.ext_iff, h5, h6]
      contradiction
    have eq1' : (1 - z.re) = 2 * ((1 - z.re)^2 + (z.im)^2) := by
      have h4 : (1 - z.re)^2 + (z.im)^2 ‚â† 0 := h3
      field_simp at h‚ÇÅ ‚ä¢
      nlinarith [h‚ÇÅ]
    have eq2' : z.im = -1 * ((1 - z.re)^2 + (z.im)^2) := by
      have h4 : (1 - z.re)^2 + (z.im)^2 ‚â† 0 := h3
      field_simp at h‚ÇÇ ‚ä¢
      nlinarith [h‚ÇÇ]
    have eq3 : (1 - z.re)^2 + (z.im)^2 = -z.im := by
      nlinarith [eq2']
    have h5 : z.re = 1 + 2 * z.im := by
      nlinarith [eq1']
    have h6 : z.im * (5 * z.im + 1) = 0 := by
      nlinarith [eq3, h5]
    cases (mul_eq_zero.mp h6) with
    | inl h7 =>
      have h8 : z.re = 1 := by
        nlinarith [h5, h7]
      have h9 : z.im = 0 := by 
        linarith [h7]
      have h_eq_1 : z = 1 := by
        simp [Complex.ext_iff, h8, h9]
      contradiction
    | inr h8 =>
      have h7 : z.im = -1 / 5 := by 
        nlinarith [h8]
      have h8 : z.re = 3 / 5 := by
        nlinarith [h5, h7]
      rw [Complex.ext_iff] at *
      simp [h8, h7]
      all_goals norm_num
  ¬∑ -- Reverse direction: z value implies conditions
    intro h
    rw [h]
    simp [Complex.div_re, Complex.div_im, Complex.normSq, Complex.re, Complex.im]
    all_goals norm_num

informal_statement: It is known that there is a prime number between ${{10}^{17}}$ and ${{10}^{17}}+10$. Try to find this prime number.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- It is known that there is a prime number between ${{10}^{17}}$ and ${{10}^{17}}+10$. Try to find this prime number. -/
theorem number_theory_13211 : ‚àÉ p : ‚Ñï, Nat.Prime p ‚àß p ‚àà Finset.Icc (10^17) (10^17 + 10) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_13211 : ‚àÉ p : ‚Ñï, Nat.Prime p ‚àß p ‚àà Finset.Icc (10^17) (10^17 + 10) := by
  use 10^17 + 3
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show 10^17 + 3 is prime
    native_decide
  ¬∑ -- Show 10^17 + 3 is in the interval [10^17, 10^17 + 10]
    native_decide

soln_description:
Let $n>2000, S_{n}=a_{1}+\ldots+a_{n}-$ be the sum of the first $n$ terms and $d_{n} a_{n+1}=S_{n}$. Then $d_{n+1} a_{n+2}=S_{n+1}=S_{n}+a_{n+1}=$ $\left(d_{n}+1\right) a_{n+1}$. Since $a_{n+2}>a_{n+1}$, we have

$d_{n+1}<d_{n}+1$, that is, $d_{n+1} \leq d_{n}$ (these are integers). Thus, the sequence $d_{n}$ is non-increasing.

It is sufficient to prove that in this sequence, each number $d$, except 1, can occur only a finite number of times.

Suppose $d_{n}=d_{n+1}=\ldots=d_{n+k}=d$. According to the formula obtained above,

$a_{n+k+1}=\frac{d+1}{d} a_{n+k}=\left(\frac{d+1}{d}\right)^{2} a_{n+k-1}=\ldots=\left(\frac{d+1}{d}\right)^{k} a_{n+1}$. The numbers $d$ and $d+1$ are coprime, and $a_{n+1}$ can only be divisible by a finite power of $d$.
informal_statement:
Shapovalov A.V.

In an infinite increasing sequence of natural numbers, each number starting from the 2002nd is a divisor of the sum of all preceding numbers. Prove that in this sequence, there exists some number such that every number starting from it is equal to the sum of all preceding numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Shapovalov A.V.

In an infinite increasing sequence of natural numbers, each number starting from the 2002nd is a divisor of the sum of all preceding numbers. Prove that in this sequence, there exists some number such that every number starting from it is equal to the sum of all preceding numbers. -/
theorem number_theory_200691 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï) (ha : StrictMono a)
    (h : ‚àÄ n, 2002 ‚â§ n ‚Üí a n ‚à£ ‚àë i in Finset.Ico 1 n, a i) :
    ‚àÉ b, ‚àÄ n, b ‚â§ n ‚Üí a n = ‚àë i in Finset.Ico 1 n, a i := by

soln_description:
Answer: By $30 \%$.

Solution: By increasing the speed by $60 \%$, i.e., by 1.6 times, Ivan Semenovich reduced the time by 1.6 times and gained 40+25=65 minutes. Denoting the usual travel time as $T$, we get $\frac{T}{1.6}=T-65$, from which $T=\frac{520}{3}$. To arrive in $T-40=\frac{400}{3}$, the speed needed to be increased by $\frac{520}{3} \div \frac{400}{3}=1.3$ times, i.e., by $30 \%$.
informal_statement: 2. Ivan Semenovich leaves for work at the same time every day, drives at the same speed, and arrives exactly at 9:00. One day he overslept and left 40 minutes later than usual. To avoid being late, Ivan Semenovich drove at a speed 60% faster than usual and arrived at 8:35. By what percentage should he have increased his usual speed to arrive exactly at 9:00?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Ivan Semenovich leaves for work at the same time every day, drives at the same speed, and arrives exactly at 9:00. One day he overslept and left 40 minutes later than usual. To avoid being late, Ivan Semenovich drove at a speed 60% faster than usual and arrived at 8:35. By what percentage should he have increased his usual speed to arrive exactly at 9:00? -/
theorem algebra_190721 (v : ‚Ñù) (h : v > 0) (t : ‚Ñù) (ht : t = 9 - 40 / 60) :
    (1 + 35 / 60) / v = 1 + 30 / 100 := by

Find $f(x)$. -/
theorem algebra_8986 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (h : ‚àÄ x y, f (f x + f y) = (x + y) * f (x + y)) :
    ‚àÄ x, f x = 0 := by

soln_description:
1. **Define the problem and the goal:**
   We need to prove that for any given $\varepsilon > 0$, there exist positive integers $m$ and $n$ such that:
   \[
   \varepsilon < \left| h\sqrt{m} - k\sqrt{n} \right| < 2\varepsilon.
   \]

2. **Choose appropriate forms for \( m \) and \( n \):**
   Let:
   \[
   \left\{ \begin{aligned}
   m &= ak^2 + t \\
   n &= ah^2
   \end{aligned} \right.
   \]
   where \( a \) and \( t \) are positive integers to be chosen such that the expression \( F = \left| h\sqrt{m} - k\sqrt{n} \right| \) lies in the interval \( (\varepsilon, 2\varepsilon) \).

3. **Determine the conditions for \( t \):**
   Choose \( t \) large enough such that:
   \[
   3t^2h^2 - 16\varepsilon^2t > 420\varepsilon^2k^2.
   \]

4. **Determine the interval for \( a \):**
   Choose \( a \) from the open interval:
   \[
   I = \left( \left( \frac{th}{4\varepsilon k} \right)^2, \left( \frac{th}{2\varepsilon k} \right)^2 - \frac{t}{k^2} \right).
   \]
   The length of \( I \) is given by:
   \[
   \left[ \left( \frac{th}{2\varepsilon k} \right)^2 - \frac{t}{k^2} \right] - \left( \frac{th}{4\varepsilon k} \right)^2 = \frac{3t^2h^2 - 16\varepsilon^2t}{16\varepsilon^2k^2} > \frac{420}{16} > 1.
   \]
   This ensures that there is a positive integer in \( I \).

5. **Compute \( F \) and show it lies in \( (\varepsilon, 2\varepsilon) \):**
   \[
   F = \left| h\sqrt{ak^2 + t} - k\sqrt{ah^2} \right|.
   \]
   Simplify \( F \):
   \[
   F = h\left( \sqrt{ak^2 + t} - \sqrt{ak^2} \right).
   \]
   Using the difference of square roots:
   \[
   F = \frac{th}{\sqrt{ak^2 + t} + \sqrt{ak^2}}.
   \]

6. **Upper bound for \( F \):**
   Note that:
   \[
   F < \frac{th}{2\sqrt{ak^2}}.
   \]
   Since:
   \[
   a > \left( \frac{th}{4\varepsilon k} \right)^2 \implies \sqrt{ak^2} > \frac{th}{4\varepsilon},
   \]
   we have:
   \[
   F < \frac{th}{2 \cdot \frac{th}{4\varepsilon}} = 2\varepsilon.
   \]

7. **Lower bound for \( F \):**
   Similarly, note that:
   \[
   F > \frac{th}{2\sqrt{ak^2 + t}}.
   \]
   Since:
   \[
   a < \left( \frac{th}{2\varepsilon k} \right)^2 - \frac{t}{k^2} \implies \sqrt{ak^2 + t} < \frac{th}{2\varepsilon},
   \]
   we have:
   \[
   F > \frac{th}{2 \cdot \frac{th}{2\varepsilon}} = \varepsilon.
   \]

8. **Conclusion:**
   Thus, the pair \( (m, n) \) works, completing the proof.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $h$ and $k$ be positive integers. Prove that for every $\varepsilon >0,$ there are positive integers $m$ and $n$ such that \[\varepsilon < \left|h\sqrt{m}-k\sqrt{n}\right|<2\varepsilon.\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $h$ and $k$ be positive integers. Prove that for every $\varepsilon >0,$ there are positive integers $m$ and $n$ such that \[\varepsilon < \left|h\sqrt{m}-k\sqrt{n}\right|<2\varepsilon.\] -/
theorem number_theory_26616 (h k : ‚Ñ§) (h‚ÇÄ : h > 0) (k‚ÇÄ : k > 0)
    (Œµ : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÅ : Œµ > 0) :
    ‚àÉ m n : ‚Ñï, m > 0 ‚àß n > 0 ‚àß Œµ < |h * Real.sqrt m - k * Real.sqrt n| ‚àß
    |h * Real.sqrt m - k * Real.sqrt n| < 2 * Œµ := by

soln_description:
Answer: $2 \sqrt{n}$ if $n$ is even and $2 \sqrt{n-1}$ if $n$ is odd.

We start with the case where $n$ is even. From the triangle inequality and the arithmetic-quadratic inequality:

$$
\sum_{i=2}^{n+1}\left|a_{i}-a_{i-1}\right| \leqslant 2 \sum\left|a_{i}\right| \leqslant 2 \sqrt{n} \sqrt{\sum a_{i}^{2}}=2 \sqrt{n}
$$

On the other hand, equality holds for $a_{2 k+1}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}$ and $a_{2 k}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}$: we have $\sum_{i=2}^{n+1}\left|a_{i}-a_{i-1}\right|=n \frac{2}{\sqrt{n}}=2 \sqrt{n}$, and $\sum a_{i}^{2}=\frac{n}{n}=1$.

Now suppose $n$ is odd, we take the indices of the sequence $\bmod n$, which defines $a_{i}$ for all integers $i$. Let's prove that there exists $i$ such that $a_{i-1} \leqslant a_{i} \leqslant a_{i+1}$ or $a_{i-1} \geqslant a_{i} \geqslant a_{i+1}$. Suppose by contradiction that this is not the case, we always have $a_{i-1} \neq a_{i}$, and thus either $a_{i-1}>a_{i}$ (and in this case, $a_{i}a_{i+1}$). In particular, if $a_{1}a_{2 k+3}$, which poses a problem for the $k$ such that $n=2 k+1$, since $a_{2 k+2}>a_{2 k+3}$ becomes $a_{1}>a_{2}$, which is contradictory. If $a_{1}>a_{2}$, we show by induction that $a_{2 k+1}>a_{2 k+2}$ and $a_{2 k+2}<a_{2 k+3}$, which poses a problem for the $k$ such that $n=2 k+1$, since $a_{2 k+2}<a_{2 k+3}$ becomes $a_{1}<a_{2}$, which is contradictory.

We can then group the terms $\left|a_{i-1}-a_{i}\right|$ and $a_{i}-a_{i+1} \mid$ into $\left|a_{i-1}-a_{i+1}\right|$. We have then reduced to the same inequality as at the beginning, but for $n-1$. The previous case ensures that $\sum_{i=2}^{n+1} \mid a_{i-1}-$ $a_{i} \mid \leqslant 2 \sqrt{n-1}$. Conversely, we obtain equality by setting $a_{2 k-1}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}$ and $a_{2 k}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}$, for $1 \leqslant k \leqslant \frac{n-1}{2}$, and $a_{n}=0$.
informal_statement:
Let $n \geqslant 3$ and $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers such that $\sum a_{i}^{2}=1$. Determine the maximum value that

$$
\sum_{i=2}^{n+1}\left|a_{i}-a_{i-1}\right|
$$

can take.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $n \geqslant 3$ and $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers such that $\sum a_{i}^{2}=1$. Determine the maximum value that

$$
\sum_{i=2}^{n+1}\left|a_{i}-a_{i-1}\right|
$$

can take. -/
theorem algebra_132528 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 3 ‚â§ n) (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (h : ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.Icc 1 n, (a i)^2 = 1) :
  ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.Icc 2 (n + 1), |a i - a (i - 1)| ‚â§ 2 * sqrt n := by

soln_description:
[Proof] Since
$$a_{n+1}+b_{n+1} \sqrt[3]{2}+c_{n+1} \sqrt[3]{4}=\left(a_{n}+b_{n} \sqrt[3]{2}+c_{n} \sqrt[3]{4}\right)(1+4 \sqrt[3]{2}-4 \sqrt[3]{4})$$

Therefore, $a_{n+1}=a_{n}-8 b_{n}+8 c_{n}, n=0,1,2, \cdots$
Given $a_{0}=1$, it follows that $a_{n}$ is always an odd number.
For every non-zero integer $k$, there exists a non-negative integer $l$ and an odd number $k^{\prime}$, such that
$$k=2^{l} \cdot k^{\prime}$$

Define $f(k)=l$.
First, we can prove that when $n=2^{m}$, for $m=0,1,2, \cdots$, $b_{n}$ and $c_{n}$ are non-zero integers, and
$$f\left(b_{n}\right)=f\left(c_{n}\right)=m+2$$

In fact, if $m=0$, then $n=1$. It is easy to see that $b_{1}=4, c_{1}=-4$, so (1) holds. Let
$$\begin{array}{l}
a=a_{2}{ }^{m}, b=b_{2}{ }^{m}, c=c_{2}{ }^{m} \\
A=a_{2^{m+1}}, B=b_{2}{ }^{m+1}, C=c_{2}{ }^{m+1}
\end{array}$$

Then $A+B \sqrt[3]{2}+C \sqrt[3]{4}=(a+b \sqrt[3]{2}+c \sqrt[3]{4})^{2}$.
From this, we get
$$\begin{array}{l}
A=a^{2}+2 b c \\
B=2 a b+2 c^{2} \\
C=2 a c+b^{2}
\end{array}$$

Since $a$ is an odd number, when $f(b)=f(c)=m+2$, it is easy to see that
$$f(B)=f(C)=m+3$$

Thus, by induction, we can prove that for any $n=2^{m}(m \geqslant 0)$, (1) holds.
Secondly, from
$$\begin{aligned}
& a_{n+m}+b_{n+m} \sqrt[3]{2}+c_{n+m} \sqrt[3]{4} \\
= & \left(a_{n}+b_{n} \sqrt[3]{2}+c_{n} \sqrt[3]{4}\right)\left(a_{m}+b_{m} \sqrt[3]{2}+c_{m} \sqrt[3]{4}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

We get
$$\begin{array}{l}
a_{n+m}=a_{n} a_{m}+2 b_{n} c_{m}+2 b_{m} c_{n}, \\
b_{n+m}=a_{n} b_{m}+a_{m} b_{n}+2 c_{n} c_{m} \\
c_{n+m}=a_{n} c_{m}+a_{m} c_{n}+b_{n} b_{m} .
\end{array}$$

If $b_{n}, b_{m}, c_{n}, c_{m}$ are all non-zero, and there exist $\lambda \neq \mu$ such that
$$f\left(b_{n}\right)=f\left(c_{n}\right)=\lambda, \quad f\left(b_{m}\right)=f\left(c_{m}\right)=\mu$$

From the fact that $a_{n}$ and $a_{m}$ are both odd numbers and the above relations, we can deduce that $b_{n+m}$ and $c_{n+m}$ are non-zero and
$$f\left(b_{n+m}\right)=f\left(c_{n+m}\right)=\min \{\lambda, \mu\}$$

For any positive integer $n$, there exist integers $0 \leqslant m_{0}<m_{1}<\cdots<m_{r}$, such that $n=2^{m_{0}}+2^{m_{1}}+\cdots+2^{m_{r}}$.
From (1) and (2), we know that $c_{n} \neq 0$, and $f\left(c_{n}\right)=m_{0}+2$, i.e.,
$$2^{m_{0}+2} \mid c_{n} \text {, but } 2^{m_{0}+3} \nmid c_{n} \text {, }$$

Thus, the conclusion to be proven holds.
informal_statement:
8-56 Let $n$ be a non-negative integer, and denote
$$(1+4 \sqrt[3]{2}-4 \sqrt[3]{4})^{n}=a_{n}+b_{n} \sqrt[3]{2}+c_{n} \sqrt[3]{4}$$

where $a_{n}, b_{n}, c_{n}$ are integers. Prove that if $c_{n}=0$, then $n=0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8-56 Let $n$ be a non-negative integer, and denote
$$(1+4 \sqrt[3]{2}-4 \sqrt[3]{4})^{n}=a_{n}+b_{n} \sqrt[3]{2}+c_{n} \sqrt[3]{4}$$

where $a_{n}, b_{n}, c_{n}$ are integers. Prove that if $c_{n}=0$, then $n=0$. -/
theorem algebra_600026 {n : ‚Ñï} (a b c : ‚Ñ§) (h : (1 + 4 * (2 : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) - 4 * (2 : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) ^ 2) ^ n = a + b * (2 : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) + c * (2 : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) ^ 2) (hc : c = 0) : n = 0 := by

soln_description:
23. Transform the equation into
$$\begin{aligned}
x^{2} & =(p+1)\left(y^{2}-x^{2}\right)-p x-p y-2 y+1 \\
& =(p+1)(y+x)(y-x)-(p+1)(x+y)+x-y+1 \\
& =((p+1)(x+y)-1)((y-x)-1) .
\end{aligned}$$

Let $z=y-1$, then the above equation becomes
$$x^{2}=(z-x)(p(z+x)+p)$$

If $(z-x,(p+1)(z+x)+p)=1$, then by (7), $z-x$ and $(p+1)(z+x)+p$ are both perfect squares. But
$$(p+1)(z+x)+p \equiv p \equiv 3(\bmod 4),$$

which is a contradiction. Therefore, $(z-x,(p+1)(z+x)+p)>1$. Let $q=(z-x,(p+1)(z+x)+p)$, then $q^{2} \mid x^{2}$, i.e., $q \mid x$, and thus $q \mid z$, so $q \mid p$. Since $q>1$ and $p$ is a prime, we have $p=q$, hence $p \mid x$. Therefore, if $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ is a positive integer solution of the equation, then $p \mid x_{0}$.

Furthermore, if $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ is a solution, we can set $x_{0}=p x_{1}, y_{0}-1=p z_{1}$. By (7), we have
$$x_{1}^{2}=\left(z_{1}-x_{1}\right)\left((p+1)\left(z_{1}+x_{1}\right)+1\right),$$

combined with $(z-x,(p+1)(z+x)+p)=p$, we know $\left(z_{1}-x_{1},(p+1)\left(z_{1}+x_{1}\right)+1\right)=1$, thus there exist $a, b \in \mathbf{N}^{*}$, such that $z_{1}-x_{1}=a^{2},(p+1)\left(z_{1}+x_{1}\right)+1=b^{2}$, at this time $x_{1}=a b$, where $(a, b)=1$. From this, we know
$$(p+2) b^{2}-(p+1)(a+b)^{2}=1$$

This Pell's equation has infinitely many positive integer solutions, which in turn implies that the original equation has infinitely many positive integer solutions.
informal_statement:
23. Let $p$ be a given prime, $p \equiv 3(\bmod 4)$. Prove: the indefinite equation
$$(p+2) x^{2}-(p+1) y^{2}+p x+(p+2) y=1$$

has infinitely many positive integer solutions $(x, y)$, and for each positive integer solution $(x, y)$, we have $p \mid x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 23. Let $p$ be a given prime, $p \equiv 3(\bmod 4)$. Prove: the indefinite equation
$$(p+2) x^{2}-(p+1) y^{2}+p x+(p+2) y=1$$

has infinitely many positive integer solutions $(x, y)$, and for each positive integer solution $(x, y)$, we have $p \mid x$. -/
theorem number_theory_7504 (p : ‚Ñï) (hp : Nat.Prime p) (h : p ‚â° 3 [MOD 4]) :
    ‚àÄ n, ‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñï,
      x > n ‚àß y > n ‚àß
      (p + 2) * x ^ 2 - (p + 1) * y ^ 2 + p * x + (p + 2) * y = 1 ‚àß
      p ‚à£ x := by

soln_description:
1. Since \( p+q+r+s \) is prime and \( p, q, r, s \) are distinct primes, one of \( p, q, r, s \) must be equal to \( 2 \). If this were not the case, then \( p+q+r+s \) would be even and greater than \( 2 \), hence not prime. Therefore, we can assume without loss of generality that \( p = 2 \).

2. Given \( p = 2 \), we have the equations:
   \[
   a^2 = p^2 + qr \quad \text{and} \quad b^2 = p^2 + qs
   \]
   Substituting \( p = 2 \), we get:
   \[
   a^2 = 4 + qr \quad \text{and} \quad b^2 = 4 + qs
   \]

3. Since \( q \) is a prime, \( q \) must divide \( a^2 - 4 \). By the properties of primes, \( q \) must divide either \( a+2 \) or \( a-2 \). Similarly, \( q \) must divide either \( b+2 \) or \( b-2 \).

4. Since \( r \neq s \), \( a \neq b \). We also note that \( a^2 - 4 \) and \( b^2 - 4 \) both have exactly two distinct prime factors. Therefore, the divisibility conditions must be equalities. Without loss of generality, let:
   \[
   q = a - 2 \quad \text{and} \quad q = b + 2
   \]
   Then:
   \[
   r = a + 2 = q + 4 \quad \text{and} \quad s = b - 2 = q - 4
   \]

5. Thus, \( q, r, s \) form an arithmetic progression with a common difference of \( 4 \). We need to find primes \( q, r, s \) such that \( q, q+4, q-4 \) are all primes.

6. Checking small primes, we find:
   \[
   q = 7 \implies r = 7 + 4 = 11 \quad \text{and} \quad s = 7 - 4 = 3
   \]
   All of these are primes.

7. Therefore, the primes are \( p = 2 \), \( q = 7 \), \( r = 11 \), and \( s = 3 \). Summing these, we get:
   \[
   p + q + r + s = 2 + 7 + 11 + 3 = 23
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{23}\)
informal_statement: Let $p$, $q$, $r$, and $s$ be 4 distinct primes such that $p+q+r+s$ is prime, and the numbers $p^2+qr$ and $p^2+qs$ are both perfect squares. What is the value of $p+q+r+s$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $p$, $q$, $r$, and $s$ be 4 distinct primes such that $p+q+r+s$ is prime, and the numbers $p^2+qr$ and $p^2+qs$ are both perfect squares. What is the value of $p+q+r+s$? -/
theorem number_theory_61318 (p q r s : ‚Ñï) (hpqr : p.Prime ‚àß q.Prime ‚àß r.Prime ‚àß s.Prime)
    (hs : p ‚â† q ‚àß p ‚â† r ‚àß p ‚â† s ‚àß q ‚â† r ‚àß q ‚â† s ‚àß r ‚â† s)
    (hprime : (p + q + r + s).Prime) (h1 : ‚àÉ m, m^2 = p^2 + q * r) (h2 : ‚àÉ n, n^2 = p^2 + q * s) :
    p + q + r + s = 23 := by

soln_description: 1. $\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{a+b+c}=\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}-2(a b+b c+c a)}{a+b+c}=(a+b+c)-2 \cdot \frac{a b+b c+c a}{a+b+c}$ - an integer.
informal_statement: 1. It is known that the numbers $a+b+c$ and $\frac{a b+b c+c a}{a+b+c}$ are integers. Prove that the number $\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{a+b+c}$ is also an integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. It is known that the numbers $a+b+c$ and $\frac{a b+b c+c a}{a+b+c}$ are integers. Prove that the number $\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{a+b+c}$ is also an integer. -/
theorem algebra_131885 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (ha : ‚àÉ m : ‚Ñ§, a + b + c = m)
    (hb : ‚àÉ n : ‚Ñ§, (a * b + b * c + c * a) / (a + b + c) = n) :
    ‚àÉ p : ‚Ñ§, (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2) / (a + b + c) = p := by

soln_description:
1. We need to find the smallest integer \( n \ge 2 \) such that there exist \( n \) positive integers adding up to 2014, and these integers have distinct remainders when divided by \( n \).

2. Let \( a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n \) be the \( n \) positive integers. We know:
   \[
   a_1 + a_2 + \cdots + a_n = 2014
   \]
   and the remainders \( a_i \mod n \) are distinct for \( i = 1, 2, \ldots, n \).

3. The possible remainders when dividing by \( n \) are \( 0, 1, 2, \ldots, n-1 \). Therefore, the sum of these remainders is:
   \[
   0 + 1 + 2 + \cdots + (n-1) = \frac{n(n-1)}{2}
   \]

4. We need to check if there exists an \( n \) such that:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n a_i = 2014
   \]
   and the remainders \( a_i \mod n \) are distinct.

5. Let's start with \( n = 2 \):
   - The possible remainders are \( 0 \) and \( 1 \).
   - The sum of two distinct positive integers with remainders \( 0 \) and \( 1 \) is not 2014 (since \( 2014 \) is even).

6. Next, consider \( n = 3 \):
   - The possible remainders are \( 0, 1, \) and \( 2 \).
   - The sum of three distinct positive integers with remainders \( 0, 1, \) and \( 2 \) is not 2014 (since \( 2014 \) is not divisible by 3).

7. Now, consider \( n = 4 \):
   - The possible remainders are \( 0, 1, 2, \) and \( 3 \).
   - We can choose the integers \( 502, 503, 504, \) and \( 505 \):
     \[
     502 + 503 + 504 + 505 = 2014
     \]
   - The remainders when divided by 4 are:
     \[
     502 \mod 4 = 2, \quad 503 \mod 4 = 3, \quad 504 \mod 4 = 0, \quad 505 \mod 4 = 1
     \]
   - These remainders are distinct.

8. Therefore, \( n = 4 \) satisfies the conditions.

The final answer is \( \boxed{4} \)
informal_statement: Say that an integer $n \ge 2$ is [i]delicious[/i] if there exist $n$ positive integers adding up to 2014 that have distinct remainders when divided by $n$.  What is the smallest delicious integer?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def is_delicious (n : ‚Ñï) : Prop :=
  ‚àÉ s : Finset ‚Ñï,
    s.card = n ‚àß
    (‚àÄ i ‚àà s, i > 0) ‚àß
    (‚àë i ‚àà s, i) = 2014 ‚àß
    (‚àÄ i ‚àà s, ‚àÄ j ‚àà s, i ‚â† j ‚Üí (i % n) ‚â† (j % n))

/- Say that an integer $n \ge 2$ is [i]delicious[/i] if there exist $n$ positive integers adding up to 2014 that have distinct remainders when divided by $n$.  What is the smallest delicious integer? -/
theorem number_theory_77900 :
    IsLeast {n | 2 ‚â§ n ‚àß is_delicious n} 4 := by

soln_description:
Proof
$$
\text { Let } \begin{aligned}
A & =2 \sin ^{4} x+3 \sin ^{2} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x+5 \cos ^{4} x, \\
B & =2 \cos ^{4} x+3 \cos ^{2} x \cdot \sin ^{2} x+5 \sin ^{4} x .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then \( A+B=7\left(\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{4} x\right)+6 \sin ^{2} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x \)
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=7\left(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x\right)^{2}-8 \sin ^{2} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x \\
=7-2 \sin ^{2} 2 x=5+2 \cos ^{2} 2 x,
\end{array}
$$
$$
A-B=3\left(\cos ^{4} x-\sin ^{4} x\right)=3\left(\cos ^{2} x-\sin ^{2} x\right)=3 \cos 2 x \text {. }
$$

By adding (1) and (2), we get \( 2 A=2 \cos ^{2} 2 x+3 \cos 2 x+5=2\left(\cos 2 x+\frac{3}{4}\right)^{2}+\frac{31}{8} \leqslant 2\left(1+\frac{3}{4}\right)^{2}+ \)
$$
\frac{31}{8}=10 \text {. }
$$

Thus, \( A \leqslant 5 \), which means \( 2 \sin ^{4} x+3 \sin ^{2} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x+5 \cos ^{4} x \leqslant 5 \).
informal_statement: Example 17 Prove: $2 \sin ^{4} x+3 \sin ^{2} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x+5 \cos ^{4} x \leqslant 5$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- Example 17 Prove: $2 \sin ^{4} x+3 \sin ^{2} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x+5 \cos ^{4} x \leqslant 5$.

 -/
theorem inequalities_245406 (x : ‚Ñù) :
  2 * (sin x)^4 + 3 * (sin x)^2 * (cos x)^2 + 5 * (cos x)^4 ‚â§ 5 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

theorem inequalities_245406 (x : ‚Ñù) :
  2 * (sin x)^4 + 3 * (sin x)^2 * (cos x)^2 + 5 * (cos x)^4 ‚â§ 5 := by
  have h1 : sin x ^ 2 + cos x ^ 2 = 1 := Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq x
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (sin x ^ 2 - 1), sq_nonneg (cos x ^ 2 - 1),
          sq_nonneg (sin x ^ 2 - cos x ^ 2),
          sq_nonneg (sin x * cos x),
          sq_nonneg (sin x ^ 4 - cos x ^ 4),
          sq_nonneg (sin x ^ 2), sq_nonneg (cos x ^ 2),
          h1]

soln_description:
Prove that if $G_{-1}=0$, then $G_{n}=G_{n-1}+G_{n-2}+1$ holds for $n=1$.
If $m=1$, the conclusion is obvious.
If $m=2$, then by the problem statement and definition, the parity of the sequence is
even, odd, even, even, odd, even, even, ‚Ä¶
Thus, there are consecutive terms divisible by $m=2$.
If $m \geqslant 3$, consider the pairs of consecutive terms $\left(G_{n}, G_{n+1}\right)$ in the sequence $\left\{G_{n}\right\}$.

For modulo $m$, there are at most $m^{2}$ different pairs.

Since the sequence is infinite, among $m^{2}+1$ pairs, there must be two pairs that have the same remainder modulo $m$ (let these pairs be $\left.\left(G_{k}, G_{k+1}\right) „ÄÅ\left(G_{l}, G_{l+1}\right)(k<l)\right)$, satisfying
$$
\left(G_{k}, G_{k+1}\right) \equiv\left(G_{l}, G_{l+1}\right)(\bmod m) .
$$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Since } G_{k-1}=G_{k+1}-G_{k}-1, \\
G_{l-1}=G_{l+1}-G_{l}-1,
\end{array}
$$

and $G_{k+1}-G_{k} \equiv G_{l+1}-G_{l}$, then
$$
G_{k-1} \equiv G_{l-1}(\bmod m) \text {. }
$$

Thus, $\left(G_{k-1}, G_{k}\right)$ and $\left(G_{l-1}, G_{l}\right)$ are congruent modulo $m$.
Continuing this, we have $\left(G_{-1}, G_{0}\right)$ and $\left(G_{l-k-1}, G_{l-k}\right)$ are congruent modulo $m$.
Since $G_{-1}=G_{1}=0$, we have
$$
G_{l-k-1} \equiv G_{l-k} \equiv 0(\bmod m),
$$

Therefore, there exist consecutive terms that are both divisible by $m$.
informal_statement:
Example 5 The sequence $\left\{G_{n}\right\}$ satisfies
$$
G_{0}=0, G_{1}=1, G_{n}=G_{n-1}+G_{n-2}+1(n \geqslant 2) \text {. }
$$

Prove: For any positive integer $m$, there exist two consecutive terms in $\left\{G_{n}\right\}$ that are both divisible by $m$. [3]
(2008, Estonian National Team Selection Exam)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def G : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï
| 0 => 0
| 1 => 1
| n + 2 => G (n + 1) + G n + 1

/- Example 5 The sequence $\left\{G_{n}\right\}$ satisfies
$$
G_{0}=0, G_{1}=1, G_{n}=G_{n-1}+G_{n-2}+1(n \geqslant 2) \text {. }
$$

Prove: For any positive integer $m$, there exist two consecutive terms in $\left\{G_{n}\right\}$ that are both divisible by $m$. [3]
(2008, Estonian National Team Selection Exam) -/
theorem number_theory_310750 (m : ‚Ñï) (hm : 0 < m) :
    ‚àÉ n, m ‚à£ G n ‚àß m ‚à£ G (n + 1) := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Domain of definition: $00, \\ \log _{5}^{2} x-2.5 \log _{5} x+1=0\end{array} \Rightarrow\left(\log _{5} x\right)_{3}=\frac{1}{2}>0,\left(\log _{5} x\right)_{4}=2>0\right.$, from which $x_{3}=\sqrt{5}, x_{4}=25$.

Answer: $\frac{1}{25} ; \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} ; \sqrt{5} ; 25$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7.188. $\sqrt{\log _{5}^{2} x+\log _{x}^{2} 5+2}=2.5$. -/
theorem algebra_167125 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x ‚àß x ‚â† 1) :
    Real.sqrt (Real.logb 5 x ^ 2 + Real.logb x 5 ^ 2 + 2) = 2.5 ‚Üî
    x = 1 / 25 ‚à® x = 1 / Real.sqrt 5 ‚à® x = Real.sqrt 5 ‚à® x = 25 := by

soln_description:
The first method. Let $x_{1}+x_{2}=x_{3}+x_{4}=m$. Then $f(x)-1=\left(x-x_{1}\right)\left(x-x_{2}\right)\left(x-x_{3}\right)\left(x-x_{4}\right)=\left(x^{2}-m x+x_{1} x_{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-\right.$ $\left.m x+x_{3} x_{4}\right)$.

The equation $f(x)=2$ can be written as $\left(x^{2}-m x+x_{1} x_{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-m x+x_{3} x_{4}\right)=1$. By making the substitution $y=x^{2}-m x$, we obtain the equation

$\left(y+x_{1} x_{2}\right)\left(y+x_{3} x_{4}\right)=1$. Since the equation $f(x)=2$ has four roots, this equation must have two roots $y_{1}$ and $y_{2}$. In this case, two roots of the equation $f(x)=2$ will be solutions of the equation $x^{2}-m x=y_{1}$, and the other two will be solutions of the equation $x^{2}-m x=y_{2}$. But in each of these equations, the sum of the roots is equal to $m$, so for the four roots of the equation $f(x)=2$, the required equality holds.

The second method. Let $1 / 2\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)=1 / 2\left(x_{3}+x_{4}\right)=n$. Consider the polynomial $g(x)=f(x+n)$, then the roots of the equation $g(x)=1$ will be the numbers $\alpha_{i}=x_{i}-n, i=1,2,3,4$. In this case, $\alpha_{1}+\alpha_{2}=\alpha_{3}+\alpha_{4}=0$, that is, these numbers are pairwise opposite. Therefore, the function $g(x)=\left(x-\alpha_{1}\right)\left(x-\alpha_{2}\right)\left(x-\alpha_{3}\right)\left(x-\alpha_{4}\right)=\left(x-\alpha_{1}\right)\left(x+\alpha_{1}\right)\left(x-\alpha_{3}\right)\left(x+\alpha_{3}\right)=\left(x^{2}-\alpha_{1}^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-\alpha_{2}^{2}\right)$ is even.

Therefore, the roots of the equation $g(x)=2$ are also pairwise opposite.

The roots of the equation $f(x)=2$ will be obtained from the corresponding roots of the equation $g(x)=2$ by adding the number $n$, so they will have the required property.
informal_statement:
[ Quadratic equations. Vieta's theorem ] $[$ Evenness and oddness $\quad]$

Given the polynomial $f(x)=x^{4}+a x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x$. It is known that each of the equations $f(x)=1$ and $f(x)=2$ has four roots. Prove that if for the roots of the first equation the equality $x_{1}+x_{2}=x_{3}+x_{4}$ holds, then the same equality holds for the roots of the second equation.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- [ Quadratic equations. Vieta's theorem ] $[$ Evenness and oddness $\quad]$

Given the polynomial $f(x)=x^{4}+a x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x$. It is known that each of the equations $f(x)=1$ and $f(x)=2$ has four roots. Prove that if for the roots of the first equation the equality $x_{1}+x_{2}=x_{3}+x_{4}$ holds, then the same equality holds for the roots of the second equation. -/
theorem algebra_194506 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (h‚ÇÄ : ‚àÄ x, f x = x ^ 4 + a * x ^ 3 + b * x ^ 2 + c * x)
    (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àÉ x‚ÇÅ x‚ÇÇ x‚ÇÉ x‚ÇÑ : ‚Ñù, x‚ÇÅ ‚â† x‚ÇÇ ‚àß x‚ÇÅ ‚â† x‚ÇÉ ‚àß x‚ÇÅ ‚â† x‚ÇÑ ‚àß x‚ÇÇ ‚â† x‚ÇÉ ‚àß x‚ÇÇ ‚â† x‚ÇÑ ‚àß x‚ÇÉ ‚â† x‚ÇÑ ‚àß
      f x‚ÇÅ = 1 ‚àß f x‚ÇÇ = 1 ‚àß f x‚ÇÉ = 1 ‚àß f x‚ÇÑ = 1 ‚àß x‚ÇÅ + x‚ÇÇ = x‚ÇÉ + x‚ÇÑ) :
    ‚àÉ x‚ÇÅ x‚ÇÇ x‚ÇÉ x‚ÇÑ : ‚Ñù, x‚ÇÅ ‚â† x‚ÇÇ ‚àß x‚ÇÅ ‚â† x‚ÇÉ ‚àß x‚ÇÅ ‚â† x‚ÇÑ ‚àß x‚ÇÇ ‚â† x‚ÇÉ ‚àß x‚ÇÇ ‚â† x‚ÇÑ ‚àß x‚ÇÉ ‚â† x‚ÇÑ ‚àß
      f x‚ÇÅ = 2 ‚àß f x‚ÇÇ = 2 ‚àß f x‚ÇÉ = 2 ‚àß f x‚ÇÑ = 2 ‚àß x‚ÇÅ + x‚ÇÇ = x‚ÇÉ + x‚ÇÑ := by

    (‚àë i in Finset.range 6, a i) / 6 ‚â§ (‚àë i in Finset.range 10, a i) / 10 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_602460 (a : Fin 10 ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÄ i j, i < j ‚Üí a i ‚â§ a j) :
    (‚àë i in Finset.range 6, a i) / 6 ‚â§ (‚àë i in Finset.range 10, a i) / 10 := by

    norm_num [Finset.sum_range_succ] at *
    all_goals 
      linarith [h 0 1 (by simp), h 0 2 (by simp), h 0 3 (by simp), h 0 4 (by simp), h 0 5 (by simp), h 0 6 (by simp), h 0 7 (by simp), h 0 8 (by simp), h 0 9 (by simp), h 1 2 (by simp), h 1 3 (by simp), h 1 4 (by simp), h 1 5 (by simp), h 1 6 (by simp), h 1 7 (by simp), h 1 8 (by simp), h 1 9 (by simp), h 2 3 (by simp), h 2 4 (by simp), h 2 5 (by simp), h 2 6 (by simp), h 2 7 (by simp), h 2 8 (by simp), h 2 9 (by simp), h 3 4 (by simp), h 3 5 (by simp), h 3 6 (by simp), h 3 7 (by simp), h 3 8 (by simp), h 3 9 (by simp), h 4 5 (by simp), h 4 6 (by simp), h 4 7 (by simp), h 4 8 (by simp), h 4 9 (by simp), h 5 6 (by simp), h 5 7 (by simp), h 5 8 (by simp), h 5 9 (by simp), h 6 7 (by simp), h 6 8 (by simp), h 6 9 (by simp), h 7 8 (by simp), h 7 9 (by simp), h 8 9 (by simp)]
  linarith

soln_description:
12. $\frac{100 p}{100+p}$.

Let the cost of the item be $a$, then we have
" $(1+p \%) (1-d \%) = a$, solving for $d$ gives $d = \frac{100 p}{100+p}$.
informal_statement: 12. The marked price of a product is $p$ \% higher than the cost. When the product is sold at a discount, to avoid a loss, the discount on the selling price (i.e., the percentage reduction) must not exceed $d$ \%. Then $d$ can be expressed in terms of $p$ as $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 12. The marked price of a product is $p$ \% higher than the cost. When the product is sold at a discount, to avoid a loss, the discount on the selling price (i.e., the percentage reduction) must not exceed $d$ \%. Then $d$ can be expressed in terms of $p$ as $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_306962 {p d : ‚Ñù} (hp : p > 0) (hd : 0 < d) (h : (1 + p / 100) * (1 - d / 100) = 1) :
    d = 100 * p / (100 + p) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_306962 {p d : ‚Ñù} (hp : p > 0) (hd : 0 < d) (h : (1 + p / 100) * (1 - d / 100) = 1) :
    d = 100 * p / (100 + p) := by
  have h2 : (100 + p) ‚â† 0 := by
    linarith
  field_simp [h2] at h ‚ä¢

Notice,
$$

(2 m+1)^{2}-(2 n+1)^{2} \\
=4(m+n+1)(m-n) .

Since $m+n+1$ and $m-n$ have opposite parity, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(m-n, m+n+1) \\
=(1,504),(3,168),(7,72), \\

\Rightarrow(m, n) \\
\quad=(252,251),(85,82),(39,32), \\
(35,27),(32,23),(22,1) .

$$

Therefore, there are 6 pairs of positive integers $(m, n)$ that satisfy the condition.

$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(x)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \sin 2 x-\frac{1+\cos 2 x}{2}-\frac{1}{2} \\
=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \sin 2 x-\frac{1}{2} \cos 2 x-1 \\
=\sin \left(2 x-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)-1

$$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { (1) From }-\frac{\pi}{12} \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{5 \pi}{12} \\
\Rightarrow-\frac{\pi}{3} \leqslant 2 x-\frac{\pi}{6} \leqslant \frac{2 \pi}{3} \\
\Rightarrow-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \leqslant \sin \left(2 x-\frac{\pi}{6}\right) \leqslant 1 \\
\Rightarrow-1-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \leqslant \sin \left(2 x-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)-1 \leqslant 0 .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, the minimum value of $f(x)$ is $-1-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$, and the maximum value is 0.
(2) From $f(C)=\sin \left(2 C-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)-1=0$, we know
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sin \left(2 C-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=1 . \\
\text { Also, } 0<\angle C<\pi \\
\Rightarrow-\frac{\pi}{6}<2 \angle C-\frac{\pi}{6}<\frac{11 \pi}{6} \\
\Rightarrow 2 \angle C-\frac{\pi}{6}=\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow \angle C=\frac{\pi}{3} .
\end{array}
$$

Since vectors $\boldsymbol{\alpha}$ and $\boldsymbol{\beta}$ are collinear, thus, $\sin B=2 \sin A$.
By the Law of Sines, we get
$$
b=2 a \text {. }
$$

By the Law of Cosines, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
c^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}-2 a b \cos \frac{\pi}{3} \\
\Rightarrow a^{2}+b^{2}-a \dot{b}=3 .

Solving equations (1) and (2), we get $a=1, b=2$.

import Mathlib

/- 17. (10 points) Given the function
$$
f(x)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \sin 2 x-\cos ^{2} x-\frac{1}{2}(x \in \mathbf{R}) \text {. }
$$
(1) When $x \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{12}, \frac{5 \pi}{12}\right]$, find the minimum and maximum values of the function $f(x)$;
(2) Let the internal angles $\angle A, \angle B, \angle C$ of $\triangle A B C$ correspond to the sides $a, b, c$ respectively, and $c=\sqrt{3}, f(C)=0$. If the vectors $\boldsymbol{\alpha}=(1, \sin A), \boldsymbol{\beta}=(2, \sin B)$ are collinear, find the values of $a, b$. -/
theorem algebra_324969 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
  (hf : f = Œª x => sqrt 3 / 2 * sin (2 * x) - cos x ^ 2 - 1 / 2) :
  IsLeast {y | ‚àÉ x ‚àà Icc (-œÄ / 12) (5 * œÄ / 12), f x = y} (-1 / 2) ‚àß
  IsGreatest {y | ‚àÉ x ‚àà Icc (-œÄ / 12) (5 * œÄ / 12), f x = y} (sqrt 3 / 2) ‚àß
  (‚àÉ A B C : ‚Ñù, A ‚àà Ioo 0 œÄ ‚àß B ‚àà Ioo 0 œÄ ‚àß C ‚àà Ioo 0 œÄ ‚àß
    A + B + C = œÄ ‚àß c = sqrt 3 ‚àß f C = 0 ‚àß
    ‚àÉ Œ± Œ≤ : ‚Ñù, Œ± > 0 ‚àß Œ≤ > 0 ‚àß Œ± * sin B = Œ≤ * sin A) ‚Üî
  a = 1 ‚àß b = 2 := by

soln_description:
Three, let $x^{2}+p x+q$ be an irrational quadratic trinomial, and $D=p^{2}-4 q$ be its discriminant.
Notice,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(\left|\alpha_{1}\right|+\left|\alpha_{2}\right|\right)^{2} \geqslant\left(\alpha_{1}-\alpha_{2}\right)^{2} \\
=\left(\frac{-p+\sqrt{D}}{2}-\frac{-p-\sqrt{D}}{2}\right)^{2}=D .
\end{array}
$$

By the definition of an irrational quadratic trinomial, we know that $D$ is a non-negative integer, but not a perfect square.
In particular, $D \neq 0,1,4$.
Also, $p^{2}-4 q \equiv p^{2}(\bmod 4)$, so $D \neq 2,3$.
Thus, $D \geqslant 5$.
From equation (1), we get $\left|\alpha_{1}\right|+\left|\alpha_{2}\right| \geqslant \sqrt{5}$.
In fact, the minimum value $\sqrt{5}$ can be achieved.
For example, when $p=1, q=-1$, $x^{2}+x-1$ is an irrational quadratic trinomial, with roots $\alpha_{1,2}=\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{5}}{2}$, at this time,
$$
\left|\alpha_{1}\right|+\left|\alpha_{2}\right|=\left|\frac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right|+\left|\frac{-1-\sqrt{5}}{2}\right|=\sqrt{5} .
$$
informal_statement: Three, (10 points) A quadratic trinomial $x^{2}+p x+q$ with coefficients $p$ and $q$ as integers, and roots as irrational numbers $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}$, is called an irrational quadratic trinomial. Find the minimum value of the sum of the absolute values of the roots for all irrational quadratic trinomials.

    IsLeast {x | ‚àÉ p q : ‚Ñ§, x = |Œ±‚ÇÅ| + |Œ±‚ÇÇ| ‚àß ‚àÉ Œ±‚ÇÅ Œ±‚ÇÇ : ‚Ñù, Œ±‚ÇÅ ‚â† Œ±‚ÇÇ ‚àß Œ±‚ÇÅ^2 + p * Œ±‚ÇÅ + q = 0 ‚àß Œ±‚ÇÇ^2 + p * Œ±‚ÇÇ + q = 0 ‚àß ¬¨(‚àÉ r : ‚Ñö, Œ±‚ÇÅ = r)} (Real.sqrt 5) := by

soln_description:
8. Proof Let the left side of the inequality be $f(x, y, z)$. First, fix $y$, then $f(x, y, z)$ becomes a binary function $g(x, z)=y$. $\frac{x}{(1+5 x)(4 x+3 y)} \cdot \frac{z}{(5 y+6 z)(z+18)}$,

and $\frac{x}{(1+5 x)(4 x+3 y)}=\frac{x}{20 x^{2}+(15 y+4) x+3 y}=\frac{1}{20 x+\frac{3 y}{x}+(15 y+4)}$
$$\leqslant \frac{1}{2 \cdot \sqrt{20 x \cdot \frac{3 y}{x}+(15 y+4)}}=\frac{1}{(\sqrt{15 y}+2)^{2}}$$

Similarly, $\frac{z}{(5 y+6 z)(z+18)} \leqslant \frac{1}{(\sqrt{5 y}+6 \sqrt{3})^{2}}$,
so $g(x, z) \leqslant y \cdot \frac{1}{(\sqrt{15 y}+2)^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{(\sqrt{5 y}+6 \sqrt{3})^{2}}$.
Now the problem is to find the maximum value of $h(y)=y \frac{1}{(\sqrt{15 y}+2)^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{(\sqrt{5 y}+6 \sqrt{3})^{2}}$.
And $h(y)=\left[\frac{\sqrt{y}}{(\sqrt{15 y}+2)(\sqrt{5 y}+6 \sqrt{3})}\right]^{2}=\left[\frac{1}{5 \sqrt{3 y}+\frac{12 \sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{y}}+20 \sqrt{5}}\right]^{2}$
$$\leqslant\left[\frac{1}{2 \cdot \sqrt{5 \sqrt{3} \cdot 12 \sqrt{3}}+20 \sqrt{5}}\right]^{2}=\frac{1}{5120}$$

Equality holds when each mean inequality reaches equality. It is not difficult to solve that equality holds when $x=\frac{3}{5}, y=\frac{12}{5}, z=6$.
informal_statement:
8. (2003 Singapore Olympiad Question) If $x, y, z \in \mathbf{R}^{-}$, prove:
$$\frac{x y z}{(1+5 x)(4 x+3 y)(5 y+6 z)(z+18)} \leqslant \frac{1}{5120}$$

import Mathlib

/- 8. (2003 Singapore Olympiad Question) If $x, y, z \in \mathbf{R}^{-}$, prove:
$$\frac{x y z}{(1+5 x)(4 x+3 y)(5 y+6 z)(z+18)} \leqslant \frac{1}{5120}$$ -/
theorem inequalities_602962 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚â§ 0) (hy : y ‚â§ 0) (hz : z ‚â§ 0) :
    x * y * z / ((1 + 5 * x) * (4 * x + 3 * y) * (5 * y + 6 * z) * (z + 18)) ‚â§ 1 / 5120 := by

Solution. Let $x$ and $y$ be the speeds (m/s) of the trains. According to the first condition, $700=28(x+y)$. According to the second condition of the problem, $\frac{490}{x}-\frac{210}{y}=35$.

In the end, we have: $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x+y=25, \\ \frac{14}{x}-\frac{6}{y}=1\end{array} \Rightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=10, \\ y=15 .\end{array}\right.\right.$

Answer: 36 km $/$ h, 54 km $/ h$.
informal_statement: 13.419 Two trains, 490 m and 210 m long, are moving towards each other at a constant speed on parallel tracks. The driver of one of them noticed the oncoming train at a distance of $700 \mathrm{~m}$; after this, the trains met after 28 s. Determine the speed of each train, given that the first train takes 35 s longer to pass a signal light than the second.

import Mathlib

/- 13.419 Two trains, 490 m and 210 m long, are moving towards each other at a constant speed on parallel tracks. The driver of one of them noticed the oncoming train at a distance of $700 \mathrm{~m}$; after this, the trains met after 28 s. Determine the speed of each train, given that the first train takes 35 s longer to pass a signal light than the second. -/
theorem algebra_199619 (v1 v2 : ‚Ñù) (h1 : v1 > 0) (h2 : v2 > 0)
    (h3 : 700 / (v1 + v2) = 28) (h4 : 490 / v1 = 35 + 210 / v2) :
    v1 = 36 := by

soln_description:
„ÄêProof„ÄëLet the three roots of the cubic equation
$$
x^{3}-3 x^{2}+1=0
$$

be $\alpha, \beta, a$ (where $\alpha<\beta<0<a$).

Since $f(0)=1>0, f(1)<0, f(2)<0, f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)>0, f(1)0 \text {, }$
$$
-10,
\end{aligned}
$$

and because $\frac{1}{2}0$,
we have
$$
-\alpha0 \quad(n \geqslant 1)$.
Also, since $\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}=(\alpha+\beta)^{2}-2 \alpha \beta$,
and
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \alpha+\beta+a=3, \quad \alpha \beta a=-1, \text { then } \\
& \alpha^{2}+\beta^{2} \\
= & (3-a)^{2}+\frac{2}{a} \\
= & 9+a^{2}-6 a+\frac{2}{a} \\
= & \frac{2\left(-3 a^{2}+1\right)}{a}+9+a^{2} \\
= & \frac{-2 a^{3}}{a}+9+a^{2} \\
= & 9-a^{2} \\
= & 1+\left(8-a^{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

From $a>2 \sqrt{2}$ we know $8-a^{2}<0$,
so $\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}<1$.
When $n \geqslant 2$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \alpha^{n}+\beta^{n}-\left(\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}\right) \\
= & \alpha^{2}\left(\alpha^{n-2}-1\right)+\beta^{2}\left(\beta^{n-2}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
$\leqslant 0$.
Therefore, $\alpha^{n}+\beta^{n} \leqslant \alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}<1$.
Thus, $0<\alpha^{n}+\beta^{n}<1$.
For all positive integers $n$, we define
$$
u_{n}=\alpha^{n}+\beta^{n}+a^{n} \text {. }
$$

It is easy to find
$$
\begin{array}{c}
\text { It is easy to find } \\
u_{0}=\alpha^{0}+\beta^{0}+a^{0}=3, \\
u_{1}=\alpha+\beta+a=3, \\
u_{2}=\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}+a^{2}=9-a^{2}+a^{2}=9 . \\
u_{n+3}-3 u_{n+2}+u_{n} \\
=\alpha^{n+3}-3 \alpha^{n+2}+\alpha^{n}+\beta^{n+3}-3 \beta^{n+2}+\beta^{n}+a^{n+3}-3 a^{n+2}+a^{n} \\
=\alpha^{n}\left(\alpha^{3}-3 \alpha^{2}+1\right)+\beta^{n}\left(\beta^{3}-3 \beta^{2}+1\right)+a^{n}\left(a^{3}-3 a^{2}+1\right) \\
=0 . \\
\text { Therefore } \\
u_{n+3}-3 u_{n+2}+u_{n}=0, \\
u_{n+3}=3 u_{n+2}-u_{n} .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore,
by mathematical induction, $u_{n}$ is an integer.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Also, } \quad a^{n}=\alpha^{n}+\beta^{n}+a^{n}-\left(\alpha^{n}+\beta^{n}\right) \\
=u_{n}-\left(\alpha^{n}+\beta^{n}\right) \text {. } \\
\end{array}
$$

Since $0<\alpha^{n}+\beta^{n}<1$, then
$$
\left[a^{n}\right]=u_{n}-1 .
$$

The problem reduces to proving that $u_{1788}-1$ and $u_{1988}-1$ are divisible by 17. From the recurrence relation
$$
u_{n+3}=3 u_{n+2}-u_{n},
$$

we can sequentially find the values of $u_{i}$ modulo 17.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
u_{0} \equiv 3, \quad u_{1} \equiv 3, \quad u_{2} \equiv 9, \quad u_{3} \equiv 7, \quad u_{4} \equiv 1, \\
u_{5} \equiv 11, \quad u_{6} \equiv 9, \quad u_{7} \equiv 9, \quad u_{8} \equiv 16, \quad u_{9} \equiv 5, \\
u_{10} \equiv 6, \quad u_{11} \equiv 2, \quad u_{12} \equiv 1, \quad u_{13} \equiv 14, u_{14} \equiv 6, \\
u_{15} \equiv 0, \quad u_{16} \equiv 3, \quad u_{17} \equiv 3, \quad u_{18} \equiv 9, \quad u_{19} \equiv 7, \\
u_{20} \equiv 1 \text {. } \\
\end{array}
$$

From the above, we know
$$
u_{16} \equiv u_{0}, u_{17} \equiv u_{1}, u_{18} \equiv u_{2}, u_{19} \equiv u_{3} .
$$

We can prove by mathematical induction that:
For all non-negative integers $n$,
$$
u_{n+16} \equiv u_{n} \quad(\bmod 17) .
$$

For $n=0,1,2$ it is clearly true.
Assume $u_{k+16} \equiv u_{k}, u_{k+14} \equiv u_{k-2},(\bmod 17)$, then
$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{k+17} & =3 u_{k+16}-u_{k+14} \\
& \equiv 3 u_{k}-u_{k-2}
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\equiv u_{k+1} \quad(\bmod 17) \text {. }
$$

Thus, $u_{k+17} \equiv u_{k+1} \quad(\bmod 17)$.
Therefore, $u_{n+16} \equiv u_{n} \quad(\bmod 17)$.
Since $1788=16 \cdot 111+12$,
$$
1988=16 \cdot 124+4 \text {, }
$$

we have $u_{1788} \equiv u_{12} \equiv 1(\bmod 17)$,
$$
u_{1988} \equiv u_{4} \equiv 1 \quad(\bmod 17) .
$$

Thus, $u_{1788}-1 \equiv 0 \quad(\bmod 17)$,
$u_{1988}-1 \equiv 0 \quad(\bmod 17)$.

Therefore, $\left[a^{1788}\right]$ and $\left[a^{1988}\right]$ are both divisible by 17.
informal_statement:
$2 \cdot 50$ Let $a$ be the largest positive root of the equation $x^{3}-3 x^{2}+1=0$. Prove that $\left[a^{1788}\right]$ and [ $a^{1988}$ ] are both divisible by 17 (the notation $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer not exceeding $x$).
Ôºà29th International Mathematical Olympiad Preliminary Question, 1988Ôºâ

/- $2 \cdot 50$ Let $a$ be the largest positive root of the equation $x^{3}-3 x^{2}+1=0$. Prove that $\left[a^{1788}\right]$ and [ $a^{1988}$ ] are both divisible by 17 (the notation $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer not exceeding $x$).

soln_description:
Answer: 45.

Solution. Let the line $A D$ intersect the line $C F$ at point $G$, as shown in the figure below. Since $A B C G$ and $D E F G$ are rectangles, we have $A B=C G, B C=A G, E F=D G$ and $D E=F G$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_c47c8a04f76ef67ab4e5g-17.jpg?height=252&width=301&top_left_y=96&top_left_x=576)

The second worker works 1.2 times faster than the first, and the working time was the same, so the second worker laid 1.2 times more asphalt than the first. Let the first worker lay $x=A B+B C$ asphalt on the section $A-B-C$, then the second worker on the section $A-D-E-F-C$ laid

$$
\begin{aligned}
1.2 x & =A D+D E+E F+F G+G C=(A D+E F+C G)+(D E+F G)= \\
& =(B C+A B)+(D E+D E)=x+2 D E
\end{aligned}
$$

From this, we find that $D E=0.1 x$, which is 12 times less than the total amount of asphalt on the second section. Therefore, the second worker spent 12 times less time on the section $D E$ than on his entire path. He worked a total of $9 \cdot 60=540$ minutes, so he spent $\frac{540}{12}=45$ minutes on $D E$.
informal_statement:
Problem 6.5. In the park, paths are laid out as shown in the figure. Two workers started to asphalt them, starting simultaneously from point $A$. They lay asphalt at constant speeds: the first on the section $A-B-C$, the second on the section $A-D-E-F-C$. In the end, they finished the work simultaneously, spending 9 hours on it. It is known that the second works 1.2 times faster than the first. How many minutes did the second spend laying asphalt on the section $D E$?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_c47c8a04f76ef67ab4e5g-16.jpg?height=259&width=299&top_left_y=1340&top_left_x=577)
