soln_description:
[Proof] Let $k, m \in \mathbb{N}, k \geqslant 2$, then
$$\begin{aligned}
\left|a_{k m}-k a_{m}\right| & =\left|\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\left(a_{(i+1) m}-a_{i m}-a_{m}\right)\right| \\
& \leqslant \sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\left|a_{(i+1) m}-a_{i m}-a_{m}\right|
\end{aligned}$$

By the assumption, we have
$$\left|a_{k m}-k a_{m}\right| \leqslant k-1$$

Clearly, when $k=1$, (1) also holds, so for any $k, m \in \mathbb{N}$, (1) holds.
For any $p, q \in \mathbb{N}$, by (1) we get
$$\begin{array}{l}
\left|a_{p q}-p a_{q}\right| \leqslant p-1 \\
\left|a_{p q}-q a_{p}\right| \leqslant q-1
\end{array}$$

Thus, 
$$\left\lvert\, \begin{array}{l}\left.\frac{a_{p q}}{p q}-\frac{a_{q}}{q} \right\rvert\, \leqslant \frac{p-1}{p q}<\frac{1}{q}, \\ \left|\frac{a_{p}}{p}-\frac{a_{p q}}{p q}\right| \leqslant \frac{q-1}{p q}<\frac{1}{p} .\end{array}\right.$$
From this, we immediately get $\square$
$$\left|\frac{a_{p}}{p}-\frac{a_{q}}{q}\right| \leqslant\left|\frac{a_{p}}{p}-\frac{a_{p q}}{p q}\right|+\left|\frac{a_{p q}}{p q}-\frac{a_{q}}{q}\right|<\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q} .$$
informal_statement:
8-175 Let the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$\left|a_{k+m}-a_{k}-a_{m}\right| \leqslant 1$, for any $k, m \in N$. Prove: For any $p, q \in N$,
$$\left|\frac{a_{p}}{p}-\frac{a_{q}}{q}\right|<\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q} .$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8-175 Let the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$\left|a_{k+m}-a_{k}-a_{m}\right| \leqslant 1$, for any $k, m \in N$. Prove: For any $p, q \in N$,
$$\left|\frac{a_{p}}{p}-\frac{a_{q}}{q}\right|<\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q} .$$ -/
theorem inequalities_603737
    (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (h : ‚àÄ k m, |a (k + m) - a k - a m| ‚â§ 1)
    (p q : ‚Ñï) (hp : 0 < p) (hq : 0 < q) :
    |(a p) / p - (a q) / q| < 1 / p + 1 / q := by

soln_description: If any of a, b, c are zero then a 2 + b 2 + c 2 ‚â• 0 = abc. So assume they are all positive. Suppose that a 2 + b 2 + c 2  a + b + c. But (a 2 + b 2 )/2 ‚â• ab (AM/GM), and similarly (b 2 + c 2 )/2 ‚â• bc and (c 2 + a 2 )/2 ‚â• ca. Adding, a 2 + b 2 + c 2 ‚â• ab + bc + ca. Hence a + b + c ‚â• abc > a 2 + b 2 + c 2 ‚â• ab + bc + ca > a + b + c. Contradiction. 10th Irish 1997 ¬© John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 17 Dec 2003 Last updated/corrected 17 Dec 03
informal_statement: 10th Irish 1997 Problem A4 a, b, c are non-negative reals such that a + b + c ‚â• abc. Show that a 2 + b 2 + c 2 ‚â• abc.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Ring
import Mathlib.Tactic

/- 10th Irish 1997 Problem A4 a, b, c are non-negative reals such that a + b + c ‚â• abc. Show that a 2 + b 2 + c 2 ‚â• abc. -/
theorem inequalities_140167 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 ‚â§ a) (hb : 0 ‚â§ b) (hc : 0 ‚â§ c)
  (h : a * b * c ‚â§ a + b + c) : a * a + b * b + c * c ‚â• a * b * c :=
formal_proof:
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Ring
import Mathlib.Tactic

theorem inequalities_140167 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 ‚â§ a) (hb : 0 ‚â§ b) (hc : 0 ‚â§ c)
  (h : a * b * c ‚â§ a + b + c) : a * a + b * b + c * c ‚â• a * b * c := by
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (c - a),
          sq_nonneg (a - 1), sq_nonneg (b - 1), sq_nonneg (c - 1),
          mul_nonneg ha hb, mul_nonneg ha hc, mul_nonneg hb hc
      ]

informal_statement: If $\left| a \right|=3$, $\left| b \right|=5$, then the absolute value of $\left| a+b \right|-\left| a-b \right|$ is ___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $\left| a \right|=3$, $\left| b \right|=5$, then the absolute value of $\left| a+b \right|-\left| a-b \right|$ is ___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___ . -/
theorem algebra_2161 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : |a| = 3) (hb : |b| = 5) :
|(|a + b| -  |a - b|)| = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_2161 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : |a| = 3) (hb : |b| = 5) :
|(|a + b| -  |a - b|)| = 6 := by 
  cases' eq_or_eq_neg_of_abs_eq ha with ha1 ha2
  ¬∑ -- Case $a = 3$
    cases' eq_or_eq_neg_of_abs_eq hb with hb1 hb2
    ¬∑ -- Case $b = 5$
      rw [ha1, hb1]
      norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
      all_goals norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
    ¬∑ -- Case $b = -5$
      rw [ha1, hb2]
      norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
      all_goals norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
  ¬∑ -- Case $a = -3$
    cases' eq_or_eq_neg_of_abs_eq hb with hb1 hb2
    ¬∑ -- Case $b = 5$
      rw [ha2, hb1]
      norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
      all_goals norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
    ¬∑ -- Case $b = -5$
      rw [ha2, hb2]
      norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
      all_goals norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
  all_goals norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
  all_goals norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]

soln_description:
14. (1) According to the problem, $S_{n}=\frac{3 n+1}{2}-\frac{n}{2} a_{n}\left(a_{n}>0\right)$.

When $n=1$, $S_{1}=\frac{3+1}{2}-\frac{1}{2} a_{1}=a_{1}$, solving gives $a_{1}=\frac{4}{3}$.

When $n=2$, $S_{2}=\frac{6+1}{2}-\frac{2}{2} a_{2}=a_{1}+a_{2}$, solving gives $a_{2}=\frac{13}{12}$.

When $n=3$, $S_{3}=\frac{9+1}{2}-\frac{3}{2} a_{3}=a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}$, solving gives $a_{3}=\frac{31}{30}$.
Thus, the first three terms of the sequence are $\frac{4}{3}, \frac{13}{12}, \frac{31}{30}$.
(2) According to the problem,
$$
S_{n}=\frac{3 n+1}{2}-\frac{n}{2} a_{n}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}\right) \text {. }
$$

From this, we get $S_{n+1}=\frac{3 n+4}{2}-\frac{n+1}{2} a_{n+1}$.
Therefore, $a_{n+1}=S_{n+1}-S_{n}$
$$
=\frac{3}{2}+\frac{n}{2} a_{n}-\frac{n+1}{2} a_{n+1} \text {. }
$$

Rearranging gives $\frac{(n+3)}{2}\left(a_{n+1}-1\right)=\frac{n}{2}\left(a_{n}-1\right)$.
Thus, $\frac{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)}{2}\left(a_{n+1}-1\right)$
$=\frac{(n+2)(n+1) n}{2}\left(a_{n}-1\right)$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=\cdots \\
=\frac{(1+2)(1+1) \times 1}{2}\left(a_{1}-1\right)=1 .
\end{array}
$$

Then, $a_{n}=1+\frac{2}{n(n+1)(n+2)}$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { (3) Clearly, } b_{n}=\frac{n(n+1)(n+2)}{2} \\
=\frac{n(n+1)(n+2)(n+3)}{8}- \\
\frac{(n-1) n(n+1)(n+2)}{8} .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $S_{n}^{\prime}=\frac{n(n+1)(n+2)(n+3)}{8}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 14. Let $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ be a sequence of positive numbers, with the sum of its first $n$ terms being $S_{n}$, and for all natural numbers $n$, we have
$$
S_{n}=\frac{3 n+1}{2}-\frac{n}{2} a_{n} \text {. }
$$
(1) Write down the first three terms of the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$;
(2) Find the general term formula for the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ (include the derivation process);
(3) Let $b_{n}=\frac{1}{a_{n}-1}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}\right)$, find the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$. -/
theorem algebra_296908 {a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (ha : ‚àÄ n, 0 < a n)
    (hsum : ‚àÄ n, ‚àë i in Finset.range n, a i = (3 * n + 1) / 2 - (n / 2) * a n) :
    a 0 = 1 ‚àß a 1 = 2 ‚àß a 2 = 3 ‚àß
    (‚àÄ n, a n = n + 1) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ n, ‚àë i in Finset.range n, (1 / (a i - 1)) = n * (n + 1) * (n + 2) * (n + 3) / 8) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_296908 {a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (ha : ‚àÄ n, 0 < a n)
    (hsum : ‚àÄ n, ‚àë i in Finset.range n, a i = (3 * n + 1) / 2 - (n / 2) * a n) :
    a 0 = 1 ‚àß a 1 = 2 ‚àß a 2 = 3 ‚àß
    (‚àÄ n, a n = n + 1) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ n, ‚àë i in Finset.range n, (1 / (a i - 1)) = n * (n + 1) * (n + 2) * (n + 3) / 8) := by 
  have h0 := hsum 0 
  simp at h0 
  all_goals linarith [ha 0, ha 1, ha 2]

informal_statement:
Let $n < 2^8$ be a number represented in binary with 8 digits, each being 0 or 1. Define the [i]shift-product[/i] of $n$ as the product of $n$ with its 7 binary rotations. For example, the shift-product of 10010100 is

$10010100 \times 01001010 \times 00100101 \times 10010010 \times 01001001 \times 10100100 \times 01010010 \times 00101001 = 1000011101011100010101110111101000110010001010000000 = 2381290789872256$ in base 10.

Find the sum of all $n$ such that its shift-product ends in a 0 when expressed in base 10.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def bin (n : ‚Ñï) := Nat.digits 2 n

def shiftProduct (n : ‚Ñï) : ‚Ñï :=
  let b := bin n
  let shift := fun i => Nat.ofDigits 2 ((b ++ b) ++ List.replicate (i + 1) 0)
  List.prod {shift 0, shift 1, shift 2, shift 3, shift 4, shift 5, shift 6, shift 7}

/- Let $n < 2^8$ be a number represented in binary with 8 digits, each being 0 or 1. Define the [i]shift-product[/i] of $n$ as the product of $n$ with its 7 binary rotations. For example, the shift-product of 10010100 is

$10010100 \times 01001010 \times 00100101 \times 10010010 \times 01001001 \times 10100100 \times 01010010 \times 00101001 = 1000011101011100010101110111101000110010001010000000 = 2381290789872256$ in base 10.

Find the sum of all $n$ such that its shift-product ends in a 0 when expressed in base 10. -/
theorem number_theory_3178 :
  ‚àë·∂† n ‚àà {n | n < 2 ^ 8 ‚àß (shiftProduct n) % 10 = 0}, n = 4080 := by

soln_description:
According to AM-QM, the left-hand side is at most equal to

$$
3 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{(7 x+3)+(7 y+3)+(7 z+3)}{3}}=3 \cdot \sqrt{16 / 3}=4 \sqrt{3}<7
$$
informal_statement:
1a. The positive real numbers $x, y$ and $z$ have a sum of 1. Show that

$$
\sqrt{7 x+3}+\sqrt{7 y+3}+\sqrt{7 z+3} \leq 7
$$

Can the number 7 on the right-hand side be replaced by a smaller number?

## Solution
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 1a. The positive real numbers $x, y$ and $z$ have a sum of 1. Show that

$$
\sqrt{7 x+3}+\sqrt{7 y+3}+\sqrt{7 z+3} \leq 7
$$

Can the number 7 on the right-hand side be replaced by a smaller number?

## Solution -/
theorem inequalities_263109 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (hsum : x + y + z = 1) :
    sqrt (7 * x + 3) + sqrt (7 * y + 3) + sqrt (7 * z + 3) ‚â§ 7 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem inequalities_263109 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (hsum : x + y + z = 1) :
    sqrt (7 * x + 3) + sqrt (7 * y + 3) + sqrt (7 * z + 3) ‚â§ 7 := by

  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (sqrt (7 * x + 3) - sqrt (7 * y + 3)), 
          sq_nonneg (sqrt (7 * y + 3) - sqrt (7 * z + 3)), 
          sq_nonneg (sqrt (7 * x + 3) - sqrt (7 * z + 3)), 
          Real.sq_sqrt (show (7 * x + 3 : ‚Ñù) ‚â• 0 by nlinarith), 
          Real.sq_sqrt (show (7 * y + 3 : ‚Ñù) ‚â• 0 by nlinarith), 
          Real.sq_sqrt (show (7 * z + 3 : ‚Ñù) ‚â• 0 by nlinarith), 
          Real.sqrt_nonneg (7 * x + 3), 
          Real.sqrt_nonneg (7 * y + 3), 
          Real.sqrt_nonneg (7 * z + 3), 
          hsum, 
          mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg (7 * x + 3)) (Real.sqrt_nonneg (7 * y + 3)), 
          mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg (7 * y + 3)) (Real.sqrt_nonneg (7 * z + 3)), 
          mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg (7 * x + 3)) (Real.sqrt_nonneg (7 * z + 3))
]

soln_description:
## Solution

The idea is to split the inequality in two, showing that

$$
\left(\sqrt{\frac{x}{y}}+\sqrt{\frac{y}{z}}+\sqrt{\frac{z}{x}}\right)^{2}
$$

can be intercalated between the left-hand side and the right-hand side. Indeed, using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality one has

$$
(x+y+z)\left(\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}\right) \geq\left(\sqrt{\frac{x}{y}}+\sqrt{\frac{y}{z}}+\sqrt{\frac{z}{x}}\right)^{2}
$$

On the other hand, as

$$
\sqrt{\frac{x}{y}} \geq \frac{2 x}{x y+1} \Leftrightarrow(\sqrt{x y}-1)^{2} \geq 0
$$

by summation one has

$$
\sqrt{\frac{x}{y}}+\sqrt{\frac{y}{z}}+\sqrt{\frac{z}{x}} \geq \frac{2 x}{x y+1}+\frac{2 y}{y z+1}+\frac{2 z}{z x+1}
$$

The rest is obvious.
informal_statement:
A8 Show that

$$
(x+y+z)\left(\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}\right) \geq 4\left(\frac{x}{x y+1}+\frac{y}{y z+1}+\frac{z}{z x+1}\right)^{2}
$$

for any real positive numbers $x, y$ and $z$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 
A8 Show that

$$
(x+y+z)\left(\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}\right) \geq 4\left(\frac{x}{x y+1}+\frac{y}{y z+1}+\frac{z}{z x+1}\right)^{2}
$$

for any real positive numbers $x, y$ and $z$.

 -/
theorem inequalities_108415 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z) :
    (x + y + z) * (1 / x + 1 / y + 1 / z) ‚â• 4 * (x / (x * y + 1) + y / (y * z + 1) + z / (z * x + 1)) ^ 2 := by

soln_description:
1. **Substitute variables**: Let \( z = 6 - a \), \( y = z - b \), and \( x = y - c \) where \( a, b, c > 0 \). This implies:
   \[
   y = 6 - a - b \quad \text{and} \quad x = 6 - a - b - c
   \]

2. **Rewrite inequalities**: The given system of inequalities is:
   \[
   \frac{1}{y - x} + \frac{1}{z - y} \leq 2
   \]
   \[
   \frac{1}{6 - z} + 2 \leq x
   \]

   Substituting the expressions for \( x \), \( y \), and \( z \):
   \[
   \frac{1}{(6 - a - b) - (6 - a - b - c)} + \frac{1}{(6 - a) - (6 - a - b)} \leq 2
   \]
   \[
   \frac{1}{6 - (6 - a)} + 2 \leq 6 - a - b - c
   \]

3. **Simplify the inequalities**:
   \[
   \frac{1}{c} + \frac{1}{b} \leq 2
   \]
   \[
   \frac{1}{a} + 2 \leq 6 - a - b - c
   \]

4. **Analyze the first inequality**:
   \[
   \frac{1}{c} + \frac{1}{b} \leq 2
   \]
   By the AM-HM inequality (Arithmetic Mean-Harmonic Mean inequality), we have:
   \[
   \frac{b + c}{2} \geq \frac{2bc}{b + c}
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   (b + c) \left( \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} \right) \geq 4
   \]
   Given \(\frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} \leq 2\), we have:
   \[
   (b + c) \cdot 2 \geq 4 \implies b + c \geq 2
   \]

5. **Analyze the second inequality**:
   \[
   \frac{1}{a} + 2 \leq 6 - a - b - c
   \]
   Rearrange to:
   \[
   \frac{1}{a} + a + b + c \leq 4
   \]
   By the AM-HM inequality, we know:
   \[
   \frac{1}{a} + a \geq 2
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   2 + b + c \leq 4 \implies b + c \leq 2
   \]

6. **Combine results**: From steps 4 and 5, we have:
   \[
   b + c \geq 2 \quad \text{and} \quad b + c \leq 2
   \]
   Thus:
   \[
   b + c = 2
   \]

7. **Equality conditions**: Since \(\frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} \leq 2\) and \(b + c = 2\), equality must hold in the AM-HM inequality, implying:
   \[
   b = c = 1
   \]

8. **Solve for \(a\)**: From \(\frac{1}{a} + a \geq 2\), equality holds when \(a = 1\).

9. **Determine \(x, y, z\)**:
   \[
   z = 6 - a = 6 - 1 = 5
   \]
   \[
   y = z - b = 5 - 1 = 4
   \]
   \[
   x = y - c = 4 - 1 = 3
   \]

Conclusion:
\[
(x, y, z) = (3, 4, 5)
\]

The final answer is \(\boxed{(3, 4, 5)}\).
informal_statement:
Let $x$, $y$, and $z$ be real numbers such that $x<y<z<6$. Solve the system of inequalities:
\[\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
\dfrac{1}{y-x}+\dfrac{1}{z-y}\le 2 \\
\dfrac{1}{6-z}+2\le x \\
\end{array}\right.\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $x$, $y$, and $z$ be real numbers such that $x<y<z<6$. Solve the system of inequalities:
\[\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
\dfrac{1}{y-x}+\dfrac{1}{z-y}\le 2 \\
\dfrac{1}{6-z}+2\le x \\
\end{array}\right.\] -/
theorem inequalities_61883 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : x < y) (hy : y < z) (hz : z < 6)
    (h1 : 1 / (y - x) + 1 / (z - y) ‚â§ 2) (h2 : 1 / (6 - z) + 2 ‚â§ x) :
    x = 3 ‚àß y = 4 ‚àß z = 5 := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

The product of all elements of the given set is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P & =2 \cdot 4 \cdot 6 \cdot 8 \cdot 10 \cdot 12 \cdot 14 \cdot 16 \\
& =2 \cdot 2^{2} \cdot(2 \cdot 3) \cdot 2^{3} \cdot(2 \cdot 5) \cdot\left(2^{2} \cdot 3\right) \cdot(2 \cdot 7) \cdot 2^{4} \\
& =2^{15} \cdot 3^{2} \cdot 5 \cdot 7
\end{aligned}
$$

The product is divisible by 5, but not by $5^{2}$, so it is clear that the number 10 needs to be removed.

The product is divisible by 7, but not by $7^{2}$, so it is clear that the number 14 also needs to be removed.

The product of the remaining numbers, $2^{13} \cdot 3^{2}$, is not a perfect square, so at least one more number needs to be removed. We see that it is sufficient to remove an odd power of 2, i.e., the number 2 or the number 8.

It is necessary to remove at least three numbers.

## Note.

It is not necessary for the student to list all possible ways to remove three elements, but it is necessary to show that it is not possible to remove only one or two numbers and for the product of the remaining to be a perfect square. The possible ways to remove three numbers are: $\{\mathscr{Z ,} 4,6,8,10,12,14,16\}$ and $\{2,4,6,8,10,12,14,16\}$.
informal_statement:
Task A-1.5. (4 points)

How many elements at least need to be removed from the set $\{2,4,6,8,10,12,14,16\}$ so that the product of the remaining elements is a square of a natural number?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Task A-1.5. (4 points)

How many elements at least need to be removed from the set $\{2,4,6,8,10,12,14,16\}$ so that the product of the remaining elements is a square of a natural number? -/
theorem number_theory_207676 (S : Finset ‚Ñï) (hS : S ‚äÜ {2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16}) :
    IsLeast {k | ‚àÉ T ‚äÜ S, T.card = k ‚àß ‚àÉ n : ‚Ñï, (T.prod id) = n^2} 3 := by

soln_description:
The given expression can also be written as:

$$
(100+99)(100-99)+(98+97)(98-97)+\ldots(2+1)(2-1)
$$

or

$$
100+99+98+97+\ldots+2+1
$$

The sum of this arithmetic series is

$$
50(1+100)=5050
$$

(Vilmos Erd√∂s, Budapest.)

Number of solutions: 54.
informal_statement:
Let's determine the value of the following expression:

$$
100^{2}-99^{2}+98^{2}-97^{2}+\ldots+2^{2}-1^{2}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let's determine the value of the following expression:

$$
100^{2}-99^{2}+98^{2}-97^{2}+\ldots+2^{2}-1^{2}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_277491 : ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 100, (100 - i)^2 - (100 - i - 1)^2 = 5050 := by

soln_description:
Answer: 1000 kg

Solution. All dimensions of the body are 10 times larger compared to the model. Therefore, the volume of the body is larger by $10 \cdot 10 \cdot 10=1000$ times. Mass is directly proportional to volume, therefore, the mass of the body:

$$
m_{\text {body }}=1000 m_{\text {model }}=1000 \text { kg. }
$$

Preliminary Stage

6th grade

2018-2019

Variant 2

Tasks, answers, and evaluation criteria
informal_statement: 6. (20 points) A one-kilogram model of a sports car body was made from aluminum at a scale of 1:10. What is the mass of the actual body if it is also entirely made of aluminum?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. (20 points) A one-kilogram model of a sports car body was made from aluminum at a scale of 1:10. What is the mass of the actual body if it is also entirely made of aluminum? -/
theorem algebra_176564 {m : ‚Ñù} (hm : m > 0) (h : (1 / 10) ^ 3 * m = 1) :
    m = 1000 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_176564 {m : ‚Ñù} (hm : m > 0) (h : (1 / 10) ^ 3 * m = 1) :
    m = 1000 := by
  linarith

soln_description: 5. $\mathrm{D}$ Hint: The original inequality is equivalent to $\left(x+\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right)\left(x+\frac{x^{2}}{2}+2\right)<0$, which is $x(x+2)\left[(x+1)^{2}+3\right]<0$.
informal_statement:
5. The solution set of the inequality $\left|1+x+\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right|<1$ is
A. $\{x \mid-1<x<1\}$
B. $\left\{x \left\lvert\,-\frac{3}{2}<x<0\right.\right\}$
C. $\left\{x \left\lvert\,-\frac{5}{4}<x<0\right.\right\}$
D. $\{x \mid-2<x<0\}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 5. The solution set of the inequality $\left|1+x+\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right|<1$ is
A. $\{x \mid-1<x<1\}$
B. $\left\{x \left\lvert\,-\frac{3}{2}<x<0\right.\right\}$
C. $\left\{x \left\lvert\,-\frac{5}{4}<x<0\right.\right\}$
D. $\{x \mid-2<x<0\}$ -/
theorem inequalities_218552 :
  {x : ‚Ñù | abs (1 + x + x^2 / 2) < 1} = {x | -2 < x ‚àß x < 0} := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem inequalities_218552 :
  {x : ‚Ñù | abs (1 + x + x^2 / 2) < 1} = {x | -2 < x ‚àß x < 0} := by
    ext x
    simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq, Set.mem_setOf_eq]
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- First, we'll prove that if |1 + x + x^2/2| < 1, then -2 < x < 0.
      intro h
      have h1 : -1 < (1 + x + x^2 / 2) := by linarith [abs_lt.mp h]
      have h2 : (1 + x + x^2 / 2) < 1 := by linarith [abs_lt.mp h]
      constructor
      ¬∑ -- Show that -2 < x
        nlinarith
      ¬∑ -- Show that x < 0
        nlinarith
    ¬∑ -- Now prove the reverse: if -2 < x < 0, then |1 + x + x^2/2| < 1
      rintro ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü©
      have h3 : (1 + x + x^2 / 2) < 1 := by
        nlinarith
      have h4 : -1 < (1 + x + x^2 / 2) := by
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x + 1)]
      apply abs_lt.mpr
      constructor <;> linarith

soln_description:
We notice that $1=1^{2}$. Then, according to the poor student's inequality,

$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b} \geqslant \frac{(1+1)^{2}}{a+b}=\frac{4}{a+b}
$$
informal_statement: Let $a, b$ be two strictly positive real numbers. Show that $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b} \geqslant \frac{4}{a+b}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a, b$ be two strictly positive real numbers. Show that $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b} \geqslant \frac{4}{a+b}$ -/
theorem inequalities_110699 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    1 / a + 1 / b ‚â• 4 / (a + b) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_110699 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    1 / a + 1 / b ‚â• 4 / (a + b) := by
  have h1 : 0 < a * b := mul_pos ha hb
  have h2 : 0 < a + b := add_pos ha hb

  have h3 : (a + b) ^ 2 ‚â• 4 * a * b := by
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b)]

  have h4 : (1 / a + 1 / b) - (4 / (a + b)) ‚â• 0 := by
    have h5 : (1 / a + 1 / b) - (4 / (a + b)) = ((a + b) ^ 2 - 4 * a * b) / (a * b * (a + b)) := by
      field_simp [ha.ne.symm, hb.ne.symm, show a + b ‚â† 0 by linarith]
      ring
    rw [h5]
    apply div_nonneg
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b)]
    positivity

  linarith

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
|x|^{3}-2 x^{2}-4|x|+3=(|x|-3)\left(x^{2}+|x|-1\right) \\
=(|x|-3)\left(|x|-\frac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right)\left(|x|+\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right)<0 \Rightarrow \frac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{2}<|x|<3 \\
\Rightarrow x \in\left(-3, \frac{1-\sqrt{5}}{2}\right) \cup\left(\frac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{2}, 3\right) .
\end{array}
$$

The solution is as follows:

$$
\begin{array}{l}
|x|^{3}-2 x^{2}-4|x|+3=(|x|-3)\left(x^{2}+|x|-1\right) \\
=(|x|-3)\left(|x|-\frac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right)\left(|x|+\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right)<0 \Rightarrow \frac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{2}<|x|<3 \\
\Rightarrow x \in\left(-3, \frac{1-\sqrt{5}}{2}\right) \cup\left(\frac{-1+\sqrt{5}}{2}, 3\right) .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement: 7. The solution set of the inequality $|x|^{3}-2 x^{2}-4|x|+3<0$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 7. The solution set of the inequality $|x|^{3}-2 x^{2}-4|x|+3<0$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem inequalities_281974 (x : ‚Ñù) :
  abs x ^ 3 - 2 * x ^ 2 - 4 * abs x + 3 < 0 ‚Üî
  (x ‚àà Ioo (-3) ((1 - sqrt 5) / 2) ‚à™ Ioo ((-1 + sqrt 5) / 2) 3) := by

soln_description:
4. 1399 .

Solution: Let these 4 digits be $a, b, c, d$. It is easy to see that $p=3, S(x)$ $=a+b+c+d=22$, and from $T(x)=3^{k}$ we know that $a, b, c, d$ are multiples of 3 or 1. It can be verified that 1399 is the smallest integer that satisfies the conditions.
informal_statement: 4. If $x$ is a four-digit integer in decimal notation, let the product of the digits of $x$ be $T(x)$, the sum of the digits be $S(x)$, $p$ be a prime number, and $T(x)=p^{k}, S(x)=p^{p}-5$, then the smallest $x$ is $\qquad$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Nat

def T : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï
| n => (Nat.digits 10 n).prod

def S : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï
| n => (Nat.digits 10 n).sum

/- 4. If $x$ is a four-digit integer in decimal notation, let the product of the digits of $x$ be $T(x)$, the sum of the digits be $S(x)$, $p$ be a prime number, and $T(x)=p^{k}, S(x)=p^{p}-5$, then the smallest $x$ is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem number_theory_150350 {x : ‚Ñï} (hx : x ‚àà Finset.Icc 1000 9999) (p k : ‚Ñï)
    (hp : Nat.Prime p) (hpk : T x = p ^ k ‚àß S x = p ^ p - 5) :
    x = 1399 := by

soln_description: 12. These numbers $442 \cdot 444 \cdot 446=87526608$.
informal_statement: 12. Restore the digits. On the board, there was the product of three consecutive even numbers. During the break, Vasya erased some digits. As a result, on the board remained $87 * * * * * 8$. Help Petya find the missing digits in the product.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 12. Restore the digits. On the board, there was the product of three consecutive even numbers. During the break, Vasya erased some digits. As a result, on the board remained $87 * * * * * 8$. Help Petya find the missing digits in the product. -/
theorem number_theory_194695 (n : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : Even n) (h‚ÇÅ : Even (n + 2)) (h‚ÇÇ : Even (n + 4))
    (h‚ÇÉ : n * (n + 2) * (n + 4) = 87000000 + k) :
    k = 526608 := by

soln_description:
1. **Initial Setup and Conditions:**
   Let $(x, y)$ be a solution such that $x \mid y^2 - 3$, $y \mid x^2 - 2$, and $\gcd\left(3x + \frac{2(y^2 - 3)}{x}, 2y + \frac{3(x^2 - 2)}{y}\right) = k$.
   
   From $y \mid x^2 - 2$, we have $(y, 3) = 1$, and from $x \mid y^2 - 3$, we have $4 \nmid x$.
   
   Letting $g = \gcd(x, y)$, we have $g \mid 2$ and $g \mid 3$, hence $g = 1$.
   
   The gcd condition can be written as:
   \[
   \gcd\left(\frac{3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6}{x}, \frac{3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6}{y}\right) = \frac{3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6}{xy} = k
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   3x^2 + 2y^2 - kxy = 6 \quad \text{(1)}
   \]

2. **Case Analysis:**
   - **Case 1: $k$ is odd.**
     - If $x$ is odd, then $ky = 3x + 2 \times \frac{y^2 - 3}{x}$ is odd, hence $k$ is odd.
     - **Claim:** A pair of positive integers $(x, y)$ such that $3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6 = kxy$ and $2 \nmid x$, $3 \nmid y$ satisfies the conditions of the problem.
     - **Proof:**
       - From $x \mid 2y^2 - 6$ and $x$ odd, we have $x \mid y^2 - 3$.
       - Similarly, $y \mid x^2 - 2$.
       - Let $g = \gcd(x, y)$. Since $g \mid 6$ and $2 \nmid x$, $3 \nmid y$, we have $g = 1$.
       - Hence, $\gcd\left(\frac{3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6}{x}, \frac{3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6}{y}\right) = \frac{3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6}{xy} = k$.

     - **Pell's Equation:**
       - Rewrite equation (1) as:
         \[
         16y^2 - 8kxy + 24x^2 = 48
         \]
         \[
         (4y - kx)^2 - (k^2 - 24)x^2 = 48
         \]
       - Let $Y = 4y - kx$ and $X = x$, then $d = k^2 - 24$. The equation becomes:
         \[
         Y^2 - dX^2 = 48
         \]
       - There exists a solution $(\alpha, \beta)$ such that $\beta^2 - d\alpha^2 = 1$.
       - Let the original solution be $(X_1, Y_1)$. If $Y_1 > 0$, define:
         \[
         Y_n + \sqrt{d}X_n = (Y_1 + \sqrt{d}X_1)(\beta + \sqrt{d}\alpha)^{n-1}
         \]
       - Recurrence relations:
         \[
         Y_{n+1} = \beta Y_n + d\alpha X_n, \quad X_{n+1} = \alpha Y_n + \beta X_n
         \]
       - Since $Y_1 > 0$, $X_n, Y_n > 0$ and solutions are increasing and distinct.
       - We need $2 \nmid X_n$, $4 \mid Y_n + kX_n$, and $3 \nmid \frac{Y_n + kX_n}{4}$.
       - By a lemma, $(X_n, Y_n)$ cycles modulo $m$ for any positive integer $m$.

     - If $Y_1 < 0$, define:
       \[
       Y_n + \sqrt{d}X_n = (Y_1 + \sqrt{d}X_1)(\beta - \sqrt{d}\alpha)^{n-1}
       \]
       - We have $(-Y_n) + \sqrt{d}X_n = (-Y_1 + \sqrt{d}X_1)(\beta + \sqrt{d}\alpha)^{n-1}$.
       - Since $-Y_1, X_1 > 0$, $X_n > 0, Y_n < 0$ and solutions are distinct.
       - Check $Y_n + kX_n > 0$:
         \[
         Y_n^2 = 48 + dX_n^2 = 48 + (k^2 - 24)X_n^2 < (kX_n)^2 \quad \text{for } X_n > 1
         \]
       - By the lemma, we conclude there are infinitely many solutions.

   - **Case 2: $k$ is even.**
     - If $x \equiv 2 \pmod{4}$ and $(y, 3) = 1$, similar to Case 1:
     - **Claim:** A pair of positive integers $(x, y)$ such that $3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6 = kxy$ and $x \equiv 2 \pmod{4}$, $3 \nmid y$ satisfies the conditions.
     - **Proof:**
       - From $y \mid 3x^2 - 6$ and $(y, 3) = 1$, we have $y \mid x^2 - 2$.
       - From the equation, $\frac{k}{2}xy = 3x(\frac{x}{2}) + y^2 - 3$, hence $x \mid y^2 - 3$.
       - Let $g = \gcd(x, y)$. Since $g \mid 6$ and $2 \nmid x$, $3 \nmid y$, we have $g = 1$.
       - Hence, $\gcd\left(\frac{3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6}{x}, \frac{3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6}{y}\right) = \frac{3x^2 + 2y^2 - 6}{xy} = k$.

     - Proceed similarly to Case 1 to conclude there are infinitely many solutions.

$\blacksquare$
informal_statement:
Positive integer $k(\ge 8)$ is given. Prove that if there exists a pair of positive integers $(x,y)$ that satisfies the conditions below, then there exists infinitely many pairs $(x,y)$.
(1) $ $ $x\mid y^2-3, y\mid x^2-2$
(2) $ $ $gcd\left(3x+\frac{2(y^2-3)}{x},2y+\frac{3(x^2-2)}{y}\right)=k$ $ $
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Positive integer $k(\ge 8)$ is given. Prove that if there exists a pair of positive integers $(x,y)$ that satisfies the conditions below, then there exists infinitely many pairs $(x,y)$.
(1) $ $ $x\mid y^2-3, y\mid x^2-2$
(2) $ $ $gcd\left(3x+\frac{2(y^2-3)}{x},2y+\frac{3(x^2-2)}{y}\right)=k$ $ $ -/
theorem number_theory_48277 (k : ‚Ñï) (hk : 8 ‚â§ k) (h : ‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñï, 0 < x ‚àß 0 < y ‚àß x ‚à£ y ^ 2 - 3 ‚àß y ‚à£ x ^ 2 - 2 ‚àß Nat.gcd (3 * x + 2 * (y ^ 2 - 3) / x) (2 * y + 3 * (x ^ 2 - 2) / y) = k) :
    ‚àÄ n : ‚Ñï, ‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñï, 0 < x ‚àß 0 < y ‚àß x ‚à£ y ^ 2 - 3 ‚àß y ‚à£ x ^ 2 - 2 ‚àß Nat.gcd (3 * x + 2 * (y ^ 2 - 3) / x) (2 * y + 3 * (x ^ 2 - 2) / y) = k ‚àß x > n ‚àß y > n := by

soln_description:
Solution. The parametric equations of the curve $C$ are

$$
x=t, \quad y=-t
$$

or in complex form

$$
z=t-i t
$$

where the real variable $t$ varies from 0 to $\pi$.

Applying formula (2), we get

$$
\int_{C} \mathrm{e}^{\bar{z}} d z=\int_{0}^{\pi} e^{t+i t}(1-i) d t=(1-i) \int_{0}^{\pi} e^{(1+i) t} d t=\left.\frac{1-i}{1+i} e^{(1+i) t}\right|_{0} ^{\pi}=\left(e^{\pi}+1\right) i
$$
informal_statement: Example 3. Compute the integral $\int_{C} e^{\bar{z}} d z$, where $C$ is the line segment $y=-x$, connecting the points $z_{1}=0$ and $z_{2}=\pi-i \pi$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

/- Example 3. Compute the integral $\int_{C} e^{\bar{z}} d z$, where $C$ is the line segment $y=-x$, connecting the points $z_{1}=0$ and $z_{2}=\pi-i \pi$. -/
theorem calculus_146300 (f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) (hf : f = Œª z => exp (z.re - I * z.im)) :
    ‚à´ z in segment ‚Ñù 0 (Real.pi - I * Real.pi), f z = (exp Real.pi + 1) * I := by

informal_statement: $S$ is a subset of the set ${1,2,3,..2023}$, satisfying that the sum of the squares of any two elements is not a multiple of $9$. Then the maximum value of $|S|$ is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___ (here $|S|$ denotes the number of elements in $S$).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $S$ is a subset of the set ${1,2,3,..2023}$, satisfying that the sum of the squares of any two elements is not a multiple of $9$. Then the maximum value of $|S|$ is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___ (here $|S|$ denotes the number of elements in $S$). -/
theorem number_theory_10175 (S : Finset ‚Ñï) (hS : S ‚äÜ Finset.Icc 1 2023)
    (hS' : ‚àÄ x ‚àà S, ‚àÄ y ‚àà S, x ‚â† y ‚Üí ¬¨(9 ‚à£ x^2 + y^2)) :
    S.card ‚â§ 1350 := by

informal_statement: Suppose that $x$ and $y$ are positive real numbers such that $x^3, y^3$ and $x + y$ are all rational numbers. Show that the numbers $xy, x^2+y^2, x$ and $y$ are also rational
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose that $x$ and $y$ are positive real numbers such that $x^3, y^3$ and $x + y$ are all rational numbers. Show that the numbers $xy, x^2+y^2, x$ and $y$ are also rational -/
theorem algebra_66617 (x y : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ q : ‚Ñö, x^3 = q) (h2 : ‚àÉ q : ‚Ñö, y^3 = q) (h3 : ‚àÉ q : ‚Ñö, x + y = q) :
    ‚àÉ q1 q2 q3 q4 : ‚Ñö, x * y = q1 ‚àß x^2 + y^2 = q2 ‚àß x = q3 ‚àß y = q4 := by

soln_description:
1. First, we need to simplify the expression for \( x \):
   \[
   x = \frac{\sqrt{6 + 2\sqrt{5}} + \sqrt{6 - 2\sqrt{5}}}{\sqrt{20}}
   \]

2. We start by simplifying the terms inside the square roots. Notice that:
   \[
   \sqrt{6 + 2\sqrt{5}} = \sqrt{(\sqrt{5} + 1)^2} = \sqrt{5} + 1
   \]
   and
   \[
   \sqrt{6 - 2\sqrt{5}} = \sqrt{(\sqrt{5} - 1)^2} = \sqrt{5} - 1
   \]

3. Substituting these back into the expression for \( x \):
   \[
   x = \frac{(\sqrt{5} + 1) + (\sqrt{5} - 1)}{\sqrt{20}}
   \]

4. Simplify the numerator:
   \[
   x = \frac{2\sqrt{5}}{\sqrt{20}}
   \]

5. Simplify the denominator:
   \[
   \sqrt{20} = \sqrt{4 \cdot 5} = 2\sqrt{5}
   \]

6. Substitute back into the expression for \( x \):
   \[
   x = \frac{2\sqrt{5}}{2\sqrt{5}} = 1
   \]

7. Now, we need to evaluate the expression \( H \):
   \[
   H = (1 + x^5 - x^7)^{2012^{3^{11}}}
   \]

8. Since \( x = 1 \):
   \[
   x^5 = 1^5 = 1 \quad \text{and} \quad x^7 = 1^7 = 1
   \]

9. Substitute these values back into the expression for \( H \):
   \[
   H = (1 + 1 - 1)^{2012^{3^{11}}} = 1^{2012^{3^{11}}}
   \]

10. Any number raised to any power is still 1:
    \[
    1^{2012^{3^{11}}} = 1
    \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{1}\).
informal_statement:
Let $x=\frac{\sqrt{6+2\sqrt5}+\sqrt{6-2\sqrt5}}{\sqrt{20}}$. The value of $$H=(1+x^5-x^7)^{{2012}^{3^{11}}}$$
is
(A)  $1$ (B)  $11$ (C) $21$ (D) $101$ (E) None of the above
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $x=\frac{\sqrt{6+2\sqrt5}+\sqrt{6-2\sqrt5}}{\sqrt{20}}$. The value of $$H=(1+x^5-x^7)^{{2012}^{3^{11}}}$$
is
(A)  $1$ (B)  $11$ (C) $21$ (D) $101$ (E) None of the above -/
theorem algebra_70150 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x = (sqrt (6 + 2 * sqrt 5) + sqrt (6 - 2 * sqrt 5)) / sqrt 20) :
    (1 + x^5 - x^7)^(2012^(3^11)) = 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem algebra_70150 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x = (sqrt (6 + 2 * sqrt 5) + sqrt (6 - 2 * sqrt 5)) / sqrt 20) :
    (1 + x^5 - x^7)^(2012^(3^11)) = 1 := by
  have h1 : sqrt (6 + 2 * sqrt 5) = sqrt 5 + 1 := by
    have h2 : (sqrt 5 + 1) ^ 2 = 6 + 2 * sqrt 5 := by
      nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0 : ‚Ñù) < (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num)]
    rw [‚Üê h2]
    field_simp
    all_goals nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0 : ‚Ñù) < (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num)]
  have h4 : sqrt (6 - 2 * sqrt 5) = sqrt 5 - 1 := by
    have h5 : (sqrt 5 - 1) ^ 2 = 6 - 2 * sqrt 5 := by
      nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0 : ‚Ñù) < (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num)]
    rw [‚Üê h5]
    have : 0 ‚â§ sqrt 5 - 1 := by
      nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg 5, Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num)]
    rw [Real.sqrt_sq (by nlinarith)]
    all_goals nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0 : ‚Ñù) < (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num)]
  have h7 : sqrt 20 = 2 * sqrt 5 := by
    rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
    <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num
  have hx1 : x = 1 := by
    rw [hx]
    rw [h1, h4, h7]
    field_simp
    all_goals nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0 : ‚Ñù) < (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num)]
  rw [hx1]
  norm_num

soln_description:
# Solution and Evaluation Criteria:

When the positive terminal of the power supply is connected to point $A$, the current flows only through resistor $R_{2}$, and in this case: $I_{1}=\frac{\varepsilon}{R_{2}+r}$.

## (3 points)

When the polarity is reversed, the current flows only through resistance $R_{1}$, and:

$I_{2}=\frac{\varepsilon}{R_{1}+r}$

According to the condition: $I_{2}=1.5 I_{1}$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 1.5 I_{1}\left(R_{1}+r\right)=I_{1}\left(R_{2}+r\right) \\
& 1.5(10+r)=30+r \\
& r=30 \text { Ohms. }
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement:
# Problem ‚Ññ 7 (10 points)

In the electrical circuit shown in the diagram, the resistances of the resistors are $R_{1}=10$ Ohms and $R_{2}=30$ Ohms. An ammeter is connected to points A and B in the circuit. When the polarity of the current source is reversed, the ammeter readings change by one and a half times. Determine the internal resistance of the source. Consider the ammeter to be ideal. Assume that the resistance of the diodes in the forward direction is negligible, and in the reverse direction, it is infinitely large.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_7ac9c551b647ccda756fg-7.jpg?height=528&width=859&top_left_y=798&top_left_x=610)

## Answer: 30 Ohms

#
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- # Problem ‚Ññ 7 (10 points)

In the electrical circuit shown in the diagram, the resistances of the resistors are $R_{1}=10$ Ohms and $R_{2}=30$ Ohms. An ammeter is connected to points A and B in the circuit. When the polarity of the current source is reversed, the ammeter readings change by one and a half times. Determine the internal resistance of the source. Consider the ammeter to be ideal. Assume that the resistance of the diodes in the forward direction is negligible, and in the reverse direction, it is infinitely large.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_7ac9c551b647ccda756fg-7.jpg?height=528&width=859&top_left_y=798&top_left_x=610)

## Answer: 30 Ohms

# -/
theorem other_178109 (R1 R2 : ‚Ñù) (hR1 : R1 = 10) (hR2 : R2 = 30)
    (I : ‚Ñù) (hI : I = (V / (R1 + R2))) (hV : V > 0) (hI' : I' = (V / (R1 + R2 + x)))
    (hI'' : I' = 1.5 * I) :
    x = 30 := by

soln_description:
Solution.

$$
\cos ^{-2} 4 \alpha-\operatorname{tg}^{2}(3 \pi+4 \alpha)-2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-\sqrt{3} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2} \pi-2 \alpha\right)=
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} 4 \alpha}-(\operatorname{tg}(3 \pi+4 \alpha))^{2}-2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-\sqrt{3} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2} \pi-2 \alpha\right)= \\
& =\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} 4 \alpha}-\operatorname{tg}^{2} 4 \alpha-2 \cos ^{2} 2 \alpha+\sqrt{3} \sin 2 \alpha= \\
& =\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} 4 \alpha}-\frac{\sin ^{2} 4 \alpha}{\cos ^{2} 4 \alpha}-2 \cos ^{2} \alpha+\sqrt{3} \sin 2 \alpha= \\
& =\frac{1-\sin ^{2} 4 \alpha}{\cos ^{2} 4 \alpha}-2 \cos ^{2} \alpha+\sqrt{3} \sin 2 \alpha=\frac{\cos ^{2} 4 \alpha}{\cos ^{2} 4 \alpha}-2 \cos ^{2} \alpha+\sqrt{3} \sin 2 \alpha= \\
& =1-2 \cos ^{2} \alpha+\sqrt{3} \sin 2 \alpha=-\left(2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-1\right)+\sqrt{3} \sin 2 \alpha= \\
& =\sqrt{3} \sin 2 \alpha-\cos 2 \alpha=2\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \sin 2 \alpha-\frac{1}{2} \cos 2 \alpha\right)= \\
& =2\left(\cos \frac{\pi}{6} \sin 2 \alpha-\sin \frac{\pi}{6} \cos 2 \alpha\right)= \\
& =2\left(\sin 2 \alpha \cos \frac{\pi}{6}-\cos 2 \alpha \sin \frac{\pi}{6}\right)=2 \sin \left(2 \alpha-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: $2 \sin \left(2 \alpha-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)$.
informal_statement: 3.258. $\cos ^{-2} 4 \alpha-\operatorname{tg}^{2}(3 \pi+4 \alpha)-2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-\sqrt{3} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2} \pi-2 \alpha\right)$.

/- 3.258. $\cos ^{-2} 4 \alpha-\operatorname{tg}^{2}(3 \pi+4 \alpha)-2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-\sqrt{3} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2} \pi-2 \alpha\right)$. -/
theorem algebra_162782 (Œ± : ‚Ñù) :
    Real.cos (4 * Œ±) ^ (-2 : ‚Ñ§) - Real.tan (3 * Real.pi + 4 * Œ±) ^ 2 -
    2 * Real.cos Œ± ^ 2 - Real.sqrt 3 * Real.cos (3 * Real.pi / 2 - 2 * Œ±) =
    2 * Real.sin (2 * Œ± - Real.pi / 6) := by

soln_description:
Prove: By eliminating the denominator and rearranging, the inequality is equivalent to
$$a b^{2}+b c^{2}+c a^{2} \leq 2+a b c$$

Without loss of generality, assume $b$ is the second largest number in the set $\{a, b, c\}$, then
$$a(b-a)(b-c) \leq 0 \Leftrightarrow a^{2} b+a b c \geq a b^{2}+c a^{2}$$

Therefore, we only need to prove
$$2 \geq a^{2} b+b c^{2} \Leftrightarrow b\left(a^{2}+c^{2}\right) \leq 2 \Leftrightarrow b\left(3-b^{2}\right) \leq 2 \Leftrightarrow(b-1)^{2}(b+2) \geq 0$$

This is obviously true. The equality holds when $a=b=c=1$ or $a=0, b=1, c=\sqrt{2}$ and their permutations.
informal_statement:

/- 62. Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative real numbers, and satisfy $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=3$, prove:
$$\frac{a}{b+2}+\frac{b}{c+2}+\frac{c}{a+2} \leq 1 \text { (Vasile Cirtoaje) }$$ -/
theorem inequalities_597400
    (a b c : ‚Ñù)
    (ha : 0 ‚â§ a)
    (hb : 0 ‚â§ b)
    (hc : 0 ‚â§ c)
    (h : a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 3) :
    a / (b + 2) + b / (c + 2) + c / (a + 2) ‚â§ 1 := by

soln_description:
1. **Claim: \( f(x) \ge 0 \) for all \( x \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0} \).**

   **Proof:**
   - Consider \( x = 1 \). From condition (i), we have:
     \[
     f(x)f(1) \ge f(x) \implies f(x)(f(1) - 1) \ge 0.
     \]
   - If \( f(x) < 0 \) for some \( x \), then \( f(1) \le 1 \).
   - From condition (i) with \( x = 1 \):
     \[
     f(1)^2 \ge f(1) \implies f(1) \ge 1 \text{ or } f(1) \le 0.
     \]
   - Given \( f(a) = a > 1 \), we have:
     \[
     af(1) \ge a \implies f(1) \ge 1.
     \]
   - Combining \( f(1) \le 1 \) and \( f(1) \ge 1 \), we get \( f(1) = 1 \).
   - By induction, we can show \( f(x) \ge x \) for all \( x \in \mathbb{N} \).

2. **Claim: \( f(x) \neq 0 \) for all \( x \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0} \), which implies \( f(x) > 0 \).**

   **Proof:**
   - Suppose \( f(k) = 0 \) for some \( k \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0} \).
   - For any positive rational \( c \), \( f(ck) = 0 \), implying \( f \equiv 0 \), which contradicts \( f(a) = a \).

3. **Claim: \( f(x) \ge x \) for all \( x \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0} \).**

   **Proof:**
   - We have \( f(1) \ge 1 \), implying \( f(2) \ge 2 \).
   - By induction, \( f(n) \ge n \) for all \( n \in \mathbb{N} \).
   - For \( k = \frac{p}{q} \) where \( p \) and \( q \) are relatively prime positive integers:
     \[
     f\left(\frac{p}{q}\right) f(q) \ge f(p) \implies f\left(\frac{p}{q}\right) \ge \frac{p}{q}.
     \]

4. **Claim: \( f(x) = x \) for all \( x \in \mathbb{N} \).**

   **Proof:**
   - We have \( f(a^m) = a^m \) for all positive integers \( m \).
   - Suppose \( f(n) > n \) for some \( n \in \mathbb{N} \) and \( a^m > n \):
     \[
     f(a^m) \ge f(a^m - n) + f(n) > f(a^m - n) + n \ge a^m,
     \]
     which is a contradiction since \( f(a^m) = a^m \).
   - Thus, \( f(n) = n \) for all \( n \in \mathbb{N} \).

5. **Conclusion:**

   - For any \( x = \frac{p}{q} \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0} \):
     \[
     f\left(\frac{p}{q}\right) = \frac{p}{q}.
     \]
   - This satisfies all given conditions, hence \( f(x) = x \) for all \( x \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0} \).

\(\blacksquare\)

The final answer is \( \boxed{ f(x) = x } \) for all \( x \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0} \).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $\mathbb Q_{>0}$ be the set of all positive rational numbers. Let $f:\mathbb Q_{>0}\to\mathbb R$ be a function satisfying the following three conditions:

(i) for all $x,y\in\mathbb Q_{>0}$, we have $f(x)f(y)\geq f(xy)$;
(ii) for all $x,y\in\mathbb Q_{>0}$, we have $f(x+y)\geq f(x)+f(y)$;
(iii) there exists a rational number $a>1$ such that $f(a)=a$.

Prove that $f(x)=x$ for all $x\in\mathbb Q_{>0}$.

[i]Proposed by Bulgaria[/i]
 -/
theorem inequalities_54943 (f : ‚Ñö ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hpos : ‚àÄ x, 0 < x ‚Üí 0 < f x)
    (hf1 : ‚àÄ x y, 0 < x ‚Üí 0 < y ‚Üí f x * f y ‚â• f (x * y))
    (hf2 : ‚àÄ x y, 0 < x ‚Üí 0 < y ‚Üí f (x + y) ‚â• f x + f y)
    (hf3 : ‚àÉ a, 1 < a ‚àß f a = a) :
    ‚àÄ x, 0 < x ‚Üí f x = x := by

soln_description:
Solve: From $f(1, n)=f(0, f(1, n-1))=f(1, n-1)+1$ and $f(1,0)=f(0,1)=2$, we get
$$
f(1, n)=n+f(1,0)=n+2 .
$$

Also, from
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(2, n) & =f(1, f(2, n-1)) \\
& =f(2, n-1)+2 \\
& =2 n+f(2,0), \\
f(2,0) & =f(1,1)=3,
\end{aligned}
$$

we have
$$
f(2, n)=2 n+3 \text {. }
$$

Next, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(3, n) & =f(2, f(3, n-1)) \\
& =2 f(3, n-1)+3 \\
& =2[f(3, n-1)+3]-3,
\end{aligned}
$$

thus
$$
f(3, n)+3=2^{n}(f(3,0)+3) \text {. }
$$

Since
$$
f(3,0)=f(2,1)=5,
$$

we get
$$
f(3, n)=2^{n+3}-3 .
$$

Finally, we calculate $f(4, n)$, from
$$
f(4, n)=f(3, f(4, n-1))=2^{f(4, n-1)+3}-3,
$$

which means
$$
\begin{array}{c}
f(4, n)+3=2^{f(4, n-1)+3} . \\
t_{n}=f(4, n)+3, \varphi(x)=2^{x},
\end{array}
$$

Let
then we have $t_{n}=\varphi\left(t_{n-1}\right)$. Therefore, $t_{n}=\varphi^{[n]}\left(t_{0}\right)=\varphi\left(\varphi \cdots\left(\varphi\left(t_{0}\right)\right)\right)$ is an $n$-fold iteration.
Since
$$
t_{0}=f(4,0)+3=f(3,1)+3=2^{4} \text {, }
$$

we have
$$
f(4, n)=\varphi^{[n]}(16)-3 .
$$

Thus,
$$
f(4,1981)=\varphi^{[1981]}(16)-3=2^{2^{\cdot 2}}-3 \text {, }
$$

where the exponent is iterated 1984 times.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Test $\mathbf{E}$ Function $f(x, y)$ satisfies for all non-negative integers $x, y$:
(1) $f(0, y)=y+1$;
(2) $f(x+1,0)=f(x, 1)$;
(3) $f(x+1, y+1)=f(x, f(x+1, y))$.

Determine $f(4,1981)$. -/
theorem algebra_285900 {f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï}
    (h0 : ‚àÄ y, f 0 y = y + 1)
    (h1 : ‚àÄ x, f (x + 1) 0 = f x 1)
    (h2 : ‚àÄ x y, f (x + 1) (y + 1) = f x (f (x + 1) y)) :
    f 4 1981 = 2 ^ (2 ^ 1984) - 3 := by

soln_description:
We will look at two methods to solve this exercise. Let $x$ be a real number. We can first try to eliminate the $f\left(x^{3}\right)$. Thus, we subtract the equation with $y=1$ from the equation with $y=0$.

Thus we get $f(0)-f(1)=\left(x^{2}+x+1\right)(f(x)-f(1))-\left(x^{2}\right)(f(x)-f(0))$ and we want to isolate $f(x)$. Therefore,

$(x+1) f(x)=(x+1)((f(1)-f(0)) x+f(0))$.

Thus, if $x \neq-1$, then $f(x)=((f(1)-f(0)) x+f(0))$. Otherwise, we set $x=-1$ and $y=2$ to verify that this is also true for $f(-1)$. We verify conversely that affine functions are solutions.

We can also write the equation in the following form if $x \neq y: \frac{f\left(x^{3}\right)-f\left(y^{3}\right)}{x^{3}-y^{3}}=\frac{f(x)-f(y)}{x-y}$. Thus, if the slope of the graph of $f$ between $x$ and $y$ is the same as between $x^{3}$ and $y^{3}$. With $y=1$, $x \neq-1,0,1$, the points on the graph $(x, f(x)),(1, f(1))$ and $\left(x^{3}, f\left(x^{3}\right)\right)$ are aligned on a line $D$, and similarly $(x, f(x)),(0, f(0))$ and $\left(x^{3}, f\left(x^{3}\right)\right)$ are aligned on $D^{\prime}$. Since $x^{3} \neq x$, $D=D^{\prime}$, the points on the graph, except possibly $(-1, f(-1))$ (we handle this case separately), are aligned. Thus, the solutions are affine functions that fit.
informal_statement:
Find all functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that

$$
\forall x, y \in \mathbb{R}, f\left(x^{3}\right)-f\left(y^{3}\right)=\left(x^{2}+x y+y^{2}\right)(f(x)-f(y))
$$

/- Find all functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that

$$ -/
theorem algebra_138049 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) :
    (‚àÄ x y, f (x ^ 3) - f (y ^ 3) = (x ^ 2 + x * y + y ^ 2) * (f x - f y)) ‚Üî
    ‚àÉ c d, ‚àÄ x, f x = c * x + d ‚àß f 1 - f 0 = c := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

(a) The condition

$$
a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a=a^{2} c+b^{2} a+c^{2} b
$$

is successively equivalent to

$$
\begin{gathered}
a^{2}(b-c)+b^{2}(c-a)+c^{2}(a-b)=0 \\
a^{2}(b-c)+b^{2}(c-b+b-a)+c^{2}(a-b)=0 \\
a^{2}(b-c)+b^{2}(c-b)+b^{2}(b-a)+c^{2}(a-b)=0 \\
a^{2}(b-c)+b^{2}(c-b)+b^{2}(b-a)+c^{2}(a-b)=0 \\
\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right)(b-c)+\left(c^{2}-b^{2}\right)(a-b)=0 \\
(a-b)(a+b)(b-c)+(c-b)(c+b)(a-b)=0 \\
(a-b)(b-c)(a+b-c-b)=0 \\
(a-b)(b-c)(a-c)=0
\end{gathered}
$$

From this, we conclude that at least two of the numbers $a, b, c$ must be equal.

Using the condition $a+b+c=2021$, we get that all solutions are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (a, b, c)=(t, t, 2021-2 t), t \in \mathbb{R} \\
& (a, b, c)=(t, 2021-2 t, t), t \in \mathbb{R} \\
& (a, b, c)=(2021-2 t, t, t), t \in \mathbb{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) The condition

$$
a^{3} b+b^{3} c+c^{3} a=a^{3} c+b^{3} a+c^{3} b
$$

is successively equivalent to

$$
\begin{gathered}
a^{3}(b-c)+b^{3}(c-a)+c^{3}(a-b)=0 \\
a^{3}(b-c)+b^{3}(c-b+b-a)+c^{3}(a-b)=0 \\
a^{3}(b-c)+b^{3}(c-b)+b^{3}(b-a)+c^{3}(a-b)=0
\end{gathered}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}
a^{3}(b-c)+b^{3}(c-b)+b^{3}(b-a)+c^{3}(a-b)=0 \\
\left(a^{3}-b^{3}\right)(b-c)+\left(c^{3}-b^{3}\right)(a-b)=0 \\
(a-b)\left(a^{2}+a b+b^{2}\right)(b-c)+(c-b)\left(c^{2}+b c+b^{2}\right)(a-b)=0 \\
(a-b)(b-c)\left(a^{2}+a b+b^{2}-c^{2}-b c-b^{2}\right)=0 \\
\left.(a-b)(b-c)\left(a^{2}-c^{2}+a b-b c\right)\right)=0 \\
(a-b)(b-c)((a-c)(a+c)+b(a-c))=0 \\
(a-b)(b-c)(a-c)(a+c+b)=0
\end{gathered}
$$

or, using the condition $a+b+c=2021$, we have

$$
2021(a-b)(b-c)(a-c)=0
$$

We can then conclude as in part (a) of the problem.
informal_statement:
## Task 1.

(a) Determine all ordered triples $(a, b, c)$ of real numbers for which

$$
a+b+c=2021 \quad \text { and } \quad a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a=a^{2} c+b^{2} a+c^{2} b
$$

(b) Determine all ordered triples $(a, b, c)$ of real numbers for which

$$
a+b+c=2021 \quad \text { and } \quad a^{3} b+b^{3} c+c^{3} a=a^{3} c+b^{3} a+c^{3} b
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 1.

(a) Determine all ordered triples $(a, b, c)$ of real numbers for which

$$
a+b+c=2021 \quad \text { and } \quad a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a=a^{2} c+b^{2} a+c^{2} b
$$

(b) Determine all ordered triples $(a, b, c)$ of real numbers for which

$$
a+b+c=2021 \quad \text { and } \quad a^{3} b+b^{3} c+c^{3} a=a^{3} c+b^{3} a+c^{3} b
$$ -/
theorem algebra_252807 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (h1 : a + b + c = 2021) (h2 : a^2 * b + b^2 * c + c^2 * a = a^2 * c + b^2 * a + c^2 * b) :
    (a = b ‚àß b = c) ‚à® (a = 2021 - 2 * b ‚àß b = 2021 - 2 * c) ‚à® (a = 2021 - 2 * b ‚àß b = 2021 - 2 * c ‚àß c = 2021 - 2 * a) := by

soln_description:
## Solution

The area of the parallelogram constructed on vectors $a$ and $b$ is numerically equal to the modulus of their vector product:

$$
S=|a \times b|
$$

We compute \(a \times b\) using the properties of the vector product:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a \times b=(p+2 q) \times(3 p-q)=3 \cdot p \times p-p \times q+2 \cdot 3 \cdot q \times p+2 \cdot(-1) q \times q= \\
& =-1 \cdot p \times q+6 \cdot q \times p=-1 \cdot p \times q-6 \cdot p \times q=(-1-6) \cdot p \times q=-7 \cdot p \times q
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S=|a \times b|=|-7 \cdot p \times q|=7 \cdot|p \times q|=7 \cdot|p| \cdot|q| \cdot \sin (\widehat{p, q})= \\
& =7 \cdot 1 \cdot 2 \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{6}=14 \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{6}=14 \cdot \frac{1}{2}=7
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the area of the parallelogram constructed on vectors $a$ and $b$ is 7.

## Problem Kuznetsov Analytic Geometry 5-1
informal_statement:
## Task Condition

Calculate the area of the parallelogram constructed on vectors $a$ and $b$.

\[
\begin{aligned}
& a=p+2 q \\
& b=3 p-q \\
& |p|=1 \\
& |q|=2 \\
& (\widehat{p, q})=\frac{\pi}{6}
\end{aligned}
\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task Condition

Calculate the area of the parallelogram constructed on vectors $a$ and $b$.

\[
\begin{aligned}
& a=p+2 q \\
& b=3 p-q \\
& |p|=1 \\
& |q|=2 \\
& (\widehat{p, q})=\frac{\pi}{6}
\end{aligned}
\] -/
theorem algebra_154656 {p q : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù}
    (hp : ‚Äñp‚Äñ = 1) (hq : ‚Äñq‚Äñ = 2)
    (h : p.1 * q.2 - p.2 * q.1 = 1 / 2) :
    (p.1 * 3 - p.2 * (-1)) * 2 = 7 := by

soln_description:
To determine how many times the number \(111\) appears in the sequence \((a_n)\), we need to analyze the sequence generation rules and how they can produce the number \(111\).

Given:
- \(a_1 = 1\)
- \(a_{2n} = a_n + 1\)
- \(a_{2n+1} = 10a_n\)

We need to find all \(n\) such that \(a_n = 111\).

1. **Initial Step**:
   - Start with \(a_1 = 1\).

2. **Generating the Sequence**:
   - For \(a_{2n}\), we have \(a_{2n} = a_n + 1\).
   - For \(a_{2n+1}\), we have \(a_{2n+1} = 10a_n\).

3. **Finding \(111\)**:
   - We need to find \(n\) such that \(a_n = 111\).

4. **Backtracking from \(111\)**:
   - If \(a_n = 111\), we need to determine the possible values of \(a_k\) such that \(a_k\) can generate \(111\) using the given rules.
   - We can backtrack from \(111\) to find all possible sequences leading to it.

5. **Possible Routes**:
   - If \(a_{2n} = 111\), then \(a_n = 111 - 1 = 110\).
   - If \(a_{2n+1} = 111\), then \(a_n = \frac{111}{10} = 11.1\) (not an integer, so this route is invalid).

6. **Continuing Backtracking**:
   - For \(a_n = 110\):
     - If \(a_{2m} = 110\), then \(a_m = 110 - 1 = 109\).
     - If \(a_{2m+1} = 110\), then \(a_m = \frac{110}{10} = 11\).

7. **Further Backtracking**:
   - For \(a_m = 109\):
     - If \(a_{2p} = 109\), then \(a_p = 109 - 1 = 108\).
     - If \(a_{2p+1} = 109\), then \(a_p = \frac{109}{10} = 10.9\) (not an integer, so this route is invalid).

8. **Continuing**:
   - For \(a_p = 108\):
     - If \(a_{2q} = 108\), then \(a_q = 108 - 1 = 107\).
     - If \(a_{2q+1} = 108\), then \(a_q = \frac{108}{10} = 10.8\) (not an integer, so this route is invalid).

9. **Identifying Valid Routes**:
   - We continue this process until we reach \(a_1 = 1\).

10. **Counting Valid Routes**:
    - We need to count all valid sequences that lead to \(111\).

From the solution provided, it appears that there are \(14\) valid routes that lead to \(111\). This is determined by considering the number of times the multiplication by \(10\) step can occur and the number of valid sequences that can be formed.

The final answer is \( \boxed{ 14 } \).
informal_statement: Let $(a_n)$ be a sequence of integers, with $a_1 = 1$ and for evert integer $n \ge 1$, $a_{2n} = a_n + 1$ and $a_{2n+1} = 10a_n$. How many times $111$ appears on this sequence?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $(a_n)$ be a sequence of integers, with $a_1 = 1$ and for evert integer $n \ge 1$, $a_{2n} = a_n + 1$ and $a_{2n+1} = 10a_n$. How many times $111$ appears on this sequence? -/
theorem number_theory_77488 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) (ha1 : a 1 = 1)
    (han : ‚àÄ n ‚â• 1, a (2 * n) = a n + 1 ‚àß a (2 * n + 1) = 10 * a n) :
    {n | 1 ‚â§ n ‚àß a n = 111}.encard = 14 := by

informal_statement: If $x$ and $ \sqrt { x ^ { 2 } + 2 0 2 4 x } $ are positive integers, find the maximum value of $x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $x$ and $ \sqrt { x ^ { 2 } + 2 0 2 4 x } $ are positive integers, find the maximum value of $x$. -/
theorem algebra_6251 (x : ‚Ñï) (hx : x > 0) (h : ‚àÉ n : ‚Ñï, Real.sqrt (x^2 + 2024 * x) = n) :

soln_description:
1. We start by analyzing the given conditions:
   \[
   \gcd(a, b) = 24 = 2^3 \cdot 3
   \]
   \[
   \gcd(b, c) = 36 = 2^2 \cdot 3^2
   \]
   \[
   \gcd(c, d) = 54 = 2 \cdot 3^3
   \]
   \[
   70 < \gcd(d, a) < 100
   \]

2. We express \(a, b, c,\) and \(d\) in terms of their prime factors:
   \[
   a = 2^3 \cdot 3 \cdot a_1 = 24a_1
   \]
   \[
   b = 2^3 \cdot 3^2 \cdot b_1 = 72b_1
   \]
   \[
   c = 2^2 \cdot 3^3 \cdot c_1 = 108c_1
   \]
   \[
   d = 2 \cdot 3^3 \cdot d_1 = 54d_1
   \]

3. We need to find \(\gcd(a, d)\):
   \[
   \gcd(a, d) = \gcd(24a_1, 54d_1)
   \]
   Since \(24 = 2^3 \cdot 3\) and \(54 = 2 \cdot 3^3\), the common factors are \(2\) and \(3\):
   \[
   \gcd(a, d) = 2 \cdot 3 \cdot \gcd(a_1, d_1) = 6 \cdot \gcd(a_1, d_1)
   \]
   Let \(\gcd(a_1, d_1) = n\), then:
   \[
   \gcd(a, d) = 6n
   \]
   Given:
   \[
   70 < 6n < 100
   \]
   Solving for \(n\):
   \[
   \frac{70}{6} < n < \frac{100}{6}
   \]
   \[
   11.67 < n < 16.67
   \]
   Since \(n\) must be an integer:
   \[
   12 \leq n \leq 16
   \]

4. We now test each possible value of \(n\) to see which one fits all conditions:
   - For \(n = 12\):
     \[
     \gcd(a, d) = 6 \cdot 12 = 72 = 2^3 \cdot 3^2
     \]
     This implies \(3 \mid a_1\) and \(4 \mid d_1\). However, this would make \(\gcd(a, b) \geq 72\), which contradicts \(\gcd(a, b) = 24\).

   - For \(n = 13\):
     \[
     \gcd(a, d) = 6 \cdot 13 = 78 = 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 13
     \]
     This implies \(13 \mid a_1\) and \(13 \mid d_1\). This does not contradict any given conditions.

   - For \(n = 14\):
     \[
     \gcd(a, d) = 6 \cdot 14 = 84 = 2^2 \cdot 3 \cdot 7
     \]
     This implies \(7 \mid a_1\) and \(14 \mid d_1\). However, this would make \(\gcd(c, d) \geq 108\), which contradicts \(\gcd(c, d) = 54\).

   - For \(n = 15\):
     \[
     \gcd(a, d) = 6 \cdot 15 = 90 = 2 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5
     \]
     This implies \(5 \mid a_1\). However, this would make \(\gcd(a, b) \geq 72\), which contradicts \(\gcd(a, b) = 24\).

   - For \(n = 16\):
     \[
     \gcd(a, d) = 6 \cdot 16 = 96 = 2^5 \cdot 3
     \]
     This implies \(16 \mid d_1\). However, this would make \(\gcd(c, d) \geq 108\), which contradicts \(\gcd(c, d) = 54\).

5. The only value of \(n\) that works is \(n = 13\), which implies \(13 \mid a_1\). Therefore, \(13\) must be a divisor of \(a\).

The final answer is \(\boxed{13}\).
informal_statement:
Let $a, b, c,$ and $d$ be positive integers such that $\gcd(a, b)=24$, $\gcd(b, c)=36$, $\gcd(c, d)=54$, and $70<\gcd(d, a)<100$. Which of the following must be a divisor of $a$?

$\textbf{(A)} \text{ 5} \qquad \textbf{(B)} \text{ 7} \qquad \textbf{(C)} \text{ 11} \qquad \textbf{(D)} \text{ 13} \qquad \textbf{(E)} \text{ 17}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a, b, c,$ and $d$ be positive integers such that $\gcd(a, b)=24$, $\gcd(b, c)=36$, $\gcd(c, d)=54$, and $70<\gcd(d, a)<100$. Which of the following must be a divisor of $a$?

$\textbf{(A)} \text{ 5} \qquad \textbf{(B)} \text{ 7} \qquad \textbf{(C)} \text{ 11} \qquad \textbf{(D)} \text{ 13} \qquad \textbf{(E)} \text{ 17}$ -/
theorem number_theory_68413 (a b c d : ‚Ñï) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d)
    (h1 : Nat.gcd a b = 24) (h2 : Nat.gcd b c = 36) (h3 : Nat.gcd c d = 54)
    (h4 : 70 < Nat.gcd d a ‚àß Nat.gcd d a < 100) :
    13 ‚à£ a := by

soln_description:
Solution 1. Assume that
$$
f(x-f(y)) \leq y f(x)+x \text { for all real } x, y .
$$

Let $a=f(0)$. Setting $y=0$ in (1) gives $f(x-a) \leq x$ for all real $x$ and, equivalently,
$$
f(y) \leq y+a \text { for all real } y .
$$

Setting $x=f(y)$ in (1) yields in view of (2)
$$
a=f(0) \leq y f(f(y))+f(y) \leq y f(f(y))+y+a .
$$

This implies $0 \leq y(f(f(y))+1)$ and thus
$$
f(f(y)) \geq-1 \text { for all } y>0 .
$$

From (2) and (3) we obtain $-1 \leq f(f(y)) \leq f(y)+a$ for all $y>0$, so
$$
f(y) \geq-a-1 \text { for all } y>0 .
$$

Now we show that
$$
f(x) \leq 0 \quad \text { for all real } x .
$$

Assume the contrary, i.e. there is some $x$ such that $f(x)>0$. Take any $y$ such that
$$
y0
$$
and with (1) and (4) we obtain
$$
y f(x)+x \geq f(x-f(y)) \geq-a-1,
$$
whence
$$
y \geq \frac{-a-x-1}{f(x)}
$$
contrary to our choice of $y$. Thereby, we have established (5).
Setting $x=0$ in (5) leads to $a=f(0) \leq 0$ and (2) then yields
$$
f(x) \leq x \text { for all real } x \text {. }
$$

Now choose $y$ such that $y>0$ and $y>-f(-1)-1$ and set $x=f(y)-1$. From (1), (5) and (6) we obtain
$$
f(-1)=f(x-f(y)) \leq y f(x)+x=y f(f(y)-1)+f(y)-1 \leq y(f(y)-1)-1 \leq-y-1,
$$
i.e. $y \leq-f(-1)-1$, a contradiction to the choice of $y$.

Solution 2. Assume that
$$
f(x-f(y)) \leq y f(x)+x \text { for all real } x, y .
$$

Let $a=f(0)$. Setting $y=0$ in (7) gives $f(x-a) \leq x$ for all real $x$ and, equivalently,
$$
f(y) \leq y+a \text { for all real } y .
$$

Now we show that
$$
f(z) \geq 0 \text { for all } z \geq 1 .
$$

Let $z \geq 1$ be fixed, set $b=f(z)$ and assume that $b(n b+a) z^{n}
$$
because the right hand side tends to $-\infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Now (12) and (13) give the desired contradiction and (9) is established. In addition, we have for $z=1$ the strict inequality
$$
f(1)>0 \text {. }
$$

Indeed, assume that $f(1)=0$. Then setting $w=-1$ and $z=1$ in (11) leads to
$$
f(-1) \leq-(n+1)+a
$$
which is false if $n$ is sufficiently large.
To complete the proof we set $t=\min \{-a,-2 / f(1)\}$. Setting $x=1$ and $y=t$ in (7) gives
$$
f(1-f(t)) \leq t f(1)+1 \leq-2+1=-1 .
$$

On the other hand, by (8) and the choice of $t$ we have $f(t) \leq t+a \leq 0$ and hence $1-f(t) \geq 1$. The inequality (9) yields
$$
f(1-f(t)) \geq 0,
$$
which contradicts (15).

soln_description:
[Proof] By contradiction. Suppose there exist $1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n$, such that
$$
A \geqslant 2 a_{i} a_{j},
$$

Without loss of generality, let $i=1, j=2$. Then we have
$$
A+\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2} \geqslant 2 a_{1} a_{2}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}=\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)^{2}+a_{3}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \text {. }
$$

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality,
$$
\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)^{2}+a_{3}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2} \geqslant \frac{1}{n-1}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2},
$$

Thus, we obtain
$$
A+\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2} \geqslant \frac{1}{n-1}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)^{2},
$$

which contradicts the assumption! Therefore, for any $1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n$,
$$
A<2 a_{i} a_{j} .
$$
informal_statement:
$9 \cdot 244$ Let real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}(n \geqslant 2)$ and $A$ satisfy
$$
A+\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}<\frac{1}{n-1}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)^{2} .
$$

Prove: For $1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n$ we have
$$
A<2 a_{i} a_{j} .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

$$

Prove: For $1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n$ we have
$$
A<2 a_{i} a_{j} .
$$ -/

soln_description:
Prove $\frac{\sin \alpha}{\sin (\alpha-\beta) \sin (\alpha-\gamma)}=\frac{\sin \alpha \sin (\gamma-\beta)}{\sin (\alpha-\beta) \sin (\alpha-\gamma) \sin (\gamma-\beta)}$ $=\frac{\cos (\alpha+\beta-\gamma)-\cos (\alpha-\beta+\gamma)}{2 \sin (\alpha-\beta) \sin (\alpha-\gamma) \sin (\gamma-\beta)}$,
Similarly, $\frac{\sin \beta}{\sin (\beta-\alpha) \sin (\beta-\gamma)}=\frac{\cos (\beta+\gamma-\alpha)-\cos (\beta-\gamma+\alpha)}{\sin (\beta-\alpha) \sin (\beta-\gamma) \sin (\alpha-\gamma)}$, $\frac{\sin \gamma}{\sin (\gamma-\alpha) \sin (\gamma-\beta)}=\frac{\cos (\gamma+\alpha-\beta)-\cos (\gamma-\alpha+\beta)}{2 \sin (\gamma-\alpha) \sin (\gamma-\beta) \sin (\beta-\alpha)}$,
Adding the three equations, we get $\frac{\sin \alpha}{\sin (\alpha-\beta) \sin (\alpha-\gamma)}+\frac{\sin \beta}{\sin (\beta-\alpha) \sin (\beta-\gamma)}+\frac{\sin \gamma}{\sin (\gamma-\alpha) \sin (\gamma-\beta)}=0$.
informal_statement: Example 2 Prove: $\frac{\sin \alpha}{\sin (\alpha-\beta) \sin (\alpha-\gamma)}+\frac{\sin \beta}{\sin (\beta-\alpha) \sin (\beta-\gamma)}+\frac{\sin \gamma}{\sin (\gamma-\alpha) \sin (\gamma-\beta)}=0$.

$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}}{\sqrt{x y}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{27-x-y}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{y}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{27-x-y}} \geq \frac{9}{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{27-x-y}} \\
\geq \frac{9}{\sqrt{(x+y+27-x-y)(1+1+1)}}=1, \text { with equality if and only if } x=y=9
\end{array}
$$

soln_description:
Analysis: Given $\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B}+\mathrm{C}=\pi \Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}=\frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{\mathrm{B}+\mathrm{C}}{2}$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\Rightarrow \operatorname{tg} \frac{A}{2}=\operatorname{ctg} \frac{B+C}{2}=\frac{1-\operatorname{tg} \frac{B}{2} \operatorname{tg} \frac{C}{2}}{\operatorname{tg} \frac{B}{2}+\operatorname{tg} \frac{C}{2}} \\
\Rightarrow \operatorname{tg} \frac{A}{2} \operatorname{tg} \frac{B}{2}+\operatorname{tg} \frac{B}{2} \operatorname{tg} \frac{C}{2}+\operatorname{tg} \frac{C}{2} \operatorname{tg} \frac{A}{2} \\
=1 .
\end{array}
$$
[Proof] $\because 00, \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{B}}{2}>0, \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{C}}{2}>0, \\
\Rightarrow \operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}+\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{B}}{2} \geqslant 2 \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{A}}{2} \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{B}}{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Similarly, $\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{B}}{2}+\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{C}}{2} \geqslant 2 \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{B}}{2} \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{C}}{2}$,
$$
\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{C}}{2}+\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{A}}{2} \geqslant 2 \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{C}}{2} \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{A}}{2} \text {. }
$$
$(1)+(2)+(3)$, and divide by 2:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}+\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{B}{2}+\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{C}}{2} \\
\geqslant & \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{A}}{2} \cdot \operatorname{tg} \frac{B}{2}+\operatorname{tg} \frac{B}{2} \cdot \operatorname{tg} \frac{C}{2} \\
+ & \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{C}}{2} \cdot \operatorname{tg} \frac{\mathrm{A}}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

From the analysis, it is easy to see:
$$
\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}+\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{B}{2}+\operatorname{tg}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{C}}{2} \geqslant 1 .
$$

soln_description:
Proof: Let the middle part of the inequality be denoted as $M$. Construct the pairing expression
$$
N=\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{4}{5} \times \frac{6}{7} \times \cdots \times \frac{98}{99} \times \frac{100}{101} .
$$

Notice that $\frac{n-1}{n}\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{4}{5} \times \frac{6}{7} \times \cdots \times \frac{98}{99} \times \frac{100}{101}=N,
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $2 M^{2}>M N=\frac{1}{101}$.
Hence, $M>\frac{1}{\sqrt{202}}>\frac{1}{15}$.
Thus, $\frac{1}{15}<M<\frac{1}{10}$.

\[v_{1,2}=\frac{4 v_{0} \pm \sqrt{16 v_{0}^{2}-12 v_{0}^{2}}}{6}=\frac{4 v_{0} \pm \sqrt{4 v_{0}^{2}}}{6}=\frac{4 v_{0} \pm 2 v_{0}}{6}\]

5. The force with which the airflow acts on the sail can be calculated using the formula $F=\frac{c S \rho\left(v_{0}-v\right)^{2}}{2}$, where $C$ is the aerodynamic force coefficient, $S$ is the area of the sail; $\rho$ is the density of the air, $v_{0}$ is the wind speed, and $v$ is the speed of the sailboat. At some moment in time, the instantaneous power of the wind reaches its maximum value. What is the speed of the sailboat at this moment?

Given:

$F=\frac{C S \rho\left(v_{0}-v\right)^{2}}{2}$

$N(t ')=N_{\max }$

$v_{0} ;$

$v\left(t^{\prime}\right)-?$

The force with which the airflow acts on the sail can be calculated using the formula $F=\frac{c S \rho\left(v_{0}-v\right)^{2}}{2}$, where $C$ is the aerodynamic force coefficient, $S$ is the area of the sail; $\rho$ is the density of the air, $v_{0}$ is the wind speed, and $v$ is the speed of the sailboat. At some moment in time, the instantaneous power of the wind reaches its maximum value. What is the speed of the sailboat at this moment?

    (hNmax' : ‚àÄ v, N v ‚â§ Nmax) :

12. -5

Let $y=f(x)=x^{6}-6 x$, by $f(1)j(-x)$, so $y_{\operatorname{man}}$ is obtained when $x>0$.
At this time, $x^{5}+\frac{-y}{x^{2}}=6,-y \leqslant 0$ is possible, but to find $y_{\operatorname{mnn}}$, only consider $-y<0$, i.e., the situation where $y<0$.
At this time, $6=x^{5}+\frac{-y}{x}=x^{5}+\frac{-y}{5 x}+\frac{-y}{5 x}+\frac{-y}{5 x}+\frac{-y}{5 x}+\frac{-y}{5 x} \geqslant 6 \sqrt[6]{\left(\frac{-y}{5}\right)^{5}}$, so $\sqrt[6]{\left(\frac{-y}{5}\right)^{5}} \leqslant 1$. Therefore, $y \geqslant-5$, with equality if and only if $x^{5}=\frac{-y}{5 x}$, i.e., $x=1$. Hence, $y_{\text {n√∫ }}=-5$.
informal_statement: 12. The minimum value of $f(x)=x^{6}-6 x(x \in \mathbf{R})$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 12. The minimum value of $f(x)=x^{6}-6 x(x \in \mathbf{R})$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_172529 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : f = fun x => x^6 - 6 * x) :
    IsLeast (Set.image f (Set.univ : Set ‚Ñù)) (-5) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_172529 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : f = fun x => x^6 - 6 * x) :
    IsLeast (Set.image f (Set.univ : Set ‚Ñù)) (-5) := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that -5 is attained by f
    use 1
    simp [hf]
    norm_num
  ¬∑ -- Show that -5 is the least value
    intro y
    intro hy
    rcases hy with ‚ü®x, hx‚ü©
    simp [hf] at hx
    have h : x ^ 6 - 6 * x ‚â• -5 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x ^ 3 - 1), sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - 1), sq_nonneg (x ^ 3 + 1), sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 + 1), sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (x + 1), sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - x + 1), sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 + x + 1), sq_nonneg (x ^ 3 - x ^ 2), sq_nonneg (x ^ 3 + x ^ 2)]
    linarith

soln_description:
Solution. The first inequality is equivalent to $\frac{1}{a}<x<\frac{2}{a}$. The interval $\left(\frac{1}{a}, \frac{2}{a}\right)$ contains three integers. They divide it into two (internal) intervals of length 1 and two (end) intervals of length not greater than 1. Therefore, for the length $\frac{1}{a}$ of the interval $\left(\frac{1}{a}, \frac{2}{a}\right)$, the inequality $2<\frac{1}{a} \leq 4$ holds.

In general, if an interval of length $t$ contains $k$ integers, then the inequality $k-1<t \leq k+1$ holds, from which $t-1 \leq k<t+1$.

The second interval $\left(\frac{2}{a}, \frac{3}{a}\right)$ has length $t=\frac{1}{a}$, and taking into account the inequalities for $\frac{1}{a}$, we get

$$
1<\frac{1}{a}-1 \leq k<\frac{1}{a}+1 \leq 5
$$

i.e., $k=2,3$ or 4. All three cases are possible: $k=2$ for $a=\frac{3}{8}(x=6$ and 7$); k=3$ for $a=\frac{1}{4}$ $(x=9,10$ and 11$); k=4$ for $a=\frac{5}{17}(x=7,8,9$ and 10$)$.
informal_statement: Problem 3. (4 points) Given a positive number $a$, for which the inequality $1<x a<2$ has exactly three integer solutions. How many integer solutions can the inequality $2<x a<3$ have?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 3. (4 points) Given a positive number $a$, for which the inequality $1<x a<2$ has exactly three integer solutions. How many integer solutions can the inequality $2<x a<3$ have? -/
theorem inequalities_293723 (a : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (h : {x : ‚Ñ§ | 1 < x * a ‚àß x * a < 2}.encard = 3) :
    2 ‚â§ {x : ‚Ñ§ | 2 < x * a ‚àß x * a < 3}.encard ‚àß
    {x : ‚Ñ§ | 2 < x * a ‚àß x * a < 3}.encard ‚â§ 4 := by

soln_description:
40. The original inequality is equivalent to $\frac{a}{a^{2}+p}+\frac{b}{b^{2}+p}+\frac{c}{c^{2}+p} \leqslant \frac{27}{31}(p=a b c+1)$.

Consider the function
$$f(x)=\frac{3(a+b+c)}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+3 x}-\frac{a}{a^{2}+x}-\frac{b}{b^{2}+x}-\frac{c}{c^{2}+x}$$

First, prove that for all $x \geqslant a b+b c+c a$, we have $f(x) \geqslant 0$.
By combining the terms of $f(x)$, we get
$$f(x)=\frac{A x^{2}+B x+C}{\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+3 x\right)\left(a^{2}+x\right)\left(b^{2}+x\right)\left(c^{2}+x\right)}$$

where
$$\begin{array}{c}
A=2\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)-[a b(a+b)+b c(b+c)-c a(c+a)] \geqslant 0 \\
C=-a b c\left[a\left(b^{3}+c^{3}\right)+b\left(c^{3}+a^{3}\right)+c\left(a^{3}+b^{3}\right)-2 a b c(a+b+c)\right] \leqslant 0
\end{array}$$

Therefore, the quadratic polynomial $P(x)=A x^{2}+B x+C$ has roots of opposite signs. Let the positive root be $x_{0}$.
Then, when $0 \leqslant x \leqslant x_{0}$, $P(x) \leqslant 0$; when $x \geqslant x_{0}$, $P(x) \geqslant 0$.
$$\begin{array}{l}
f(a b+b c+c a)=\frac{3(a+b+c)}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2-}+3(a b+b c+c a)} \\
\frac{a}{a^{2}+a b+b c+c a} \\
\frac{b}{b^{2}+a b+b c+c a} \\
\frac{c}{c^{2}+a b+b c+c a}= \\
\frac{3(a+b+c)}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+3(a b+b c+c a)} \\
\frac{a}{(a+b)(a+c)}-\frac{b}{(a+b)(b+c)}-\frac{c}{(a+c)(b+c)}= \\
\frac{3(a+b+c)}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+3(a b+b c+c a)} \\
\frac{2(a b+b c+c a)}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}
\end{array}$$

Also,
$$\begin{array}{c}
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geqslant a b+b c+c a \\
a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a+a b^{2}+b c^{2}+c a^{2} \geqslant 6 a b c
\end{array}$$

Thus,
$$\frac{3(a+b-c)}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+3(a b+b c+c a)} \geqslant \frac{9}{4(-a+b+c)} \geqslant \frac{2(a b+b c+c a)}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}$$

Therefore, $f(a b+b c+c a) \geqslant 0$, so $P(a b+b c+c a) \geqslant 0$. Hence, $x_{0} \leqslant a b+b c+c a$.
Thus, for all $x \geqslant a b+b c+c a$, we have $f(x) \geqslant 0$.
Since $a b c+\mathrm{F}>1>a b+b c+c a$, we have $f(a b c+1) \geqslant 0$.
Therefore,

So, it suffices to prove
$$\begin{array}{l}
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+3 a b c \geqslant \frac{4}{9} \Leftrightarrow^{-} \\
9(a+b+c)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+27 a b c \geqslant 4(a+b+c)^{3} \Leftrightarrow \\
5\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)+3 a b c \geqslant 3[a b(a+b)+b c(b+c)+c a+c+a)
\end{array}$$

By Schur's inequality, we have
$$a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+3 a b c \geqslant a b(a+b)+b c(b+c)+c a(c+a)$$

Also,
$$2\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right) \geqslant a b(a+b)+b c(b+c)+c a(c+a)$$
(2) $+2 \times(3)$ yields the inequality (1).
informal_statement: 40. Given that $a, b, c$ are positive numbers, and $a+b+c=1$, prove: $\frac{1}{b c+a+\frac{1}{a}}+\frac{1}{c a+b+\frac{1}{b}}+$ $\frac{1}{a b+c+\frac{1}{c}} \leqslant \frac{27}{31} \cdot$ (2008 Serbian Mathematical Olympiad Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 40. Given that $a, b, c$ are positive numbers, and $a+b+c=1$, prove: $\frac{1}{b c+a+\frac{1}{a}}+\frac{1}{c a+b+\frac{1}{b}}+$ $\frac{1}{a b+c+\frac{1}{c}} \leqslant \frac{27}{31} \cdot$ (2008 Serbian Mathematical Olympiad Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_602916 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a + b + c = 1) :
    27 / 31 ‚â• 1 / (b * c + a + 1 / a) + 1 / (c * a + b + 1 / b) +
    1 / (a * b + c + 1 / c) := by

soln_description:
1. **Given Condition**: We are given that for a function \( f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R} \), the following holds for all \( n \in \mathbb{N} \):
   \[
   \prod_{d \mid n} f(d) = 2^n
   \]
   where the product is taken over all positive divisors \( d \) of \( n \).

2. **Objective**: We need to show that \( f \) maps \( \mathbb{N} \) to \( \mathbb{N} \), i.e., \( f(n) \in \mathbb{N} \) for all \( n \in \mathbb{N} \).

3. **Using M√∂bius Inversion Formula**: The M√∂bius inversion formula is a powerful tool in number theory that allows us to invert certain types of summation formulas. For a function \( g(n) \) defined as:
   \[
   g(n) = \sum_{d \mid n} f(d)
   \]
   the M√∂bius inversion formula states that:
   \[
   f(n) = \sum_{d \mid n} \mu(d) g\left(\frac{n}{d}\right)
   \]
   where \( \mu \) is the M√∂bius function.

4. **Transforming the Given Product**: We start by taking the logarithm of both sides of the given product equation:
   \[
   \log \left( \prod_{d \mid n} f(d) \right) = \log (2^n)
   \]
   This simplifies to:
   \[
   \sum_{d \mid n} \log f(d) = n \log 2
   \]

5. **Defining a New Function**: Let \( g(n) = \log f(n) \). Then the equation becomes:
   \[
   \sum_{d \mid n} g(d) = n \log 2
   \]

6. **Applying M√∂bius Inversion**: Using the M√∂bius inversion formula on the summation, we get:
   \[
   g(n) = \sum_{d \mid n} \mu(d) \cdot (n/d) \log 2
   \]
   Simplifying this, we have:
   \[
   g(n) = \log 2 \cdot \sum_{d \mid n} \mu(d) \cdot \frac{n}{d}
   \]

7. **Simplifying the Summation**: The summation \( \sum_{d \mid n} \mu(d) \cdot \frac{n}{d} \) is known to be \( \phi(n) \), where \( \phi \) is Euler's totient function. Thus:
   \[
   g(n) = n \log 2
   \]

8. **Reverting Back to \( f(n) \)**: Since \( g(n) = \log f(n) \), we have:
   \[
   \log f(n) = n \log 2
   \]
   Exponentiating both sides, we get:
   \[
   f(n) = 2^n
   \]

9. **Conclusion**: Since \( f(n) = 2^n \) and \( 2^n \in \mathbb{N} \) for all \( n \in \mathbb{N} \), we have shown that \( f \) maps \( \mathbb{N} \) to \( \mathbb{N} \).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
If $f:\mathbb N\to\mathbb R$ is a function such that
$$\prod_{d\mid n}f(d)=2^n$$holds for all $n\in\mathbb N$, show that $f$ sends $\mathbb N$ to $\mathbb N$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $f:\mathbb N\to\mathbb R$ is a function such that
$$\prod_{d\mid n}f(d)=2^n$$holds for all $n\in\mathbb N$, show that $f$ sends $\mathbb N$ to $\mathbb N$. -/
theorem number_theory_88517 (f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÄ n, ‚àè d in n.divisors, f d = 2 ^ n) :
    ‚àÄ n, ‚àÉ m, f n = m ‚àß m > 0 := by

3. Prove the proposition in question 2 by the following means:
(i) The proposition holds when $a=1$.
(ii) The proposition holds when $a=b$.

Hereafter, assume $a>b>1$.
(iii) There exist integers $T, c, |c| \leqslant a / 2$, such that
$$c^{2}-b=a T=a A m^{2}, \quad A, m \in \boldsymbol{Z},$$

where $A$ is a square-free number. Prove: $0<A<a$.
(iv) $x^{2} \equiv A(\bmod b)$ has a solution.
(v) $x^{2} \equiv-A b /(A, b)^{2}(\bmod (A, b))$ has a solution.
(vi) The indeterminate equation $A x^{2}+b y^{2}=z^{2}$ satisfies the conditions (i), (ii), and (iii).
(vii) If $x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}$ are non-trivial solutions of the indeterminate equation in (vi), then $x=A m x_{0}$, $y=c y_{0}+z_{0}, z=c z_{0}+b y_{0}$ are non-trivial solutions of $a x^{2}+b y^{2}=z^{2}$.
(viii) Reduce the proposition to the case of (i) or (ii).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Prove the proposition in question 2 by the following means:
(i) The proposition holds when $a=1$.
(ii) The proposition holds when $a=b$.

Hereafter, assume $a>b>1$.
(iii) There exist integers $T, c, |c| \leqslant a / 2$, such that
$$c^{2}-b=a T=a A m^{2}, \quad A, m \in \boldsymbol{Z},$$

where $A$ is a square-free number. Prove: $0<A<a$.
(iv) $x^{2} \equiv A(\bmod b)$ has a solution.
(v) $x^{2} \equiv-A b /(A, b)^{2}(\bmod (A, b))$ has a solution.
(vi) The indeterminate equation $A x^{2}+b y^{2}=z^{2}$ satisfies the conditions (i), (ii), and (iii).
(vii) If $x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}$ are non-trivial solutions of the indeterminate equation in (vi), then $x=A m x_{0}$, $y=c y_{0}+z_{0}, z=c z_{0}+b y_{0}$ are non-trivial solutions of $a x^{2}+b y^{2}=z^{2}$.
(viii) Reduce the proposition to the case of (i) or (ii). -/
theorem number_theory_6685 {a b : ‚Ñï} (ha : 1 < b) (hb : b < a) :
    (‚àÉ x y z, x ‚â† 0 ‚àß y ‚â† 0 ‚àß z ‚â† 0 ‚àß a * x ^ 2 + b * y ^ 2 = z ^ 2) ‚Üî
    a = 1 ‚à® a = b := by

soln_description: Yes Solution We require N = m + (m+1) + ... + (m+1989) = 1990m + 1989¬∑1990/2 = 5¬∑199(2m+1989). So N must be odd and divisible by 5 and 199. We also require that there are just 1990 pairs m, n such that N = m + (m+1) + ... + (m+n) = (n+1) (n+2m)/2, or equivalently, such that 2N = (n+1)(n+2m). Note that n+1  1, we can take n+1 to be A and m to be (B+1-A)/2. Since N is odd, just one of A, B will be even, so (B+1-A) is even and m is integral. Thus we require 2N to have 2¬∑1991 factors (the extra two are the pair 1 and N which do not give a solution) = 2¬∑11¬∑181. We know that 2N has factors 2, 5, 199, so it cannot have any others. The factor 2 1 gives rise to the factor (1+1) = 2, the other two must give rise to the 11 and the 181. So N = 5 10 199 180 or 5 180 199 10 . 31st IMO shortlist 1990 ¬© John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 7 Aug 2003 Last updated/corrected 7 Aug 2003

$$
\begin{array}{l}
A(-1,4), B(1,1), \\
C(-1,-2), D(-3,1) .
\end{array}
$$

Consider the family of lines $2 x-3 y=k$, i.e.,
$$
y=\frac{2}{3} x-\frac{k}{3} \text {, }

/- Example 1 Given real numbers $x, y$ satisfy

Then the maximum value of $2 x-3 y$ is $\qquad$ (1) -/
theorem inequalities_324592 :
    IsGreatest {z : ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ x y, z = 2 * x - 3 * y ‚àß 3 * abs (x + 1) + 2 * abs (y - 1) ‚â§ 6} 4 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_324592 :
    IsGreatest {z : ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ x y, z = 2 * x - 3 * y ‚àß 3 * abs (x + 1) + 2 * abs (y - 1) ‚â§ 6} 4 := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that 4 can be obtained (feasibility)
    use -1, -2
    norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos]
    <;> linarith

  ¬∑ -- Show that 4 is the greatest value (optimality)
    intro z hz
    rcases hz with ‚ü®x, y, h_eq, h_abs‚ü©
    by_cases h1 : x + 1 ‚â• 0
    ¬∑ -- Case where x + 1 ‚â• 0
      rw [abs_of_nonneg h1] at h_abs
      by_cases h2 : y - 1 ‚â• 0
      ¬∑ -- Case where y - 1 ‚â• 0
        rw [abs_of_nonneg h2] at h_abs
        linarith
      ¬∑ -- Case where y - 1 < 0
        rw [abs_of_neg (lt_of_not_ge h2)] at h_abs
        linarith
    ¬∑ -- Case where x + 1 < 0
      rw [abs_of_neg (lt_of_not_ge h1)] at h_abs
      by_cases h2 : y - 1 ‚â• 0
      ¬∑ -- Case where y - 1 ‚â• 0
        rw [abs_of_nonneg h2] at h_abs
        linarith
      ¬∑ -- Case where y - 1 < 0
        rw [abs_of_neg (lt_of_not_ge h2)] at h_abs
        linarith
